WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility I The initial hydraulic conductivity testing was conducted using eight and 12 percent bentonite (by weight), 2 based on the results of the admix testing program conducted by Golder for the W025 Project (Golder, 3 1991 b). The target laboratory hydraulic conductivity was less than 10-8 cm/sec when permeated with 4 water. Testing was not conducted with leachate, as no actual leachate exists for the planned waste at this 5 time. Golder Associates used a synthetic leachate to perform compatibility testing on the admix liner. 6 Based on these results, they increased the bentonite percentage from 8 to 12 percent, hence the use of 7 these values in these tests. Because the base soils are expected to be similar to that used by Golder for the 8 W025 landfill, and until a more refined characterization of the IDF leachate is developed, the 9 compatibility testing performed for the W025 project was considered applicable to the IDF project. 10 Hydraulic conductivity testing was performed on all samples in flexible wall triaxial cells with 11 backpressure saturation, in general accordance with ASTM D5084. An effective confining stress of 12 5 pounds per square in (psi) was applied to each test cell. Appendix B.1 includes the details for the test, 13 including the inflow and outflow data used to confirm that each test had obtained a steady-state hydraulic 14 conductivity value. 15 After the initial hydraulic conductivity testing was completed, additional samples were set up to 16 determine the range of moisture and density parameters that are expected to produce the required 17 hydraulic conductivity in the field. 18 As noted above, the samples used for the testing were gathered from the surface sampling program. Once 19 a more comprehensive exploration program is conducted within the IDF footprint, the suitability of the 20 soils within the excavation below a depth of 5 feet (upper 2-3 feet) can be examined for use as a base soil 21 for the admix. 22 4.2.3 Geosynthetics Interface Shear Testing 23 A limited soil-to-geosynthetic interface shear testing program was conducted to determine the interface 24 shear values between the operations soil and the composite drainage net (CDN), and the admix liner soils 25 and the high-density polyethylene (HDPE). These interfaces are site specific because of the unique nature 26 of the soils, hence their behavior in interface shear. The testing was conducted by Precision Geotechnical 27 Laboratories in Anaheim, California. Soil samples collected during the surface sampling program were 28 used for testing; GSE Lining Technologies, Inc. based in Houston, Texas provided the geosynthetics for 29 testing. 30 The interface shear tests were conducted in general accordance with ASTM D5321-Standard Test 31 Method for Determining the Coefficient of Soil and Geosynthetic or Geosynthetic and Geosynthetic 32 Friction by the Direct Shear Method. The tests were conducted for both low (100 to 500 psf) and high 33 (1000 to 8000 psf) normal stress levels, to account for the variation in normal stresses that will be applied 34 across the lining system in the final landfill configuration. Both the peak and residual strength values 35 were determined during testing. Additional details for the tests are presented with the test results in 36 Appendix B.2. 37 Asperity testing was also conducted on the textured HDPE geomembrane, in general accordance with 38 GRI-GM12 -Asperity Height of Textured Geomembrane. The purpose of the asperity testing was to 39 establish a baseline roughness of the texturing of the HDPE geomembrane and for future assessments of 40 the interface shear strength of other textured HDPE geomembrane products (e.g., from other 41 manufacturers). 42 Site-specific interface shear testing was not conducted for geosynthetic-to-geosynthetic (such as CDN to 43 geosynthetic clay liner [GCL]) interfaces in this phase of design, as these values are primarily a function 44 of the manufactured product properties. A database of values for geosynthetic-to-geosynthetic interface 45 testing was used to determine the appropriate interface shear values for design. During construction, the 46 actual materials used on the site will be tested as part of the construction QC/QA, to ensure that the 47 installed materials used onsite meet or exceed the interface shear strength values used in the design. WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 * Action leakage rate 2 * Building systems analyses 3 * Civil grading 4 5.1 Slope Stability 5 Slope stability for the IDF landfill was examined for liner veneer (side slope) stability, earthwork 6 stability, waste/fill global stability. The analyses for each of these cases are summarized in the sections 7 below; Appendices C.1.a through C. I.c presents the analyses and results in detail. 8 5.1.1 Liner Veneer (Side Slope) Stability 9 The veneer stability of the liner system on the side slopes was evaluated for the period prior to waste 10 filling. The analysis examined the potential for sliding of the drainage and operations layers on the liner 11 system before waste is placed. 12 The analyses were conducted using the weakest of the interface strengths of the various lining system 13 components. The interface strengths were determined from regression analyses of data gathered from 14 various sources, including site-specific test data completed to date. Based on the data (presented in 15 Appendix C. .a), the critical interface is the textured HDPE/CDN interface. Properties of the cover soil 16 (operations layer) were determined from laboratory testing to date on the materials expected to be used 17 for the operations layer. 18 Four loading conditions were examined: 19 * Dead load: self-weight of the lining system (including the first operations layer) 20 * Dead load + Equipment: self-weight of the lining system with an equipment load 21 * Dead load + Seepage: self-weight of the lining system with a seepage load (to account for fluid 22 head in the leachate collection system); seepage loads were based on results from the leachate 23 system hydraulic analyses 24 * Seismic Loading: self-weight of the lining system with seismic loading 25 The results of the analyses show that the lining system is stable for the conditions analyzed and no 26 anchorage forces are required to meet the minimum factors of safety (1.5 for dead load only; 1.3 for 27 equipment and seepage loading). A minimum interface friction of 25 degrees and cohesion of 0 psf is 28 required to meet the minimum acceptable factors of safety. The slopes are also considered to be stable 29 under seismic loading, based on comparing the calculated yield acceleration and with the design 30 acceleration values provided in the design criteria by CH2M HILL (September, 2002), using the hazard 31 classification assigned to the overall facility. 32 The critical interface friction values will be verified during construction to ensure that the system will be 33 stable. The analyses and results are presented in full detail in Appendix C. I.a. 34 5.1.2 Earthwork Stability 35 The earthwork stability analysis covered the following three cases: 36 Excavation Case: This case covers the stability of the landfill slopes immediately after excavation and 37 before placement of the lining system. Only static loading was considered since this is an interim 38 configuration that will only exist for the construction period. 39 Ramp Case: This case covers the stability of the landfill slopes and access ramp at the south end of the 40 cell, including equipment loading on the ramps. Both static and seismic loading were examined, as the 41 access ramps are expected to be in use for a period of at least 10 years. 42 Dike Case: This case covers the stability of the perimeter dike (shine berm and access road) after 43 construction of the dike and before final closure of the landfill. Appendix 4A.1.44

--- Page 130 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 Both static and seismic loading were examined, since the perimeter dike may be in place until the final 2 cover system is completed (greater than 10 years). 3 Properties for the native soils are based on existing information, as a site-specific geotechnical 4 engineering investigation program has not yet been completed for the IDF facility. When this 5 investigation is completed, the results of this analysis (and any others that rely on the properties of the 6 native soils) will be verified. Geometry used in the analyses is based on the civil plans (generally 3H:1V 7 slopes with a few short 2H:1V slopes). 8 The results of the analyses show that the planned configurations of the landfill are stable under static 9 loading (factor of safety [FS] greater than 1.3 and 1.5, depending on the case analyzed); the 10 configurations are also considered seismically stable based on the criteria for the Hanford site. Full 11 details on the analysis method, the input data, and the results are presented in Appendix C. I.b. 12 5.1.3 Waste/Fill Global Stability 13 This analysis examined the following conditions: 14 Phase I Full Build-Out: This case examined the stability of the waste mass in full build-out of the Phase 15 1 waste cell. The critical stability examined was the waste sliding on the lining system. Both static and 16 seismic loading conditions were examined. 17 Final Configuration: This case examined the stability of the waste mass at the final configuration (entire 18 IDF landfill completed) along the edge of the cover system. Only static loading conditions were 19 examined, since this system is not being designed as part of the current effort. 20 Interim filling conditions and the internal stability of the waste mass were not examined. The internal 21 waste mass stability will primarily be a function of the filling methodology. Possible filling plans for the 22 waste are currently being developed. 23 For the analysis of the full build-out of Phase I, the critical interface strengths in the lining system were 24 determined in the same way as for the veneer stability (regression analyses of existing and site specific 25 testing data). A combination of peak and residual strengths were used, based on methodology currently 26 being employed in the state of the practice. A final check was also made to confirm that the use of 27 residual strengths in all locations resulted in a factor of safety greater than 1.0. 28 The results show that the system is stable for the configurations analyzed and for the interface friction 29 values available at the time of the analyses (FS greater than 1.5 in static loading and yield acceleration 30 greater than the 10,000-year event). The system also has a FS greater than 1.0 for the case of residual 31 strengths in all locations. The critical interfaces are the HDPE-CDN on the side slopes (using residual 32 strengths) and the HDPE-GCL on the base liner (using peak strengths) and the internal GCL strength 33 (using residual strengths). These results should be verified when additional site-specific test data 34 becomes available prior to and during construction. 35 Also, it should be noted that for the full Phase I build-out configuration, the most critical case appears to 36 be a failure surface that is allowed to propagate through the waste mass. As noted previously, the waste 37 mass was considered internally stable for this design effort. During final operations planning, the internal 38 stability of the waste will be examined in conjunction with the proposed waste filling plan. 39 For the final configuration with the cover in place, the preliminary geometry and assumed cover system 40 properties show that the configuration is stable under static loading (FS greater than 1.5) and the critical 41 failure does not intersect the waste mass. Stability of the final configuration under both static and seismic 42 loading should be examined in more detail as the final design develops for the final closure of the entire 43 IDF facility. 44 A full discussion of the methodology, input data, and the results is presented in Appendix C.I.c. WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 5.2 Landfill Bearing Capacity 2 5.2.1 Subgrade Soil 3 Based on the available geotechnical data from other projects (as discussed in Section 4), the strength of 4 the native subgrade soils beneath the landfill is expected to be greater than that for the operations layer or 5 any of the liner system components. Greater strengths equate to higher bearing capacities, and hence, the 6 bearing capacity of the subgrade soils within the landfill cell was not determined directly as they are not 7 the controlling factor. 8 The bearing capacity of the subgrade soils beneath the supporting structures adjacent to the landfill cell 9 was determined for the structural analyses, discussed under Section 5.12.1-Geotechnical Design 10 Parameters, and the results of the analyses are presented in Appendix C.1 l.a. 11 5.2.2 Liner Soils 12 The soil layers in the lining system include the operations layer, drain gravel, and the admix liner soils. 13 The admix liner soils will be placed beneath the geosynthetic lining system, and as such, loading on the 14 admix liner soils is limited to the allowable loads for the GCL. The allowable loads for the GCL are 15 much less than what the bearing capacity of the admix liner soils would be (the admix soils have much 16 higher strengths, particularly for bearing pressures). The drain gravel will be placed just above the lining 17 system; the shear strength and associated bearing capacity are also much greater than the GCL allowable 18 values. 19 At the time of these calculations, structures that would cause bearing pressure were not yet determined. 20 Hence, the bearing capacity for the operations soils was calculated for foundation widths from I to 10 feet 21 and for 2 different shapes (square and strip). Properties for the operations soils were based on laboratory 22 testing conducted to date; these properties will be verified during construction to ensure that the analyses 23 results are valid. 24 For a factor of safety of 3, the allowable bearing capacities for the operations layer are presented in 25 Table 5-1. Table 5-1. Operations Soil Bearing Capacities B, Foundation Width (feet) gall, square foundation (tsf) ga1, strip foundation (tsf) 1 0.20 0.33 5 1.0 1.6 10 2.0 3.3 26 As the operations plans are further developed, these values can be updated for the planned structures 27 (such as barrier walls). Details of the analyses are presented in Appendix C.2. 28 5.3 Settlement and Uplift Analyses 29 5.3.1 Settlement Analysis of Liner Foundation 30 The long term settlement of the soils supporting the geosynthetic liner system was estimated based on the 31 maximum loading expected in the landfill at the final IDF completion. The two soil units examined were 32 the admix liner soils and the native subgrade soils. For the admix soils, data from laboratory 33 consolidation testing performed on samples available at the time of the analysis were used to determine 34 the estimated settlements. Elastic methods were used to estimate the settlements of the subgrade soils. 35 As detailed in Appendix C.3, the estimated long term settlement over the lifetime of the landfill is 2.7 feet 36 under the maximum loading. 37 5.3.2 Subsidence and Sinkhole Potential 38 Subsidence of undisturbed foundation materials is generally the result of dissolution, fluid extraction 39 (water or petroleum), or mining. Subsidence is not expected to occur based on the following: Appendix 4A.1.46

--- Page 132 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 * The soils underlying the IDF are generally dense, coarse-grained, and well-graded sands and 2 gravels that will not be subject to piping effects that could transport soil and result in subsidence. 3 Also, sands and gravels are generally not susceptible to dissolution. 4 * The groundwater level is deep and will not affect bearing soils. 5 * The bedrock is basalt (volcanic), which is not generally susceptible to dissolution. 6 * No mining or tunneling has been reported in the areas beneath or surrounding the site for the IDF. 7 * Borings in and around the IDF have not identified any soluble materials in the foundation soils or 8 underlying sediments. Consequently, the potential for any sinkhole development will be 9 negligible. 10 5.3.3 Uplift Potential 11 The potential for uplift of the composite liner system is very low. The seasonal high-water level is over 12 200 feet below the base of the base of the landfill cell, so no external hydrostatic pressure is expected 13 from this source. Perched groundwater is not expected to occur due to the absence of continuous 14 aquitards (such as a clay layer) within the coarse-grained native soils at the IDF site. Any infiltration that 15 does occur is expected to percolate rapidly to deeper soil layers. 16 Gas pressures are also expected to be negligible, as no gas-generating material (i.e., organic material) is 17 expected in the foundation soils. Also, the subgrade soils are coarse grained and unsaturated, so any gas 18 that might occur is expected to be rapidly dissipated. 19 5.4 Admix Liner 20 5.4.1 Mix Design 21 WAC 173-303-665(2)(h)(i)(B) requires that the lower component of a composite bottom liner be 22 constructed of compacted soil material with an in-situ hydraulic conductivity no greater than 10-7 cm/sec. 23 Because of the lack of naturally occurring soils on-site that could achieve this requirement, a test program 24 was developed to determine the admixture requirements for a mixed soil design using on-site base soil 25 from either the Phase I excavation or dune sand borrow area (see Drawing H-2-830826 for location) and 26 sodium bentonite. Details of the base soil field exploration and admix testing program are provided in 27 Section 4. 28 The results of the limited field exploration for base soil samples and subsequent admix testing program 29 discussed in Section 4 show that a nominal bentonite content of 12 percent will meet the laboratory target 30 hydraulic conductivity of less than 10-8 cm/sec when permeated with water. The laboratory target was 31 established based on results of the soil liner/leachate compatibility study (Golder Associates, 1991b) for 32 the W025 landfill. Details of Golder's study are discussed in Section 5.6. The W025 study concluded 33 that the bentonite content of the admix should be increased from 8 percent (the minimum bentonite 34 percent needed to achieve the required hydraulic conductivity) to 12 percent, to provide adequate 35 resistance against high inorganic concentrations in the synthetic leachate for the W025 project. Index 36 laboratory testing on the limited field exploration at the IDF site (surface sampling) established that the 37 base soil for the IDF was similar to the W-025 project, as discussed in Section 4. Thus, until a more 38 refined characterization of the IDF leachate is developed, the compatibility testing from the W025 testing 39 is applicable to the IDF mix design. 40 Once initial hydraulic testing confirmed that an admix with 12 percent bentonite content could achieve 41 the laboratory target value, additional samples were set up to evaluate a range of moisture and density 42 parameters and their effect on hydraulic conductivity. The additional hydraulic conductivity tests were 43 performed to define moisture content-density requirements for a range of compactive energy, as outlined 44 by Daniel and Benson (1990). This data was being used to develop an "acceptable" zone of moisture and 45 density for use by QC personnel during construction. The acceptable zone for the 12 percent admix is 46 presented along with the admix design laboratory test results in Appendix B. 1. Appendix 4A. 1.47

--- Page 133 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility I The acceptable zone was developed based on samples that achieved a hydraulic conductivity of less than 2 10-8 cm/sec. A lower bound of 95 percent relative compaction, based on Standard Proctor (ASTM D698) 3 compactive effort, was established to ensure adequate shear strength levels. The intent of the placement technical specifications is to help ensure that the admix liner 12 will meet an in-place performance specification for hydraulic conductivity of less than l x10-7 cm/sec. 13 The contractor is responsible for developing and implementing compaction means and methods that will 14 produce the required relative compaction. 15 The recommended nominal bentonite percentage (12 percent) and moisture-density parameters for the 16 admix liner have been developed with a one order of magnitude factor of safety between laboratory and 17 field values for hydraulic conductivity. The factor of safety is expected to account for two issues: (1) 18 variations in the hydraulic conductivity between the laboratory soil amendment study and full-scale 19 production, and (2) the laboratory samples were permeated with water rather than leachate, which could 20 lead to a difference in the field hydraulic conductivity. However, factors such as base soil variability at 21 the borrow source and field placement and construction are difficult to quantify until full-scale production 22 begins for the admix liner. A test pad will be constructed as part the IDF construction to model the full- 23 scale production. The purpose of the test pad is to determine acceptable processing, placement, and 24 compaction methods that will produce a low-hydraulic conductivity admix liner with an in situ hydraulic 25 conductivity of 10-7 cm/sec or less. The bentonite percentage and moisture content/density range may be 26 modified if the preconstruction testing performed on the test pad indicates an in situ hydraulic 27 conductivity greater than 10-7 cm/sec. Construction QA sampling and testing for the test pad is described 28 in the Detailed Design Cell 1 Construction QA Plan (CH2M HILL, March 2004). 29 5.4.3 Freeze/Thaw 30 Compacted soil liners, such as the IDF admix liner, are known to be vulnerable to large increases in 31 hydraulic conductivity due to freeze/thaw cycling; current data suggests that compacted soil bentonite 32 admixtures may not be as vulnerable to damage as true clay liners (Kim and Daniel, 1992; Benson and 33 Othman, 1993; Kraus et al., 1997). Existing laboratory data indicate that GCLs are less susceptible to 34 damage from freeze/thaw conditions and therefore, do not undergo increases in hydraulic conductivity 35 (Hewitt and Daniel, 1997; Kraus et al., 1997). 36 In order to provide adequate freeze/thaw protection for the admix liner and avoid potential damage to the 37 GCL a protective soil cover can be used. The thickness of the protective soil cover should exceed the 38 predicted freeze depth. For the IDF, protective soil cover is provided by the operations layer on the side 39 slope (3 feet) and the drain gravel and operation layer (4 feet total) on the bottom liner. 40 The analysis was performed on the IDF lining system operations layer to determine the freeze depth or 41 frost penetration for a probable freezing season during the 10-year expected period of waste filling. 42 Appendix 4A. 1.48

--- Page 134 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility I Both a 10-year return period (90 percent probability on non-exceedance) and 20-year return period (95 2 percent probability on non-exceedance) air freeze index (AFI) were used to estimate maximum frost 3 penetration depth in the operations layer. If the maximum frost penetration depth were less than the 3- 4 foot minimum thickness operations layer over the lining system, the proposed operations layer thickness 5 would be considered as adequate protection for exposure of the lining system to freeze-thaw cycles. 6 For the 10-year return AFI, the maximum freeze depth is estimated at 17 inches. For the 20-year return 7 AFI, the maximum freeze depth is estimated at 21 inches. The maximum estimated freeze depths for both 8 the 10-year and 20-year return period freezing seasons indicate that the proposed cover soil thicknesses 9 provide more than adequate protection for the underlying admix liner and GCL from potential damage 10 when subject to freeze-thaw cycles. Details of the freeze depth calculations are included in 11 Appendix C.4. 12 5.5 Geosynthetic Liner Design 13 5.5.1 Geomembrane Liner Tension Caused By Thermal Contraction 14 The HDPE geomembrane for IDF lining system will be subject to temperature-induced tensile strain from 15 expansion/contraction as the geomembrane is exposed to temperature fluctuation. 16 Strain on the liner was calculated using published values for the coefficient of linear thermal expansion 17 for HDPE geomembrane (Koerner, 1998) and applying this to the maximum slope length. The maximum 18 length is measured from the top of the slope, where liner is anchored, to the toe of the 3H:IV side slope. 19 This is a conservative approach, as using the maximum slope length results in the maximum amount of 20 expansion and strain on the liner. Additionally, a conservative temperature change of 40 degrees C 21 (104 degrees F) was used in the analysis. 22 The maximum liner strain was estimated to be less than 0.5 percent, based on a maximum temperature 23 change of 40 degrees C (104 degrees F). The estimated maximum of slack in the liner on the side slope is 24 8.6 inches. The corresponding amount of temperature induced stress is 566 psi. See Appendix C.5.a for 25 supporting calculations. 26 As shown in the technical specifications, Section 02661 (Table 1), the elongation at yield for the 27 geomembrane that will be used in the liner system is at least 12 percent, with a minimum tensile strength 28 at yield of 2,000 psi. Therefore, the maximum anticipated strains are well below the yield tensile strain 29 and stress for the HDPE geomembrane, and temperature-induced strain will have no adverse impact on 30 lining system function. 31 It should be noted that temperature-induced strain is only applicable during the construction period when 32 the HDPE geomembrane is exposed to temperature fluctuation. Once covered with 3 to 4 feet of cover 33 soils (drain gravel and operations layer), the ambient temperature at the surface of the geomembrane will 34 be more controlled and not subject to fluctuation. 35 During installation, care must be taken to allow for expansion/contraction of the HDPE geomembrane to 36 minimize the development of wrinkles that could become future stress points under soil and waste 37 loading. The technical specifications (see Section 02661) provide requirements for control of wrinkle 38 development during liner deployment, including the limitation of working when the temperature is below 39 0 degrees C (32 degrees F) or above 40 degrees C (104 degrees F) without implementing installation 40 procedures that address the environmental conditions. 41 5.5.2 Liner System Strain Due To Settlement 42 The barrier components (geomembrane and GCL) for the IDF lining system will be subject to settlement- 43 induced tensile strains as the underlying soils, primarily the admix soil liner and the subgrade soil, settle 44 over time. Strain within the lining system was calculated based on the results of the liner foundation 45 settlement calculations (see Section 5.3 for settlement of foundation soil [subgrade] and admix liner). Appendix 4A. 1.49

--- Page 135 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 The strain calculation assumed that all vertical settlement was translated into strain along the liner rather 2 than just the vector component parallel to the liner. This is a conservative assumption that establishes an 3 upper bound for liner strain. 4 The maximum liner strain was estimated to be less than 0.6 percent, based on a maximum estimate of 5 2.7 feet of settlement at the base of the lining system. See Appendix C.5.b for supporting calculations. 6 As shown the technical specification (Section 02661, Table 1), the elongation at yield for the 7 geomembrane that will be used in the liner system is at least 12 percent. Based on studies of effect of 8 differential settlement on GCLs (LaGatta et al., 1997), the limiting strain was defined as the strain in 9 which an increase in hydraulic conductivity of the GCL was observed, which was taken as 5 percent. 10 Therefore, the maximum anticipated strains are well below the yield or limiting tensile strain for the 11 barrier components of the lining system (geomembrane and GCL). Settlement-induced strain from 12 foundation and admix soil settlement under maximum landfill content pressure will have no adverse 13 impact on lining system function. 14 5.5.3 Anchor Trench Pullout Resistance 15 During construction, the geomembrane could experience pullout forces caused by thermal 16 expansion/contraction or wind uplift. However, tension from thermal expansion and contraction is 17 expected to be small (see Section 5.5.1), and the geosynthetics installer can use sand bags or other 18 approved method to control wind uplift during installation. 19 After construction and placement of operation layer, the pullout forces on the geomembrane are expected 20 to be negligible, as there is no tension force on the liner. As indicated in the veneer (side slope) stability 21 analyses (see Section 5.1.1), the lining system interface strength exceeds the slope angle on the 3H: IV 22 side slope. Thus, the pullout resistance requirements for the anchor trench are to support the self-weight 23 of the geomembrane and other lining system components. Analyses for liner self-weight support 24 requirements determined that the frictional resistance between geosynthetics exceeds the liner self-weight. 25 Thus, no additional pullout resistance is needed at the anchor trench to support lining system self-weight. 26 Supporting calculations for the anchor trench design, as shown on Drawing H-2-830838, Detail 3, are 27 included in Appendix C.5.c. Based on the calculations for the configuration shown in the drawing, a 28 pullout resistance ranging from 1840 pound/foot (lb/ft) to 2440 lb/ft is estimated (depending on actual 29 mobilized interface shear strength). The required minimum tensile yield strength for 60-mil HDPE 30 geomembrane in the technical specifications (see Section 02661) is 1440 lb/ft (120 lb/in), which results in 31 the estimated pullout resistance exceeding the geomembrane tensile yield strength. This situation is due 32 primarily to the configuration of the shine berm, which helps to anchor the system. While it is generally 33 not desired for the pullout resistance to exceed the yield strength, this is not expected to be a problem at 34 the IDF, since, as discussed above, the potential causes for geomembrane tension have been addressed 35 and there is not a scenario for mobilizing tensile or pullout forces on the lining system. 36 5.5.4 Puncture Resistance 37 The primary geomembrane in the IDF will be overlain by the LCRS. For the side slope lining system, the 38 LCRS consists of a CDN (see Detail 2 on Drawing H-2-830838) that provides protection for the primary 39 geomembrane from the overlying operations layer. A separate discussion of the CDN geotextile puncture 40 resistance is provided in Section 5.7.2. For the bottom lining (floor) system, the LCRS consists of drain 41 gravel overlying the geomembrane (see Detail I on Drawing H-2-830838). A geotextile cushion will be 42 required between the drainage gravel and the geomembrane to prevent the gravel from puncturing the 43 geomembrane. An analysis was performed to determine the weight of the geotextile fabric required to 44 prevent geomembrane puncture either from operating equipment loads or from the combined static weight 45 of the waste and final cover. 46 Appendix 4A.1.50

--- Page 136 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility I Koerner (1998) developed a method for estimating required geotextile thickness that considers the size 2 and shape of the rock, as well as other factors that could decrease the long-term strength of the 3 geomembrane. The equation used to determine puncture resistance is based on the mass per unit area of 4 the geotextile and the protrusion height of the puncturing material. 5 Operating loads were estimated based on a melter transport trailer operating directly on the surface of the 6 first operations layer. Static loads were estimated for the post-closure condition by using the weight of 7 four layers of ILAW packages with cover soil and a 15-foot-thick closure cover, with a 2 percent grade to 8 the center of the landfill. The static load was more than two times greater than the operating load, and 9 therefore was used as the basis for the puncture analysis. Detail calculations for geomembrane puncture 10 resistance and corresponding cushion geotextile requirements are included in Appendix C.5.d. 11 The proposed design specifies that the LCRS drainage gravel will have a gradation corresponding to 12 WSDOT Standard Specification 9-03.12(4). For subrounded rock or gravel, this is more representative of the specified drain gravel, the 15 FS increases to 8.9. The specified cushion geotextile (see technical specifications, Section 02371) has a 16 nominal weight of 12 oz/sq yd, and therefore should be adequate to prevent geomembrane puncture. 17 Koerner (1998) recommends a FS greater than 3.0 for the condition of packed stones on a geomembrane, 18 such as would be the case for drain gravel over the geomembrane at the IDF. 19 5.5.5 Operational/Equipment Loading 20 The effects of loading on the GCL from construction and operational equipment and activities were 21 examined. The maximum loads from the landfill waste itself were found to produce the highest loading 22 on the geomembrane and the CDN; these materials were selected based on this maximum loading, as 23 discussed in the previous sections. 24 The cases for construction equipment loading and operational loading on the GCL were examined, 25 including the extreme loading case of the crane placing the heaviest waste loads at its maximum reach, a 26 situation which produces very high pad loads. The expected loads were compared to the calculated 27 allowable GCL bearing capacity to determine if the loads would have an effect on the GCL. The 28 allowable GCL bearing capacity was determined from classical geotechnical theory and based on 29 manufacturer's strength data. 30 The results of the analyses are presented in detail in Appendix C.5.e. For the construction loading, the 31 analyses show that the specification requirements that limit construction loading are adequate to protect 32 the GCL, based on the standard construction equipment anticipated to be used at the IDF and as examined 33 in the calculations. 34 For the operational loading cases examined, the critical condition is the crane operating under an extreme 35 condition. The minimum dunnage requirement for the crane pads is 60 square feet, or if square, a 7.7-foot 36 by 7.7-foot dunnage pad. Lower loads will require less dunnage and can be calculated as detailed in 37 Appendix C.5.e. As discussed in the appendix, dunnage requirements calculated in this way are 38 appropriate as long as the lining system is functioning as intended (i.e., no moisture in the LDS). If 39 moisture enters the LDS and the GCL becomes hydrated, the dunnage requirements will be increased by a 40 factor of approximately 2.5. 41 It should also be noted that the primary purpose of the GCL in the IDF is not as a required lining system 42 component (such as the geomembrane or the admix liner), but to "deflect" leachate from defects or 43 pinholes in the primary geomembrane over the bottom area and longer-term storage areas (such as 44 leachate sump trough), where the leachate head potential is greatest. The primary purpose of the primary 45 GCL is to reduce the actual leakage rate into the LDS in the event of leak in the primary geomembrane. 46 Given these considerations, the GCL should perform as intended under anticipated equipment and 47 operational loading. Certain materials deteriorate over time when exposed to 6 chemicals that may be contained in hazardous leachate. It is important to anticipate the type and quality 7 of the leachate that the landfill will generate and select compatible liner materials. Data collected from 8 other similar low-level radioactive mixed waste and hazardous waste sites were used in conjunction with 9 the anticipated IDF leachate concentrations to evaluate the allowable concentration of leachate 10 constituents that could be in contact with the IDF landfill liner components. 11 5.6.1 Lining System Description 12 Detailed discussion of the lining system design elements is provided in Section 6. The addition of a GCL in the primary liner layer provides an extra measure 28 of protection, exceeding the requirements of WAC 173-303-665(2)(h)(i), which stipulates a single 29 geomembrane for the primary liner and composite for the secondary only. Because the landfill will comply with waste acceptance criteria for 31 WAC dangerous waste and RCRA facilities (as does the IDF), organic materials are not expected to be 32 present in the waste after processing. The proposed geosynthetic materials are susceptible to damage 33 from certain organic compounds but generally are not susceptible to damage from inorganic compounds, 34 even with extreme pH values. As a result, the lack of organic materials results in a relatively benign 35 leachate. 36 The source leachate generated for the W025 studies, was primarily based on the waste treatment and 37 packaging approaches for W025. An aqueous solution of inorganic, with some organic compounds for 38 conservative evaluation, was generated, resulting in a viscous, slurry-like mixture. This mixture was 39 placed in a leaching column, and deionized water was introduced to simulate the effects of leachate 40 generation. Although no organic components were anticipated in the waste, small quantities of benzene, 41 methanol, and light machine oil were included to simulate the presence of organic compounds in the 42 waste material. 43 The source leachate generated through the leachate column process was chemically analyzed with the 44 following results: Appendix 4A.1.53

In reality, as the landfill nears the end of its operational life, 11 concentrations of contaminants will decrease with time as the leachable waste mass is reduced. During 12 the post-closure period, a robust landfill cover will significantly reduce infiltration, and the corresponding 13 volume of leachate. Soluble contaminants leached from the waste will come in contact with the landfill 14 bottom liner system during the operation period (approximately 10 years for each of the four planned 15 phases) and minimum post closure period (30 years). The geosynthetics and admix lining system 16 components may be in contact with soluble contaminants as long as contaminants are present in the 17 landfill. 18 The expected chemical make up of the leachate for the IDF landfill was determined based on previously 19 conducted compatibility studies (as discussed above) applicable to the same waste stream (the W025 20 studies), summarized as follows. 21 5.6.3.1 Geomembrane 22 HDPE geomembranes can deteriorate from contact with certain leachates, resulting in a decrease of 23 elongation at failure, an increase in modulus of elasticity, a decrease in the stress at failure, and a loss of 24 ductility. 25 Studies performed on polymer materials like HDPE show that their properties begin to change after 26 absorbing ionizing radiation between 1,000,000 to 10,000,000 rads (Koerner et al., 1990). The HDPE 27 geomembrane lining the bottom of the landfill will absorb ionizing radiation energy from the leachate 28 generated in the landfill. Energy will be absorbed during the operational life of the landfill, as long as 29 there are liquids with ionizing radionuclides in contact with the geomembranes. 30 Relevant compatibility studies on HDPE geomembranes have been performed for the W-025 Landfill 31 (Golder, 1991a; TRI, 1995; WHC, 1995). The results of these studies indicate that a HDPE 32 geomembrane will function well as a liner beneath the landfill waste. Appendix 4A.1.55

--- Page 141 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 EPA Method 9090 tests performed on HDPE geomembrane for the W-025 landfill, using the synthetic 2 leachate solution (assumed representative of IDF leachate concentrations) resulted in no evidence of 3 geomembrane deterioration. A comparison between the anticipated IDF landfill leachate 4 (W-025 Landfill) and that used in compatibility tests for other facilities is summarized in Table 5-2. 5 Geomembrane samples tested for the W-025 facility did not produce measurable changes in the HDPE 6 liner properties when irradiated for 120 days with a total dose of 50,000 rads. HDPE geomembranes are 7 manufactured with additives, such as carbon black and antioxidants, to improve ductility and durability. 8 The literature also indicates that these additives allow higher doses than standard HDPE material without 9 additives (Kircher and Bowman, 1964). The literature indicates that thin films (i.e., 0.002 inches) of 10 different types of HDPE material alone can become brittle when irradiated at doses between 4,400,000 11 and 78,000,000 rads. Studies performed using polymer materials, with carbon black and antioxidant 12 additives, show that properties typically begin to change at a total radiation dose of between 1,000,000 13 and 10,000,000 rads (Koerner et al., 1990). 14 The manufacturers of the geosynthetic products proposed for the IDF landfill have published maximum 15 allowable concentrations of various chemical compounds that can contact the HDPE geomembrane 16 without adversely affecting its performance. The most recent recommended maximum concentrations of 17 chemicals were obtained from the manufacturers of HDPE geomembrane (meeting the requirements for 18 the IDF technical specifications). A list of the manufacturers' maximum allowable concentrations for 19 specific leachate constituents for HDPE geomembrane and the GCL materials is shown on Table 5-3. 20 5.6.3.2 Geosynthetic Clay Liner (GCL) 21 The GCL underlying the geomembrane in the IDF landfill consists of processed sodium bentonite clay, 22 sandwiched between two geotextile fabrics. Sodium bentonite is an ore comprised mainly of the 23 montmorillonite clay mineral with broad, flat, negatively charged platelets that attract water, which 24 hydrates the bentonite. The swelling provides the ability to seal around penetrations, giving the GCL its 25 self-healing properties. A GCL product with Volclay-type sodium bentonite (manufactured by CETCO) 26 is specified for installation at the landfill. 27 The compatibility of GCL materials is usually demonstrated by permeating the material with leachate and 28 then determining its hydraulic conductivity. Typically, solutions with high concentrations of 29 contaminants or pure products are allowed to permeate a sample under confining pressure and the 30 saturated hydraulic conductivity of the material is determined using ASTM methods such as ASTM 31 D5084. A significant increase in saturated hydraulic conductivity (approximately one order of 32 magnitude) for a sample permeated with leachate, compared with a sample permeated with water, would 33 be an indicator of incompatibility. 34 Based on review of the published studies (Ruhl and Daniel, 1997; Shackelford, et al., 2000; and EPA, 35 1995), GCLs perform well unless exposed to high concentrations of divalent cations, very acidic or basic 36 solutions, or solutions with a low dielectric constant (such as gasoline). The leachate expected at the IDF 37 will have a pH of 9.2, which is a mid-range pH. The studies further demonstrate that, when confined 38 under a higher normal load (greater than 2000 psf) or if water is the first wetting liquid (Daniel et al., 39 1997), GCLs will perform well when exposed to high divalent cation concentrations. The GCL for the 40 IDF lining system is expected to confine under normal loads in excess of 2000 psf as soon as the first lift 41 or waste is placed. 42 No studies were identified that considered the long-term effects of radiation on the physical properties of 43 GCL materials. Since long-term studies cannot be conducted, conservative radiation limitations have 44 been employed. Low-hydraulic conductivity soils have been used at multiple DOE facilities containing 45 radioactive waste. The only known potential adverse reaction that can occur with a GCL is high heat that 46 could dry out the materials. The amount of radioactivity is expected to be low in the IDF landfill waste 47 and will not generate a significant amount of heat that can desiccate the admix liner. Also, it is assumed 48 that the ILAW packages will be cooled to ambient temperatures prior to placement with the cell. Appendix 4A.1.56

--- Page 142 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility I It should be noted that the operations layer and drain gravel will provide a 3-foot buffer on the side slope 2 and a 4-foot buffer between the liner system and waste for additional thermal protection, if needed. 3 Sodium bentonite is the primary clay mineral in a GCL that produces the low hydraulic conductivity and 4 high swell potential. Exposure of sodium bentonite to liquids containing concentrated salts (such as 5 brines), or divalent cation concentrations (such as Ca++ and Mg++), reduces the swelling potential and 6 increases its hydraulic conductivity. Concentrated organic solutions (such as hydrocarbons) and strong 7 acids and bases can break down the soil, which also increases hydraulic conductivity. The physical 8 mechanism that causes these changes is a reduction of the thickness, and related absorption capacity, of 9 the diffuse double layer of water molecules surrounding the clay minerals. This results in an effective 10 decrease in the volume of the clay, since the water molecules are not attracted to the clay particles. 11 The GCL manufacturer allows the use of GCL with few restrictions on maximum chemical 12 concentrations. Leachate concentrations for the IDF landfill (based on synthetic leachate from W025) 13 have relatively high inorganics and dissolved salts. The W025 dissolved salt concentrations are above the 14 manufacturers recommended concentration of 35,000 mg/L (see Table 5-3) (CETCO, 2001). As a point 15 of reference, this concentration of dissolved salts is typical of seawater (USGS, 1989). However, the 16 dissolved salt concentrations in the IDF leachate have been characterized as primarily sodium, and the 17 synthetic leachate was comprised of entirely sodium salts, not the divalent cations such as Ca++ and 18 Mg++, as assumed by the manufacturers. As such, the impact on GCL hydraulic conductivity should be 19 less as compared to divalent cation solutions. Additionally, any effects of leachate degradation on the 20 GCL would be minimized by hydration of the GCLs' sodium bentonite with relatively "fresh" water, 21 allowing the GCL to swell initially and decrease hydraulic conductivity. 22 The rationale for use of the GCL in the IDF landfill primary liner is to "deflect" leachate from defects or 23 pinholes in the geomembrane over the bottom area and longer-term storage areas (such as the leachate 24 sump trough), where leachate head potential is greatest. The main purpose of the primary GCL is to 25 reduce the actual leakage rate into the LDS in the event of leak in the primary geomembrane (see 26 Section 5.10 and Appendix C.10). The GCL is expected to contact leachate only in the event of a leak in 27 the primary geomembrane. These leachate collection and storage areas are subject to flushing throughout 28 the active life of the landfill due to phased development and fill sequence, resulting in a more dilute 29 leachate in leakage areas prior to attaining maximum leachate concentrations. Based on these 30 considerations, the GCL and landfill liner system approach should perform as intended under the 31 anticipated conditions. 32 5.6.3.3 Admix Liner 33 The admix layer consists of onsite silty sand mixed with processed bentonite amendment, similar to that 34 used in the construction of GCLs. The swelling of sodium bentonite provides the ability to seal around 35 soil particles, giving the admix a low hydraulic conductivity and self-healing properties. The 36 compatibility of the admix layer with anticipated irradiation and leachate concentrations were evaluated 37 previously as part of the W025 landfill design (Golder Associates, 1991b). The following summarizes the 38 results of the compatibility testing for the admix layer that are directly applicable to the IDF landfill 39 admix liner, since similar materials will be used in construction. More detailed discussion of the IDF 40 admix liner design is provided in Section 5.4. 41 In the W025 study, samples of the admix were irradiated, similar to that conducted for the geomembrane 42 layer, as discussed previously. Differences between irradiated and non-irradiated samples were not 43 considered significant based on the results of testing. 44 The initial W025 admix design contained approximately 8 percent bentonite clay. Testing indicated an 45 acceptable hydraulic conductivity of this admix after hydration in fresh water. However, when hydrated 46 in leachate, some hydraulic conductivity test values were twice the allowable limit and, therefore, this 47 admix formulation was not considered acceptable. This is the same leachate chemistry assumed for the 48 IDF landfill. Appendix 4A.1.57

--- Page 143 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility I It should be noted that there are two factors not considered in the W025 compatibility study (Golder 2 Associates, 199 1b) that would mitigate the impact of the synthetic leachate on the 8 percent admix 3 samples, as listed below: 4 Effective stress for samples-hydraulic conductivity tests were performed with effective stresses of 5-10 5 psi across sample (equivalent to less than one full lift of ILAW packages). It is well documented that 6 higher effective stresses will lower hydraulic conductivity and mitigate the effects of shrinking/cracking 7 in clay under attack from chemicals. In reality, by the time any leachate contacts the lining system, there 8 will be a substantial stress load on the liner that will mitigate the impacts of chemicals in leachate on the 9 admix liner. 10 First wetting liquid-W025 tests were performed using both site water and synthetic leachate as the 11 initial wetting fluid. It is well documented that if a clay soil is "attacked" by inorganics prior to 12 saturation, the increase in hydraulic conductivity will be more dramatic than if water is first permeant. 13 This was confirmed by W025 testing-there was an order of magnitude difference between samples with 14 water as first wetting liquid as opposed to leachate. It is reasonable to expect something closer to water 15 than concentrated leachate will be the first wetting liquid for the IDF admix liner. 16 Due to the results in the W025 testing showing greater than acceptable hydraulic conductivity in the 17 admix when exposed to the W025 synthetic leachate, the bentonite percentage was increased from 8 to 18 12 percent. An admix containing 12 percent bentonite clay was permeated with synthetic leachate and 19 tested with a resulting hydraulic conductivity that was 3 to 10 times lower than the maximum allowable 20 limit (10-7 cm/sec). This admix formulation was considered acceptable with respect to W025 leachate 21 compatibility and is applicable to the IDF. Thus, the technical specifications (see Section 02666) require 22 a nominal 12 percent (range from 11 to 14 percent is acceptable) bentonite by weight for the admix liner. 23 Consideration should be given to lowering the bentonite percentage upon further characterization of the 24 IDF leachate and applicability of the mitigating factors discussed above. 25 5.6.3.4 Other Materials 26 Other materials for which compatibility needs to be addressed are the CDN and geotextiles (cushion, 27 separation, and bonded to geonet of CDN). While these materials do not serve a barrier function, they 28 provide either for removal of leachate or protection of the lining system and must continue to function 29 when exposed to leachate. 30 During the W025 design, the effect of the synthetic leachate on the geonet core of the CDN and the 31 geotextiles was evaluated (Golder Associates, 1991 a). The study concluded that a geonet core comprised 32 of HDPE provided adequate chemical and radiation resistance. For geotextiles, the study concluded that 33 geotextiles made of polyester fabric were susceptible to degradation and recommended that geotextile 34 material be limited to a more chemically resistant material such as polypropylene. The technical 35 specifications for the IDF require that geotextiles be made from polypropylene (see Section 02371); thus, 36 the geotextiles used for the IDF should have adequate chemical and radiation resistance. 37 Table 5-3. Results 11 indicated that natural filter criteria could not be achieved, thus a separation geotextile is required between 12 the operations layer and drain gravel. Supporting natural filter calculations are included in 13 Appendix C.6.a. 14 Analyses were conducted to determine the proper apparent opening size (AOS) and permittivity of the 15 separation geotextile. Results of these analyses were used to develop the technical specifications 17 for the separation geotextile (see Section 02371). Supporting geotextile filter calculations are also 18 included in Appendix C.6.A. 19 5.7.2 CDN Selection 20 The CDN selection was based on analysis of two design issues, CDN geotextile puncture resistance and 21 CDN required transmissivity. 22 5.7.2.1 CDN Geotextile Puncture Resistance 23 The LCRS CDN layer at the IDF will be overlain by the operations layer on the 3H: IV side slope. The 24 operations layer is allowed to contain a particle size up to 2 inches in dimension. An analysis was 25 performed to determine if the geotextile bonded to geonet (to form the CDN) would be punctured by 26 particles/rocks of this size. 27 The method developed by Koerner (1998) was used to calculate the puncture resistance. Koerner's 28 method considers the size and shape of the rock, as well as other factors that could decrease the long-term 29 strength of the geotextile. The two loading conditions examined were initial placement of the operations 30 layer and the final depth of waste and closure cover. The geomembrane puncture resistance analysis (see 31 Section 5.5.4) provides the details for the load analysis for these conditions. Detailed calculations for 32 CDN geotextile puncture resistance and corresponding cushion geotextile requirements are included in 33 Appendix C.6.bl. 34 Results of the analyses indicate that the required puncture resistance is 11.2 lbs. The minimum specified 35 value for Type I geotextile (see technical specifications, Section 02371) is 65 lbs. Applying a partial 36 safety factor of 2 gives a minimum resistance of 32.5 lbs. Therefore, the proposed geotextile bonded to 37 the geonet of the CDN will resist puncture with a global safety factor of 2.9; it is adequate for resistance 38 to puncture from the overlying operations layer under the pressure of maximum landfill contents pressure. 39 Koerner (1998) recommends a minimum global safety factor of 2.0. 40 It should be noted that the results of this analysis are considered conservative because the analytical 41 method assumes only a uniform particle size and does not take the surrounding soil matrix into 42 consideration. This would effectively reduce the particle size by a considerable degree. 43 5.7.2.2 CDN Required Transmissivity 44 An additional selection criteria for the CDN is the required transmissivity (or flow rate) under design 45 loading conditions. This exceedance makes an 42 allowance for two items: (1) it allows for the uncertainty in the empirical formulas used to predict 43 hydraulic conductivity, and (2) it also allows for the potential long-term reduction in hydraulic 44 conductivity in the drain gravel as fines from waste filling and the operations layer migrate into the gravel 45 over time. WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 As part of Construction QA, testing it is recommended that samples of imported drain gravel be tested for 2 conformance with the gradation and hydraulic conductivity requirements in the technical specifications. 3 5.8 Leachate Production 4 5.8.1 Leachate Production Analyses 5 Estimates of the amount of leachate produced during the development and operation of the IDF were 6 needed to design the components of the leachate collection and conveyance system described in Section 7 5.9, and to provide information necessary when evaluating slope stability of the side slope and bottom 8 liner systems. Leachate is produced when precipitation falls within the lined area and infiltrates vertically 9 through the waste and/or bottom liner system. The amount of infiltration estimated to occur depends on 10 the hydrologic processes and the relative fraction of precipitation that results as leachate and is collected 11 by the leachate collection system. 12 The water balance components of the hydrologic process were estimated using EPA's Hydrologic 13 Evaluation of Landfill Performance (HELP) Model (Schroeder et. al., 1997), a well known standard for 14 water balance modeling. The HELP model has been widely used for evaluating hydrologic conditions 15 and is the standard model used for providing information necessary for the design of landfill systems. 16 Estimates of the water balance components of the hydrologic cycle provided by HELP include 17 precipitation, evapotranspiration, surface water runoff, vertical percolation, soil moisture storage, and 18 lateral drainage in soil layers. 19 The HELP model requires input of weather data, representing the conditions at the landfill location, soils 20 data representing the various layers of cover soils, waste materials, and soils underlying the waste layers, 21 and other design data used by the model for water balance calculations. A detailed description of the 22 model and modeling inputs are included in Appendix C.7. 23 The development of the IDF from Phase I through Phase IV was considered to determine the maximum 24 flow condition expected during development and operation of the landfill. That is, various combinations 25 of open and interim closed phases were considered and the combination calculated to produce the 26 maximum amount of leachate was chosen for analysis. The chosen combination was Phase I through III 27 under interim closure condition and Phase IV in the open condition with little or no waste present. The 28 flows from this condition were used to size the LCRS collection piping and pump systems. 29 Water balance components were taken directly from model output and a spreadsheet was used to calculate 30 the volumes of leachate by multiplying the HELP output parameter by the area of the type of system 31 modeled. For example, the lateral drainage estimated by the HELP model for the uncovered side slope 32 condition in Phase IV development was multiplied by the total side slope area to determine the total 33 volume of leachate from that area. A spreadsheet summarizing the estimated leachate flows is included in 34 Appendix C.7. 35 The following modeling results were used for various aspects of design of the IDF systems: 36 LCRS collection system-Modeling results for the peak day event were used to size the leachate 37 collection system piping that conveys flow to the LCRS systems. The peak day event, as predicted by 38 HELP and referenced herein, was a 1.6-inch precipitation event. This event is approximately 25 percent 39 higher than the 25 year, 24 hour peak day storm event of 1.28 inches (Appendix C.9), required by 40 regulations to be used when complying with the maximum 12 inches of head over the liner 41 (WAC 173-303-665, see Section 2). The spacing of the LCRS perforated collection piping and the 42 properties of the drain gravel material that convey lateral drainage flows above the bottom liner 43 geomembrane to the collection piping and LCRS sump area were checked to insure the maximum head 44 buildup above the sump area of the liner system did not exceed the maximum allowed according to 45 regulatory requirements, as outlined in Section 2. 46 LCRS pump and forcemain systems-Modeling results for the peak day event were used to size the 47 LCRS high flow pump system that conveys flow to the leachate storage tanks and truck loadout facilities. The maximum loading occurs over the piping in the LCRS and LDS sump area, because of its 16 low elevation and the height of material-both waste and soil layers-overlying the sumps. Loading 17 calculations from the geosynthetic liner puncture resistance calculations described in Section 5.5.4 were 18 modified to represent the maximum loading in the LCRS/LDS sump area. Other pipes in the Phase I 19 area, including piping outside the sump and the side slope riser piping, will be subjected to less than the 20 maximum loading. The maximum loading is listed in Appendix C.8.a, along with the calculations for 21 pipe sizing required to withstand this anticipated pipe loading. 22 Pipe wall thickness was selected based on the maximum loading anticipated in the sump area such that 23 the pipe will not fail due to excessive deflection, wall buckling, or wall crushing. All other piping in 24 Phase I outside of the sump area was chosen with the same standard dimension ratio (SDR) to withstand 25 the maximum load. Standard analysis methods, as recommended by the manufacturer of HDPE pipe 26 made from PE3408 type resin, were used to evaluate pipe strength under loading. These standard 27 methods are based on flexible pipe design practice as applied to HDPE piping. The manufacturer's 28 recommended design analysis techniques are based on standard analysis techniques, including the Iowa 29 formula (Waste Containment Systems, Waste Stabilization, and Landfills Design and Evaluation, Sharma 30 and Lewis, 1994), with conservative factors of safety. The potential loss of strength due to the 31 perforations in the perforated collection piping was assumed non-significant, based on actual test results 32 of perforated pipe under similar load rates. The pipe material assumed is High Density Polyethylene 33 PE3408 pipe with a cell classification of 345434C or better. Since the pipe SDR 46 is sufficiently strong for the maximum loading inside the Phase I limits, it will have more than sufficient 47 strength for loading expected outside the Phase I limits. The maximum flow used for sizing was the 22 maximum from the HELP predicted maximum day flow rate or the pump flow rate, based on the pump 23 chosen to convey flow out of the cell. 24 Perforations in the pipe were sized to allow flow rates much higher than the required maximum flow rate 25 out of the cell, with minimal head loss. This assumption was more conservative by virtue of the fact that 26 the main LCRS collection pipe will only collect and convey a portion of the lateral drainage flow from the 27 cell; the drain gravel and CDN will also convey a portion of the flow. The criteria for pumping capacity is that the maximum head 35 over the sump area of the cell will not be allowed to exceed 12 inches during the peak day event and 36 during normal operations. To meet the requirement for not exceeding the 12-inch criteria for the peak day 37 event, a LCRS high flow pump was sized to handle the expected peak day flow rate, as estimated and 38 described in Section 5.8, Leachate Production. Hydraulic analyses were conducted to size the pump and 39 forcemain piping according to standard practice to convey the maximum flow rate. 40 A LCRS low flow pump was sized to convey flow out of the cells under normal, monthly operations. The 41 criteria established for the low flow pump was to convey the average monthly flow plus one standard 42 deviation from the cells, assuming the pump could remove that amount of flow with less than continuous 43 operation. The highest value of the average month plus one standard deviation was used for the 44 maximum flow required of the pump. Under lower flow required conditions, the pump would operate 45 near this rate, depending on the system curve head loss characteristics, but would run for a shorter length 46 of time to remove the volume of leachate from the cell. 47 Appendix 4A. 1.63

Pump cycle times were considered for the flow requirements and 33 total removed volume. The manufacturer's recommendations for cycle times and other operating 34 requirements, where applicable, were checked. 35 5.9.2.4 Leachate Collection Storage Analyses 36 The results of the leachate production analysis indicate a total of approximately 269,000 gallons of 37 leachate must be removed from the IDF landfill within 24 hours after a peak storm event. A temporary 38 storage tank for each cell was sized to store leachate generated by the associated cell. The leachate 39 storage tank capacity is dependent on the flow rate of leachate into and out of the tank as well as a factor 40 of safety. 41 The leachate production analysis indicates the worst case flow rate out of each cell into the associated 42 tank would be 157 gpm (sum of the required flow rates of the high and low flow leachate pumps). The 43 leachate transfer pump for each cell can fill a tanker truck at a maximum of 250 gpm; however, the 44 limiting factor is how often a truck can be filled. 45 The calculation in Appendix C.8.c presents the method of determining the appropriate storage capacity of 46 each leachate storage tank. The following leachate tanker truck loading activities were assumed: 47 * Tanker Capacity 7,000 gallons 48 * Number of tankers per cycle 1 Appendix 4A. 1.64

--- Page 150 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 * Hours per cycle (roundtrip) 2.4 2 * Hours per shift 8 3 * Shifts per day 1 4 * Leachate tank level prior to event 2 feet 5 The calculation indicates that each tank requires a maximum operational capacity of 375,000 gallons to 6 maintain a safety factor of 1.5. The assumptions made in the calculation must be adhered to during 7 operational activities to maintain the calculated safety factor. 8 5.10 Surface Stormwater 9 The surface stormwater analysis was done to determine the sizes of the surface stormwater facilities 10 necessary for the IDF Phase I Critical Systems Design. The surface stormwater analysis is documented in 11 detail in Appendix C.9. 12 The governing regulation is WAC 173-303-665(2) (c) and (d). This requires that the stormwater system 13 be designed to prevent flow onto the active portion of the landfill during peak discharge from at least a 14 25-year storm. It also requires that the runoff management system be designed to collect and control at 15 least the water volume resulting from a 24-hour, 25-year storm. 16 The primary purpose of the proposed stormwater facilities is to prevent stormwater runoff from areas 17 adjacent to the two Phase I cells from entering the cells during Phase I operation. This will be done by 18 collecting, conveying, and safely discharging stormwater from areas outside of the two Phase I cells that 19 would otherwise run into these cells. 20 The Department of Ecology has issued State Waste Discharge Permit Number ST 4510 for industrial 21 stormwater discharges to the ground through engineered land disposal structures on the Hanford site (ST 22 4510, Ecology, 1999; DOE/RL97-67 Revision 3, January 2000). Since the design for this project does 23 include facilities for collecting stormwater runoff and discharging it to the ground, the permit was 24 reviewed to determine whether it applied to these stormwater discharges. To be covered by this permit, 25 the stormwater must be considered an industrial discharge that is collected in an engineered structure and 26 is then discharged to the ground through an engineered structure. A stormwater discharge is an industrial 27 discharge if the stormwater has the potential to come into contact with an industrial activity or is collected 28 within an area of industrial activity. The purpose of the stormwater facilities that have been designed for 29 this project is to prevent the stormwater from areas outside of the Phase I landfill from entering the 30 landfill area. Therefore, the stormwater collected by these facilities would probably not be considered 31 industrial stormwater. To be an engineered structure for the collection of stormwater, the structure has to 32 be an impervious surface that is directly associated with industrial activities. The stormwater collection 33 facilities designed for this project do not have impervious surfaces. Therefore, permit ST 4510 does not 34 apply to the stormwater system designed for this project. 35 Stormwater facilities were designed only for the operation stage of Phase I and not for interim or final 36 closure conditions. Therefore, no stormwater facilities have been designed for stormwater runoff from 37 the Phase I cells after construction of their interim closure or final closure. Stormwater needs for the 38 construction, operation, and closure of future phases were not considered. 39 No stormwater collection and conveyance facilities were analyzed and/or designed for any of the roads 40 and support facilities that will be constructed as part of this project. The roads will be gravel surfaced, 41 and stormwater that does run off the roads into adjacent areas will infiltrate. The stormwater from the 42 roofs of the buildings will be caught in gutters and discharged to the ground surface via down spouts. 43 The stormwater that falls on the leachate tanks will evaporate off the floating covers. 44 5.10.1 Existing Conditions 45 Under existing conditions, the area around the Phase I site slopes down gently from south to north at an 46 average grade of approximately 0.5 percent. Appendix 4A.1.65

--- Page 151 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility I The only area that may generate stormwater that can run into the Phase I excavation is the area that 2 extends south from the excavation area to the crest of the sand dunes, located north of 1st Street (see 3 drainage areas figure in Appendix C.9). This drainage area is moderately vegetated, primarily with large 4 sage brush and grasses. The soils are generally sandy, with relatively high rates of infiltration. This area 5 typically receives little precipitation. There is little to no runoff, and stormwater normally either 6 infiltrates or is used by the vegetation. No existing drainage channels are apparent. The groundwater 7 table is approximately 300 feet below the ground surface. 8 5.10.2 Proposed Stormwater Facilities 9 To prevent stormwater from the area south of the Phase I excavation from running overland into the 10 excavation, a combination stormwater berm/ditch will be constructed south of the top of the south slope 11 of the excavation. The south end of the excavation will be approximately 1,400 feet long, and the ground 12 will be essentially flat. The berm/ditch will have a center high point and then slope down to the east and 13 to the west (two discharge points). A berm will be constructed immediately south of the ditch. At the 14 centerline of the excavation, the invert of the ditch will be at the existing ground surface, and the berm 15 will form the south slope of the ditch. The ditch will be excavated, with a longitudinal slope of 16 0.5 percent to both the east and the west. This will be done in order to minimize the depth of the ditch at 17 its east and west ends. Culverts will be installed at the east and west ditch ends to convey the flow under 18 the access roads. The culverts will discharge into the east and west infiltration areas. 19 The base map does not show any areas where stormwater runoff from offsite areas may flow into the east 20 or west boundaries of the Phase I excavation. However, if any offsite stormwater should flow toward 21 these boundaries, the fill for the berm access road and the shine berm will prevent the stormwater from 22 flowing into the excavation (see drainage areas figure in Appendix C.9). The intercepted stormwater will 23 flow south along the toe of the fill and either infiltrate or flow overland to the north, away from the site at 24 the north end of the berm access road. 25 The ground slopes away from the north end of the Phase I site, so there will be no offsite stormwater 26 running toward the north Phase I boundary. 27 The Phase I liner will end north of the toe of the south slope of the Phase I excavation. In order to reduce 28 potential leachate flows, a stormwater berm/ditch will be constructed just south of the south end of the 29 liner. This berm/ditch will intercept and convey stormwater runoff from the unlined south slope and the 30 unlined southern ends of the east and west slopes. The berm/ditch will be sloped to drain to the east. A 31 stormwater pipe will convey the stormwater under the landing for the access ramp and will discharge to 32 the excavation infiltration area. If this pipe ran straight from the ditch to the infiltration area, it would not 33 have adequate cover. Therefore, a catch basin with a solid cover will be installed near the west end of the 34 stormwater pipe. The invert of the pipe out of the catch basin will be lower than that of the pipe running 35 into this catch basin. The stormwater pipe that will run from the catch basin to the excavation infiltration 36 area will then have adequate cover. The excavation infiltration area will be excavated in the southeast 37 corner of the excavation. 38 The south edge of the access ramp into the Phase I excavation and the south edge of the "flat" area at the 39 bottom of the access ramp will serve as ditches. The access ramp will have a cross-slope of 2 percent 40 down to the south. The "flat" area at the bottom of the access ramp will have a slope down to the south 41 that varies between I and 3 percent. Adjacent to each of these will be the south slope of the excavation. 42 Construction of a full V-shaped ditch along the south side of the access ramp and the "flat" area was 43 considered. This idea was rejected because it would result in a larger excavation with the top of the Phase 44 I south slope moved further south. 45 The stormwater facilities are shown on the Phase I Grading and Drainage Plan drawing 46 (Drawing H-2-830830). 47 Stormwater runoff from the north, east, and west lined slopes of Phase I will run into the bottom lined 48 area and will become leachate.
