WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 7.2 Operational Interfaces 2 Operations and maintenance procedures will be prepared in the future as a separate project. These 3 procedures will address operations, monitoring, and maintenance activities for the IDF. 4 This section of the Design Report presents important operational interfaces that have been identified by 5 the design team. These interfaces should be considered during preparation of the operation and 6 maintenance procedures. The interfaces are grouped by three categories-landfill excavation, liner system, 7 and leachate handling system. 8 7.2.1 IDF Landfill Excavation and Related Subsystems 9 Operational interfaces for the landfill excavation and related subsystems include the following: 10 * Due to the containerized nature of the waste, the landfill is designed to be filled in a bottom-up 11 fashion in four or more layers. The number of layers will depend on waste package size. Some 12 waste packages may be larger in dimension than the ILAW packages. Operational procedures 13 should be developed to accommodate various package sizes and their placement. 14 * Clean fill placement between waste packages must be done to minimize the potential for future 15 consolidation and potential subsidence. 16 * Operations layer on side slopes of IDF will be monitored for material loss due to wind and water 17 erosion. Lost material should be replaced. Annual application of spray-on type soil stabilization 18 material to exposed areas of Phase I IDF should be considered. 19 * Shine berms should be monitored for erosion and height and should be repaired as necessary. 20 Erosion control matting on the berm will be maintained and repaired or replaced if damage 21 occurs. 22 * Stormwater control facilities should be maintained annually. Maintenance would include debris 23 removal from the ditches and application of weed control. Periodically, if capacity of infiltration 24 areas is diminished due to collection of fines, fines removal will be necessary. To maintain 25 infiltration capacity, no other vehicle access should be allowed into these areas. 26 * Stormwater accumulation in the in-cell excavation infiltration area should be visually monitored. 27 Pumping of the area may be necessary if accumulation becomes significant (near liner levels) in 28 wet weather seasons. Periodically, if capacity of infiltration areas is diminished due to collection 29 of fines, fines removal will be necessary. To maintain infiltration capacity, no other vehicle 30 access should be allowed into these areas. 31 * Due to the heavy wheel loads on the access roads and ramps, gravel surfacing will be maintained 32 with regular maintenance. Maintenance activities may include addition of more top course 33 material, and grading and compaction of this material. 34 * Active faces of stockpiles will require periodic application of spray-on soil stabilization material. 35 7.2.2 IDF Liner System 36 Operational interfaces for the lining system include the following: 37 * Only equipment with ground pressures less than 4,400 lb/ft should be used for construction and 38 maintenance on the side slopes, when operating directly on the operations layer. Bulldozers or 39 other equipment may operate on the side slopes until a rain event in excess of 0.15 inches per 40 hour occurs. In that event, equipment should be kept off the side slope (directly on the operations 41 layer) and should not be permitted to operate on slopes until two hours after the end of the rainfall 42 event. The precipitation event applies to both the lined slopes and the unlined slopes at the 43 southern end of the Phase I cell. 44 * For equipment on ramps, equipment should be kept a minimum of 2 feet away from the edge of 45 ramps, to avoid localized sloughing of the ramp edges. Appendix 4A.1.112

--- Page 198 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 * When operating equipment or placing waste on the operations layer above the lining system, care 2 should be taken to avoid damaging the liner. Special care will be necessary for equipment 3 operation on the side slopes. 4 * Any loads placed on the surface of the first operations layer must be examined to verify that they 5 do not create loads on the lining system in excess of the allowable GCL bearing capacity. As an 6 example, different types of waste other than canisters should be examined as the waste plan is 7 more fully developed. Care should also be taken to avoid impact loading, such as dropping a 8 canister. 9 * For static loading (such as for a barrier wall), refer to the discussion in Section 5.2 and 10 Appendix C.2. 11 * For operational/equipment loading, refer to the discussion in Section 5.5.5 and Appendix C.5.e to 12 determine applicable load limits and crane dunnage requirements. 13 The waste plan, as it is developed, should be followed for placement and density requirements. Any 14 revisions to the proposed waste filling plan (discussed in Section 7.1) should be reviewed by the design 15 engineer, to evaluate impacts on the waste/fill global stability analyses (Section 5.1.3 and 16 Appendix C. 1.c). 17 As part of the waste/fill global stability analyses, the waste mass was considered internally stable for this 18 design effort. Internal waste mass stability is a function of the waste filling approach. There are 19 numerous options available to stabilize the waste through operational methodologies, such as providing a 20 greater soil buttress on the open 3:1 south slope. During subsequent design phases, the internal stability 21 of the waste should be evaluated in conjunction with the waste filling plan. 22 7.2.3 IDF Leachate Handling System 23 Operational interfaces for the leachate handling system include the following: 24 * Coordinate with Liquid Effluent Retention Facility (LERF) for leachate hauling and removal of 25 leachate from tanks to satisfy the 90-day accumulation period (Treatment capacities at LERF and 26 leachate flows for critical periods should also be coordinated. See Section 5.9.2.4 for additional 27 leachate hauling constraints.) 28 * Use leak detection history for leachate storage tanks, during the operation of IDF, to manage and 29 plan for replacement of tank liner system and temporary storage required during its replacement. 30 * Periodic preventative inspection and maintenance for all rotating equipment should be scheduled. 31 * For leachate tanks floating covers, rain or snow will need to be pumped off with the 32 manufacturer-included sump pump (mounted on side of tank). Water should not be allowed to 33 accumulate except at the perimeter of the floating cover. Excessive water may prevent vent 34 operation and cause mixing between precipitation water and leachate on top of the cover. 35 * An adequate store of critical spare electrical and mechanical parts should be maintained. 36 * All valves should be exercised at least annually. 37 * A small "contractor-type" trash pump with hose should be kept on hand that can be used to pump 38 from the leak detection chamber within the combined sump to its inner sump. 39 * Periodically, test operation of the combined sump pump should be done. 40 * Annual testing of all leachate pumps for proper operation should be scheduled. 41 * Regular verification of level transducer calibration in cells should be done. 42 * Prior to winter months, proper operation of all heat tracing system should be checked. 43 * Periodic testing of all control relays, switches and contacts should be scheduled. 44 * Additional operational interface items will be developed, based on completion of design of the 45 control system for the leachate handling system. This will be part of the IDF administration 46 building design. Appendix 4A.1.113

--- Page 199 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility * Maintenance should be provided in accordance with manufacturer's recommendations. 2 7.3 Leakage Response Action Plan 3 WAC 173-303-665(9) regulations require the owner of the operator of a landfill unit to have an approved 4 Response Action Plan (RAP) before receipt of waste. The RAP is a site-specific plan that establishes 5 actions to be taken if leakage through the upper (primary) lining system of a landfill exceeds a certain 6 rate. The intent of the RAP is to assure that any leachate that leaks through the primary lining system will 7 not migrate out of the landfill into the environment. 8 A key element of the RAP is the ALR, a threshold value which triggers the responses described in the 9 RAP, but below which no special actions are required. Because landfill liner systems have not yet been 10 perfected, a small amount of leakage through the primary liner generally occurs, despite the use of best 11 available materials, construction techniques, and QA procedures. (This leakage is collected by the LDS 12 system and removed from the landfill.) Hence, the ALR is set at some level higher than normally 13 expected leakage rates to serve as an indicator that the primary lining system is not functioning as 14 expected. Exceeding the ALR may reflect serious failure of the primary lining system and indicates the 15 need for investigation and possibly corrective action while the problem is still manageable. 16 This RAP has been prepared in accordance with requirements of WAC 173-303-665(9). The 17 requirements for determining the ALR are contained in WAC 173-303-665(8) and EPA guidance 18 document, Action Leakage Rates for Leak Detection Systems (EPA 1992a). 19 The following sections establish the ALR and discuss response actions to be taken if the ALR is 20 exceeded. 21 7.3.1 Action Leakage Rate 22 Section 5.11 provides a detailed discussion of the analysis to determine the ALR into the LDS for the 23 IDF. Based on this analyses, the ALR for each IDF cell is 206 gallons per acre per day, or approximately 24 1,800 gallons per day per cell (each cell area is approximately 8.5 acres). This value includes a factor of 25 safety of 2 in accordance with EPA guidelines (EPA 1992b). It is also much lower than the LDS pump 26 capacity. Details of the calculation are presented in Appendix C. 10. 27 In accordance with WAC 173-303-665(8)(b), the flow rate used to determine if the ALR has been 28 exceeded will be calculated as the average daily flow rate into the sump, expressed as gallons per acre per 29 day (unless Ecology approves a different calculation). This calculation will be performed on a weekly 30 basis during the active (operational) life of the landfill, and monthly after the landfill has been closed. 31 Post-closure frequency may be reduced if only minimal amounts of leachate accumulate in the LDS 32 sump. As outlined in WAC 173-303-665(4)(c)(ii), during post-closure monitoring, if the liquid level in 33 the LDS sump stays below the pump operating level for two consecutive months, monitoring of the 34 amount of liquid in the LDS sumps can be reduced to at least quarterly. If the liquid level in the LDS 35 sump stays below the pump operating level for two consecutive quarters, monitoring of the amount of 36 liquid in the LDS sumps can be reduced to at least semiannually. Pump operating level is defined as a 37 liquid level approved by Ecology, based on pump activation level, sump dimensions, and level that 38 minimizes head in the sump. 39 7.3.2 Response Actions 40 WAC 173-303-665(9) lists several required actions if the ALR is exceeded. In the event that the ALR is 41 exceeded, DOE will: 42 * Notify Ecology in writing of the exceedance within 7 days of the determination. 43 * Submit a preliminary written assessment to Ecology within 14 days of the determination, as to the 44 amount of liquids, likely sources of liquids, possible location, size, cause of any leaks, and short- 45 term actions taken and planned. 46 * Determine, to the extent practicable, the location, size , and cause of any leak. Appendix 4A.1. 114

--- Page 200 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 * Determine whether waste receipt should cease or be curtailed, whether any waste should be 2 removed from the unit for inspection, repairs, or controls, and whether or not the unit should be 3 closed. 4 * Determine any other short-term and longer-term actions to be taken to mitigate or stop any leaks. 5 Within 30 days after the notification that the ALR has been exceeded, submit to Ecology the results of the 6 analyses specified in bullets 3, 4, and 5 of this section, the results of actions taken, and actions planned. 7 Monthly thereafter, as long as the flow rate in the LDS exceeds the ALR, the owner or operator must 8 submit to the regional administrator a report summarizing the results of any remedial actions taken and 9 actions planned. 10 If the ALR is exceeded, the DOE will submit the required notifications to Ecology, as stated above. The 11 EPA will also receive copies of this confirmation. 12 The leachate will be analyzed for chemical compounds and radionuclides. If the analytical results 13 indicate that these constituents are present, and if the constituents can be traced to a particular type of 14 waste stored in a known area of the landfill, then it may be possible to estimate the location of the leak. 15 However, because the waste will meet land disposal restrictions, it will contain no free liquids and will be 16 stabilized or solidified. In addition, the canister(s) or other type of waste package(s) may not undergo 17 enough deterioration during the active life of the landfill to permit escape of its contents. For these 18 reasons, it is possible that the leachate may be clean or the composition too general to indicate a specific 19 source location. 20 If the source location cannot be identified, large-scale removal of the waste and operations layer to find 21 and repair the leaking area of the liner would be one option for remediation. However, this procedure 22 risks damaging the liner. In addition, waste would have to be handled, stored, and replaced in the landfill. 23 Backfill would need to be removed from around the waste packages to accomplish this. If the waste 24 packages are damaged during this process, the risk of accidental release may be high. For these reasons, 25 large scale removal of waste and liner system materials is not considered a desirable option and will not 26 be implemented except as a last resort. 27 The preferred options for remediation include covers and changes in landfill operating procedures. The 28 preferred alternative will depend on factors such as the amount of waste already in the landfill, the rate of 29 waste receipt, the chemistry of the leachate, the availability of other RCRA-compliant disposal facilities, 30 and similar considerations. Hence, at this time no single approach can be selected. If the ALR is 31 exceeded, potential options will be evaluated prior to selecting a remediation process. If necessary, an 32 interim solution will be implemented while the evaluation and permanent remediation is performed. 33 Examples of potential approaches include the following: 34 * The surface of the intermediate soil cover over the waste could be graded to direct runoff into a 35 shallow pond. The surface would then be covered with a discardable, temporary geomembrane 36 (e.g., 30-mil PVC or reinforced polypropylene). Precipitation water would be pumped or 37 evaporated from the pond and would not infiltrate the waste already in the landfill. Waste 38 packages would be placed only during periods of dry weather and stored temporarily at other 39 times. This type of approach would also be used, if necessary, to reduce leakage during the time 40 immediately after the ALR was exceeded, while other remediation options were being evaluated. 41 * If the landfill was nearly full, partial construction of the final closure cover might be an option. 42 This would reduce infiltration into the landfill and possibly the leakage rate, if the cover were 43 constructed over the failed area. 44 * A layer of low-permeability soil could be placed over the existing waste, perhaps in conjunction 45 with a geomembrane, to create a second "primary" liner higher in the landfill. This new liner 46 would intercept precipitation and allow its removal. Appendix 4A.1.115

--- Page 201 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility * A rigid-frame or air-supported structure could be constructed over the landfill to ensure that no 2 infiltration occurred. Although costly, this approach might be less expensive than constructing a 3 new landfill. 4 In general, the selected remediation efforts would be those that are easiest to implement, with more 5 difficult or expensive options to be applied only if earlier approaches were not satisfactory. 6 8.0 REFERENCES 7 40 CFR 264. WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility I SECTION 1 GENERAL 2 1.1 Introduction 3 This Construction Quality Assurance (CQA) Plan describes the quality assurance (QA) activities for 4 constructing Phase I of the Integrated Disposal Facility (IDF) at the Hanford facility in Richland, 5 Washington. 6 1.1.1 Applicable Units 7 QA activities will be required during construction of Cell I of Phase I to certify that the following 8 construction activities are performed in accordance with the construction documents: 9 * Construction/preparation of foundation systems for liners. 10 * Construction of dikes or embankments. 11 * Construction of low-permeability soil liners. 12 * Construction of geomembranes. 13 * Construction of leachate collection and removal systems and leak detection systems. 14 This CQA Plan has been prepared to describe the activities that will be performed during construction of 15 the lining system, leachate collection and leak detection systems, and operation layer of Cell 1. This 16 CQA Plan is intended to satisfy the regulatory requirements and guidance established in 40 CFR 264.19, 17 the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) technical guidance document, Quality Assurance and 18 Quality Control for Waste Containment Facilities (EPA 1993), and Washington Administrative Code 19 (WAC) 173-303-335. 20 This CQA Plan will be implemented by a CQA Officer (herein referred to as the CQA certifying 21 engineer), a person familiar with EPA's technical guidance document, Quality Assurance and Quality 22 Control for Waste Containment Facilities and this CQA Plan. The CQA certifying engineer will be 23 supported by the number of CQA representatives necessary to implement the requirements in this CQA 24 Plan and to document the work. 25 1.1.2 Scope 26 This CQA Plan establishes general administrative and documentation procedures that will be applicable 27 for selected activities of construction. With respect to responsibilities, personnel qualifications, and 28 specific inspection and testing activities, this CQA Plan addresses only those activities associated with the 29 soils, geosynthetics, and related liner and leachate collection system piping components for the IDF. 30 The CQA requirements are divided into the following sections to provide quick access to CQA 31 requirements for individual liner components: * Soils CQA * Composite Drainage Net CQA * Geosynthetic Clay Liner CQA * Polyethylene Pipe and Fittings CQA * Geomembrane CQA * CQA Documentation and Certification * Geotextile CQA * CQA Documentation and Certification 32 1.2 Project Organization 33 This section describes the anticipated project organization for the IDF construction activities. The 34 following subsections address the organizations involved in the construction, their respective roles in 35 construction activities, and the methods of interactions between organizations. 36 1.2.1 Responsibility and Authority 37 The organization chart for the IDF construction is shown in Figure 1-1. These personnel will be 38 associated with two main entities that include the Tank Farm operating contractor and his agents and the 39 construction general contractor and his personnel and/or subcontractors. The CQA certifying engineer is a registered professional engineer in 26 Washington and has the authority to provide a certification letter that the IDF is constructed in accordance 27 with the approved CQA Plan, the approved plans and specifications, and any approved changes. The 28 CQA certifying engineer also has the authority and responsibility to stop work and recommend remedial 29 actions to the IDF PM. 30 1.2.1.9 Field Inspector 31 Field inspectors are employees or agents of the Tank Farm operating contractor and report to the CQA 32 certifying engineer. Specific duties of the 25 construction QC engineer include activities such as preparing construction submittals, field 26 documentation, and interfacing with the CQA certifying engineer. 27 1.2.2 Project Meetings 28 The various progress and status meetings that are anticipated to be held throughout the IDF construction 29 are described below. The purpose of the meetings is to discuss work progress, planning, and other issues 30 related to construction. A portion of these meetings can be dedicated to CQA issues, as necessary, to 31 provide an opportunity for the CQA team to express concerns regarding quality, relay test results, and 32 ensure good communication between all organizations involved in the construction of the IDF. 33 1.2.2.1 Pre-Construction Meeting 34 A pre-construction meeting will be scheduled prior to beginning construction activities for the IDF. At a 35 minimum, the meeting will be attended by IDF staff including the PM, CM, project engineer, design 36 engineer, as well as the construction general contractor site supervisor, and the CQA certifying engineer. 37 A portion of the meeting will be dedicated to the discussion of QA issues. Suggested CQA topics will 38 include, but not be limited to: 39 * Reviewing the responsibilities of each organization. 40 * Discussing the authority of agencies and project and field team members to order work stoppages. 41 * Reviewing lines of authority and communication for each organization. 42 * Providing each organization with all relevant CQA documents and supporting information. 43 * Familiarizing each organization with the CQA Plan and its role, relative to the design criteria, 44 plans, and specifications. WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility I * Discussing the established procedures or protocol for observations and tests, including sampling 2 strategies. 3 * Discussing the established procedures or protocol for handling construction deficiencies, repairs, 4 and re-testing, including "stop work" conditions. 5 * Reviewing methods for documenting and reporting inspection data. 6 * Reviewing methods for distributing and storing documents and reports. 7 * Reviewing work area security and safety protocol. 8 * Reviewing the proposed project schedule. 9 * Discussing procedures for the location and protection of construction materials and for the 10 prevention of damage of the materials from inclement weather or other adverse events. 11 * Determining action items, assigning actionees, and recording minutes to be transmitted to 12 meeting attendees. 13 * Discussing document control requirements and control of CQA records. 14 * Discussing control and protection of samples. 15 1.2.2.2 Daily Pre-Job Briefing 16 The construction general contractor will conduct daily pre-job briefings at the work area. The primary purpose of these meetings will be to address the day's planned activities. 19 The CQA monitor will discuss CQA activities planned for that day and interface needs with the 20 construction personnel. Suggested CQA topics are: 21 * Review the work location and activities for the day. 22 * Discuss the construction general contractor's personnel and equipment assignments for the day. 23 * Address scheduling of resources for upcoming work. 24 * Review any new test data. 25 * Discuss any potential construction problems, including unexpected subsurface conditions. 26 * Discuss CQA-planned activities and interface needs. 27 This meeting will be documented and the documentation will be retained on file by the CQA monitor. 28 1.2.2.3 Construction Progress Meetings 29 Weekly progress meetings will be held at the site to discuss construction progress. At a minimum, the 30 weekly progress meetings will be attended by the IDF PM, CM, the site supervisor, and the CQA 31 certifying engineer or CQA monitor. The purposes of the meeting are to: 32 * Review previous activities and accomplishments. 33 * Review claims, change orders, delays, and similar items. 34 * Review planned activities for the upcoming 2-week period. 35 * Finalize resolution of problems from previous meetings. 36 * Discuss potential problems with the work planned for the upcoming 2-week period. 37 Minutes will be recorded and transmitted to meeting attendees and other interested parties. 38 1.2.2.4 Non-Conformance Meetings 39 Meetings will be convened as necessary to address non-conformances discovered during inspection. 40 Deficiencies observed during construction by the CQA representatives will be brought to the attention of 41 the IDF CM and CQA certifying engineer and documented using the non-conformance reporting (NCR) 42 procedures outlined in Section 8.1.4. 43 Appendix 4B.14

All documentation 28 relating to qualifications will be maintained with the project CQA records. 29 1.3.1 CQA Certifying Engineer 30 The CQA certifying engineer will have landfill construction certification experience. The CQA certifying 31 engineer will, at a minimum, be a registered civil professional engineer in good standing in the State of 32 Washington, possess a bachelor's degree in civil or construction engineering, geotechnical engineering, 33 engineering geology, or a closely related discipline, and have sufficient practical, technical, and 34 managerial experience to direct successfully the CQA activities discussed in this CQA Plan. The CQA 35 certifying engineer's qualifications will be documented by training records and a professional resume 36 showing significant field experience in landfill construction and low permeability soil-bentonite admix 37 liner construction, having directed CQA activities at a minimum of three landfill construction projects or 38 a minimum of 100 acres of combined landfill area certifying experience. The CQA certifying engineer 39 will be familiar with the EPA technical guidance document, Quality Assurance and Quality Control for 40 Waste Containment Facilities (EPA 1993). Qualification documentation will be reviewed by the IDF PM 41 and IDF project engineer. 42 1.3.2 CQA Monitor 43 Appendix 4B.15

Appendix 4B.16

--- Page 268 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 1.4.2 Use of the Terms in This Plan 2 The definitions used in the context of this CQA Plan are as follows: 3 * CQA refers to means and actions employed by the CQA representatives to assure conformity of 4 liner system, LCRS, LDS, SLDS, and pipe preparation, production, and installation with this 5 CQA Plan, the technical specifications, and the construction drawings. CQA will be provided by 6 a third party, acting independently from the product manufacturer and construction general 7 contractor. 8 * CQC refers to those actions taken by manufacturers, suppliers, or construction general contractor, 9 including their designated representatives, to ensure that the materials and the workmanship meet 10 the requirements of the technical specifications and the construction drawings. 11 1.5 References 12 1.5.1 Applicable Organizations 13 Organizations whose standards are referenced in the CQA Plan include: 14 * ASTM-American Society for Testing and Materials 15 * DOE-Department of Energy 16 * GRI-Geosynthetic Research Institute 17 * OSHA-Occupational Safety and Health Administration 18 * EPA-U.S. Environmental Protection Agency 19 1.5.2 Applicable Standards 20 Any reference to standards of any society, institute, association, or governmental agency will pertain to 21 the edition in effect as of the date of this CQA Plan, unless stated otherwise. 22 Specific test standards for tests cited in the CQA Plan are provided in the technical specifications. These 23 standards may be modified due to technological advances since compilation of the technical 24 specifications. All such modifications are to be approved in accordance with change order procedures 25 described in Section 8.1.5. 26 1.6 Construction Activities and Submittal Requirements 27 1.6.1 Construction Activities 28 This section describes the construction activities and submittal requirements that will be performed by the 29 construction general contractor during the IDF construction. This CQA Plan only addresses selected 30 activities of the Phase I construction. 31 In general, construction activities will consist of preparing the subgrade, installing the liner system, the 32 leak detection systems (LDS and SLDS), the leachate collection and removal system (LCRS), and 33 operations layer and necessary equipment to complete the landfill for waste acceptance. Construction 34 will consist of these activities: 35 * Mobilizing construction equipment and personnel. 36 * Vendor data submittals. 37 * Installing sediment and erosion control. 38 * Preparing soil bentonite material. 39 * Excavation, embankment, fine grading of landfill subgrade, and sump construction. 40 * Constructing the secondary leak detection system (SLDS) sump. 41 * Constructing the soil bentonite admix liner (SBL). 42 * Dust control activities during construction. Appendix 4B.17

--- Page 269 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 * Placing the geosynthetics for the secondary liner. 2 * Constructing the leak detection system (LDS). 3 * Placing the geosynthetics for the primary liner. 4 * Constructing the leachate collection and removal system. 5 0 Constructing the operations layer. 6 * Site restoration. 7 * Demobilization. 8 Prior to the start of construction activities, the CQA representatives will review and become familiar with 9 all construction drawings, technical specifications, the CQA Plan, and RCRA permit. The CQA 10 certifying engineer also will be familiar with the most recent construction schedule, so that adequate 11 resources (i.e., laboratory, field testing equipment, staff, and CQA forms), including contingencies 12 (e.g., backup equipment, alternate laboratory, and alternate CQA staff) for CQA activities, will be 13 commensurate with the anticipated construction productivity and work schedule. 14 1.6.2 Submittal Requirements 15 The construction general contractor will provide the submittals required (listed in Table 1-1 in this 16 section) to the IDF PM. Submittals will be provided far enough in advance of scheduled installation dates 17 to allow time for reviews, possible revisions and resubmittals, placing orders, and securing delivery. The 18 construction general contractor will identify, track, and disposition all required vendor data. The CQA monitor will monitor the fill placement and compaction to verify and 12 document the following: 13 * The soil being placed meets the technical specifications requirements for earth fill and structural 14 fill as determined by the test methods and frequencies specified within this CQA Plan and the 15 source quality control submittals. 16 * The placement surface has been prepared as specified in the technical specifications. 17 * The compacted lift thickness is in accordance with the requirements of the technical 18 specifications. 19 * The dry unit weight of the earth fill and structural fill meets specifications as determined by the 20 test methods and frequencies described in Table 2-1 for earth fill and Table 2-2 for structural fill. 21 * Material placed in permanent stockpiles meets the appropriate specifications for earth fill or 22 structural fill. 23 2.1.2 Construction Quality Assurance Evaluation 24 The frequency of soils testing for CQA purposes will conform to the minimum frequencies presented in 25 Table 2-1 for earth fill and Table 2-2 for structural fill. Material properties will be determined from 26 samples collected either immediately after placement or from stockpiles. Appendix 4B.22

--- Page 274 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 Nuclear density meter test methods will be used for the field-testing of the in situ dry unit weight of the 2 in-place, compacted fill. Any settlement or other defects in the fill will be backfilled and compacted in 3 accordance with the technical specifications. 4 Standard count calibrations will be conducted to monitor the aging of the nuclear density gauge sources in 5 accordance with ASTM standards. Sand cone or drive sleeve tests will be conducted periodically to 6 verify densities using the nuclear density gauge. Oven moisture content tests will be conducted and 7 compared to field moisture content results to determine a field correction factor for moisture. Sand cone 8 or drive sleeve tests and in situ moisture content tests will be performed at the frequencies specified in 9 Tables 2-1 and 2-2. 10 If an in-place density test result fails to meet specifications, a confirmatory test will be performed 11 immediately adjacent to the failed test. If the confirmatory test meets or exceeds specifications, a second 12 confirmatory test will be performed at a second location immediately next to the failed test. If the second 13 confirmatory test also meets or exceeds specifications, the area will be declared as meeting project 14 specifications and the confirmatory tests will be reported. In the event that either confirmatory test fails 15 to meet specifications, a CQA representative will determine the extent and nature of the defect by 16 observations and/or additional testing, as necessary, to identify the limits of the area that does not meet 17 project specifications. 18 If a defective area is discovered in the fill, a CQA representative will determine the extent and nature of 19 the defect. If the defect is indicated by an unsatisfactory test result, the CQA representative will 20 determine the extent of the defective area by additional tests, observations, a review of records, or other 21 means that the CQA representative deems appropriate. If the defect is related to adverse site conditions, 22 such as excessively wet soils or surface desiccation, the CQA representative will define the limits and 23 nature of the defect by testing or observation. After the extent and nature of a defect is determined and 24 remedied by the construction general contractor, the CQA representative will verify that the deficiency 25 has been corrected by re-testing repaired areas before any additional work is performed by the 26 construction general contractor in the area of the deficiency. All confirmatory tests, failing tests, and re- 27 tests will be recorded in the CQA representative's field book or compaction testing form. The 28 approximate location and elevation of each test will be recorded. 29 The CQA representative will document fill placement and compaction as determined by the test methods 30 and frequency prescribed by this CQA Plan and will report any non-conformance in accordance with the 31 non-conformance reporting procedures outlined in Section 8.1.4. 32 2.2 Prepared Subgrade 33 The CQA representative will verify and document that the prepared subgrade is constructed to the 34 elevations and grades shown in the construction drawings, with subgrade meeting the requirements of the 35 technical specifications as determined by the test methods and frequencies specified within this CQA 36 Plan. 37 Upon completion of the excavation of the landfill, the CQA monitor will perform the following tasks: 38 * Inspect the subgrade on the side slopes and base of the landfill and note areas of weak or 39 excessively weathered subgrade materials. 40 * Observe completion of excavation and subgrade compaction prior to foundation, fill, or liner 41 placement. 42 * Observe the proof rolling of the base of the landfill and note areas that exhibit excessive rutting, 43 heaving, or softening. 44 * Observe that the surface of the subgrade is free of debris, wet and soft areas, standing water, 45 vegetation, mud, ice, or frozen material. 46 * Observe any excavation and backfilling operations associated with unsuitable material found in 47 the prepared subgrade. The CQA certifying engineer will provide a certificate of layer completion to the 15 construction general contractor and the IDF project engineer, certifying that the area is complete. 16 2.3 Soil Bentonite Admix Liner and Test Pads 17 The soil bentonite admix liner (SBL) is composed of a mixture of base soil and bentonite material. Two 18 SBL test pads will include both a horizontal and a sloped test pad. The horizontal test pad will be 19 constructed by using the same compaction methods as that used for the production SBL, to ensure the 20 SBL is constructed to meet the minimum hydraulic conductivity requirements. The sloped test pad will 21 be constructed on a sloping surface to verify that compaction methods (determined during the horizontal 22 test pad) will be adequate for the side slopes of the landfill. If necessary, the technical specifications 23 and/or CQA Plan may be modified, based on the results of the test pads. 24 2.3.1 Test Pads 25 Test pads will be constructed by the construction general contractor to determine acceptable placement 26 and compaction methods to produce a low permeable SBL on a horizontal surface and on a 3H:IV side 27 slope that satisfies the performance requirements of the technical specifications. 28 In addition, the mixing of the base soil and bentonite admixture using the pugmill will be tested to ensure 29 adequate control of the ratio of admixture components as well as the homogeneity of the completed SBL 30 mixture. 31 2.3.1.1 Construction Quality Assurance Evaluation 32 During test pad construction, the CQA representative will continuously observe and document the 33 construction of the test pad. These guidelines will be followed to ensure that the test pad accurately 34 represents the performance of the full-scale facility: 35 * Construction of the test pad will use the same soil material, design specifications, equipment, and 36 procedures as proposed for the full-scale facility. 37 * The test pad length, width, and depth will be as required by the technical specifications and for 38 the in-situ hydraulic conductivity test spacing. 39 * The number of lifts used to construct the test pad will be as required by the technical 40 specifications. 41 The test pad will be constructed to allow determination of the relationship among density, moisture 42 content, and method of compaction. Field variables can affect this relationship and must be carefully 43 measured and controlled, both in the test pad and during construction of the full-scale liner. At a 44 minimum, the following will be observed and documented: Appendix 4B.24

--- Page 276 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 * Track weight of base soil and bentonite during mixing operations. 2 * Mixing operation homogeneity. 3 * Test pad configuration and dimensions. 4 * Compaction equipment type, configuration, and weight. 5 * Number of passes and speed of the compaction equipment. 6 * Uncompacted and compacted lift thickness. 7 * Weather conditions, including ambient temperature, humidity, wind speed and direction, and 8 precipitation. 9 The CQA representative will provide the necessary surveying and/or reference grid points, for adequately 10 and expeditiously, determining the elevation and dimensions of the test pad, including each lift. 11 The CQA representative will be responsible for all testing, surveying, and documentation necessary to 12 verify that the test pad performs in accordance with the technical specifications, and that the methods, 13 equipment, and materials used can achieve the same results or better during full-scale construction. 14 Testing methods and frequencies will be as indicated in Table 2-4. Additional tests may be conducted at 15 the direction of the CQA certifying engineer. All tests will be conducted in accordance with the methods 16 and procedures specified in Table 2-4. Tests are separately identified in Table 2-4 which are intended to 17 provide the following: 18 * Information Only, for use in evaluating overall methods, materials, or equipment. 19 * Pass/Fail, which have criteria established in the technical specifications which must be met. 20 * Calibration and Check, for use in calibrating instruments. 21 The CQA certifying engineer will compare the results of the test pad constructed on the level surface with 22 the results of the test pad on the side slopes. The CQA certifying engineer will recommend changes to 23 compaction methods, if necessary, to the IDF project engineer. The CQA certifying engineer will prepare 24 an interim report, which summarizes the construction and testing of the test pads. 25 It is important to note that an acceptable zone has been established in the technical specifications for the 26 allowable moisture content and density ranges that are applicable for the SBL admix to meet minimum 27 permeability requirements. This zone may be adjusted as a result of the test pad data obtained during 28 construction to reflect specific conditions observed based on the construction general contractor's 29 proposed blending, placement, and compaction methods. With the range of placement moisture content 30 and density allowed with this approach, minimum compaction effort (i.e., the number of passes a piece of 31 compaction equipment needs to bring the admix into the allowable moisture/density zone) will vary based 32 on material conditions and placement location. Minimum compaction effort recommendations will be 33 developed by the CQA certifying engineer for application to both bottom slope and side-slope admix 34 construction based on test pad results. However, these minimums should be considered as guidelines 35 only and may need to be adjusted based on changes to admix properties (primarily moisture content), site 36 conditions, and compaction location as needed to bring the admix into the required acceptable zone for 37 compaction. 38 2.3.2 Soil Bentonite Admix Liner 39 The CQA team will verify and document that the SBL is placed to the elevations, grades, and thicknesses 40 shown in the construction drawings, with bentonite-amended material meeting the requirements of the 41 technical specifications as determined by the test methods and frequencies specified within this CQA 42 Plan. 43 2.3.2.1 Construction Quality Assurance Evaluation 44 CQA testing will be performed during processing and placement of the SBL. WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility I SECTION 3 GEOSYNTHETIC CLAY LINER CONSTRUCTION QUALITY ASSURANCE 2 3.1 Geosynthetic Clay Liner Manufacture and Delivery 3 3.1.1 Labeling 4 The CQA representative will verify and document that the GCL manufacturer has labeled each roll of 5 GCL and includes the information required by the technical specifications. The CQA representative will 6 examine GCL rolls upon delivery and deviation from the above requirements will be reported to the CQA 7 certifying engineer prior to installation of the GCL. 8 3.1.2 Transportation and Handling 9 The CQA representative will observe and document that the type of GCL handling equipment used by the 10 installer minimizes damage to the material. Upon delivery at the site, the CQA representative will 11 conduct a visual inspection of all rolls for defects and for damage. This examination will be conducted 12 without unrolling rolls unless visible defects or damages are found. The CQA representative will indicate 13 to the CQA certifying engineer: 14 * Any rolls that need to be unrolled to allow for their inspection. 15 * Any rolls, or portions thereof, that need to be rejected and removed from the site because they 16 have severe flaws. 17 * Any rolls that include minor repairable flaws. 18 3.1.3 Storage 19 The CQA representative will verify and document that storage of the GCL is in accordance with the 20 technical specifications. 21 3.1.4 Inventory 22 All geosynthetic materials that arrive onsite will be inventoried. The inventory will include the specific 23 roll numbers delivered with each shipment. The inventory will be compared to the QC testing 24 information, supplied by the manufacturer to ensure that the material tested is the same material that was 25 delivered to the site. Material for which QC testing data has been supplied will be sampled for 26 conformance testing. Conformance samples may be obtained by the CQA representative at the 27 manufacturing plant or taken upon delivery of the material to the site by a CQA representative. As 28 shipments arrive at the site, a CQA representative will monitor the unloading operations and will 29 inventory the material. Rolls selected for conformance testing will be set aside for sampling as soon as 30 possible. 31 The CQA representative will record the following information, at a minimum, for each roll: 32 * Manufacturer-Indicate the manufacturer of the material that is being inventoried, which may 33 not be the same as the installer. 34 * Date of Inventory-Date that the material was inventoried. 35 * Date of Delivery-Enter date when the truck arrived onsite, if known. 36 * Truck Type-Indicate type of truck used for shipping geosynthetics (covered or uncovered 37 flatbed, box trailer). 38 * Bill of Lading Number-If the bill-of-lading is available, indicate number and date (also attach 39 copy to inventory form). 40 * CQA Representative-Indicate name of CQA representative performing inventory. 41 * Unloading Equipment-Indicate the type and model number of the equipment unloading the 42 geosynthetic material; also note any special attachments that are used to unload the material 43 (stinger, straps, forks). The identification 10 method will be agreed upon by the CQA certifying engineer and the construction general contractor. This 11 field panel identification scheme will be as simple and logical as possible. (Note: manufacturing plant 12 roll numbers are usually cumbersome and are not related to location in the field.) It will be the 13 responsibility of the construction general contractor to ensure that each field panel placed is marked with 14 the manufacturing plant roll number. The roll number will be marked in the center of the panel in a color 15 to allow for easy inspection. 16 The CQA representative will establish a table or chart showing correspondence between manufacturing 17 plant roll numbers and field panel identification codes. The field panel identification code will be used 18 for all CQA records. 19 3.2.3.2 Field Panel Placement 20 Installation Schedule 21 The CQA representative will evaluate significant changes in the schedule, proposed by the construction 22 general contractor, and will advise the CQA certifying engineer on the acceptability of that change. WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 3.2.4 Defects and Repairs 2 Any defects and subsequent repairs will be documented, using NCR procedures outlined in Section 8.1.4. 3 3.2.4.1 Identification 4 All seams and non-seam areas of the GCL will be inspected by the CQA representative for evidence of 5 defects, holes, contamination of geotextiles, displaced panels, premature hydration, and any sign of 6 contamination by foreign matter. The CQA representative will observe and document repair procedures 7 described below. 8 3.2.4.2 Repair Procedures 9 Prior to cover material placement, damage to the GCL will be identified and repaired by the installer. 10 Rip and Tear Repair (Flat Surfaces) 11 Rips or tears may be repaired by completely exposing the affected area, removing all foreign objects or 12 soil, and by then placing a patch cut from unused GCL over the damage (damaged material may be left in 13 place), with a minimum overlap of 12 inches on all edges. 14 Accessory bentonite will be placed between the patch edges and the repaired material at a rate of a quarter 15 pound per lineal foot of edge, spread in a continuous 6-inch fillet. 16 Rip and Tear Repair (Slopes) 17 Damaged GCL material on slopes will be repaired by the same procedures as described above, however, 18 the overlapped edges of the patch need to be wide enough to ensure the patch will keep its position during 19 backfill or cover operations. 20 Displaced Panels 21 Displaced panels will be adjusted to the correct position and orientation. The adjusted panel will then be 22 inspected for any geotextile damage or bentonite loss. Damage will be repaired by the above-described 23 procedure. 24 Premature Hydration 25 If the GCL is subjected to premature hydration, the construction general contractor will notify the CQA 26 certifying engineer for a site-specific determination as to whether the material is acceptable or if 27 alternative measures must be taken to ensure the quality of the design dependent upon the degree of 28 damage. 29 Appendix 4B.40

WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 Nondestructive testing will not be permitted before sunrise or after sunset unless the construction general 2 contractor demonstrates to the CQA certifying engineer that the construction general contractor has the 3 capabilities to perform continuity testing under reduced light conditions. The purpose of these tests is to evaluate 20 seam strength and integrity. Seam strength testing will be done as the seaming work progresses, not at 21 the completion of all field seaming. 22 Location and Frequency 23 The CQA representative will select locations where seam samples will be cut out for laboratory testing at 24 the frequency specified in the technical specifications (see Section 02661). In general, destructive tests 25 will be located in non-critical areas, such as seam run-out areas or near three-panel intersections or other 26 areas that will require a patch anyway. In addition, because extrusion welding may be limited on a daily 27 basis, extrusion destructive samples may be welded after passing a trial seam on scrap material not used 28 for construction. However, when significant lengths (greater than 100 feet) of seams or caps are extrusion 29 welded, a destructive test of the weld will be taken. 30 Control charts will be used to track the performance of each welding machine and technician to allow for 31 biased sampling, according to performance. An upper control limit (UCL) will be established to identify 32 statistically the sources of test failures. Machines and technicians whose failure rates exceed the UCL 33 will then be identified and destructively tested at twice the original frequency (one per 250 feet of seam 34 length) to better monitor their performance. Once the failure rate drops back into compliance with the 35 UCL, the original testing frequency will be reinstated. Machines and technicians whose failure notes are 36 below the UCL will be identified to decrease the original frequency, as approved by the CQA certifying 37 engineer. 38 The UCL is established based on the failure rate for all destructive tests plus three standard deviations 39 with a ceiling of 3.5 percent. The ceiling is the maximum failure rate determined to be acceptable, as 40 agreed upon jointly by the construction general contractor and CQA certifying engineer. The initial UCL 41 will be calculated once a single machine or technician fails two destructive tests and will typically be 42 updated daily with the most recent destructive testing results. Destructive tests tracking a failed 43 destructive will not be included in the calculation of the failure rates. 44 45 Appendix 4B.46

--- Page 298 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility I Additional destructive test locations may be required during seaming operations. The necessity for such 2 additional sampling and testing will be determined by CQA representatives and will be implemented 3 when there is cause to suspect the presence of excess crystallinity, contamination, offset welds, or any 4 other reason to suspect potentially defective seams. The location selection of the additional testing will 5 be based on the CQA representative's judgment and observation of a suspected problem. 6 The construction general contractor will not be informed in advance of the locations where the seam 7 samples will be taken. 8 Sampling Procedure 9 The construction general contractor will be required to cut samples, as directed by the CQA representative 10 as the seaming progresses, in order to have laboratory test results before the geomembrane is covered by 11 another material. The continuity of the new seams in the 20 repaired area will be nondestructively tested, according to the technical specifications. 21 Size of Samples 22 At a given sampling location, two types of samples will be taken by the construction general contractor. 23 First, two specimens for field-testing will be taken. Each of these specimens will be 1 inch wide by 6 to 24 12 inches long, with the seam centered parallel to the width. The distance between these two specimens 25 will be approximately 42 inches. If both specimens pass the field test described in the technical 26 specifications, a sample for laboratory testing will be taken. 27 The sample for laboratory testing will be required to be taken between the two specimens for field-testing. 28 The destructive sample will be 12 inches wide by 42 inches long, with the seam centered lengthwise. The 29 sample will be cut into three parts and distributed as follows: 30 * One portion to the construction general contractor, 12 inches long. 31 * One portion to the IDF CM for archive storage, 12 inches long. 32 * One portion to the CQA certifying engineer for CQA Laboratory testing, 18 inches long. 33 Final determination of the sample sizes will be made at the preconstruction meeting. 34 Field Testing 35 The two 1-inch-wide specimens, as specified above, will be required to be tested in the field by the CQA 36 representative by tensiometer for peel and shear and need not to fail in the seam. If any field test sample 37 fails to pass, the procedures outlined in the technical specifications will be followed. 38 The CQA representative will mark all samples and portions with their number, date, and time. 39 Geosynthetic Construction Quality Assurance Laboratory Testing 40 Laboratory destructive test samples will be packaged and shipped to the Geosynthetics CQA Laboratory 41 by the CQA representative in a manner that will not damage the test sample. The CQA representative 42 will store the archive samples until the completion of the project. 43 Testing will include "Shear Strength" and "Peel Strength" (ASTM D6392) with 1-inch-wide strip, tested 44 at 2 inches per minute. The minimum acceptable values to be obtained in these tests are those indicated in 45 the technical specifications. At least five specimens will be tested for each test method. Appendix 4B.47

WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 4C. FACILITY RESPONSE ACTION PLAN 2 4C.1. Leakage Response Action Plan 3 WAC 173-303-665(9) regulations require the owner of the operator of a landfill unit to have an approved 4 Response Action Plan (RAP) before receipt of waste. The RAP is a site-specific plan that establishes 5 actions to be taken if leakage through the upper (primary) lining system of a landfill exceeds a certain 6 rate. The intent of the RAP is to assure that any leachate that leaks through the primary lining system will 7 not migrate out of the landfill into the environment. 8 A key element of the RAP is the Action Leakage Rate (ALR), a threshold value which triggers the 9 responses described in the RAP, but below which no special actions are required. Because landfill liner 10 systems have not yet been perfected, a small amount of leakage through the primary liner generally 11 occurs, despite the use of best available materials, construction techniques, and quality assurance 12 procedures. (This leakage is collected by the LDS system and removed from the landfill.) Hence, the 13 ALR is set at some level higher than normally expected leakage rates to serve as an indicator that the 14 primary lining system is not functioning as expected. Exceeding the ALR may reflect serious failure of 15 the primary lining system and indicates the need for investigation and possibly corrective action while the 16 problem is still manageable. 17 This RAP has been prepared in accordance with requirements of WAC 173-303-665(9). The 18 requirements for determining the ALR are contained in WAC 173-303-665(8) and the Environmental 19 Protection Agency (EPA) guidance document, Action Leakage Rates for Leak Detection Systems (EPA 20 530-R-92-004). 21 The following sections establish the ALR and discuss response actions to be taken if the ALR is 22 exceeded. 23 4C.1.1. Action Leakage Rate 24 Section 5.11 provides a detailed discussion of the analysis to determine the ALR into the LDS for the 25 Integrated Disposal Facility (IDF). Based on this analyses, the ALR for the IDF permitted cell is 26 206 gallons per acre per day, or approximately 1,800 gallons per day per cell (each cell area is 27 approximately 8.5 acres). This value includes a factor of safety of 2 in accordance with EPA guidelines 28 (57 FR 19). It is also much lower than the LDS pump capacity. Details of the calculation are presented 29 in Appendix C.10. 30 In accordance with WAC 173-303-665(8)(b), the flow rate used to determine if the ALR has been 31 exceeded will be calculated as the average daily flow rate into the sump, expressed as gallons per acre per 32 day (unless Ecology approves a different calculation). This calculation will be performed on a weekly 33 basis during the active (operational) life of the landfill, and monthly after the landfill has been closed. 34 Post-closure frequency may be reduced if only minimal amounts of leachate accumulate in the leak 35 detection system sump. As outlined in WAC 173-303-665(4)(c)(ii), during post-closure monitoring, if 36 the liquid level in the LDS sump stays below the pump operating level for two consecutive months, 37 monitoring of the amount of liquid in the LDS sumps can be reduced to at least quarterly. If the liquid 38 level in the LDS sump stays below the pump operating level for two consecutive quarters, monitoring of 39 the amount of liquid in the LDS sumps can be reduced to at least semiannually. Pump operating level is 40 defined as a liquid level approved by Ecology, based on pump activation level, sump dimensions, and 41 level that minimizes head in the sump. 42 4C.1.2. Response Actions 43 WAC 173-303-665(9) lists several required actions if the ALR is exceeded. In the event that the ALR is 44 exceeded, the United States Department of Energy (DOE) will: 45 * Notify Ecology in writing of the exceedance within 7 days of the determination. Appendix 4C.5

--- Page 322 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 * Submit a preliminary written assessment to Ecology within 14 days of the determination, as to the 2 amount of liquids, likely sources of liquids, possible location, size, cause of any leaks, and short- 3 term actions taken and planned. 4 * Determine, to the extent practicable, the location, size, and cause of any leak. 5 * Determine whether waste receipt should cease or be curtailed, whether any waste should be 6 removed from the unit for inspection, repairs, or controls, and whether or not the unit should be 7 closed. 8 * Determine any other short-term and longer-term actions to be taken to mitigate or stop any leaks. 9 * Within 30 days after the notification that the action leakage rate has been exceeded, submit to 10 Ecology the results of the analyses specified in bullets 3, 4, and 5 of this section, the results of 11 actions taken, and actions planned. Monthly thereafter, as long as the flow rate in the leak 12 detection system exceeds the action leakage rate, the owner or operator must submit to the 13 regional administrator a report summarizing the results of any remedial actions taken and actions 14 planned. 15 If the ALR is exceeded, DOE will submit the required notifications to Ecology, as stated above. The EPA 16 will also receive copies of this confirmation. 17 The leachate will be analyzed for Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) constituents. If the 18 analytical results indicate that these constituents are present, and if the constituents can be traced to a 19 particular type of waste stored in a known area of the landfill, then it may be possible to estimate the 20 location of the leak. However, because the waste will meet land disposal restrictions, it will contain no 21 free liquids and will be stabilized or solidified, except as allowed by Appendix 3A, section 1.2. In 22 addition, the canister(s) or other type of waste package(s) may not undergo enough deterioration during 23 the active life of the landfill to permit escape of its contents. For these reasons, it is possible that the 24 leachate may be clean or the composition too general to indicate a specific source location. 25 If the source location cannot be identified, large-scale removal of the waste and operations layer to find 26 and repair the leaking area of the liner would be one option for remediation. However, this procedure 27 risks damaging the liner. In addition, waste would have to be handled, stored, and replaced in the landfill. 28 Backfill would need to be removed from around the waste packages to accomplish this. If the waste 29 packages are damaged during this process, the risk of accidental release may be high. For these reasons, 30 large scale removal of waste and liner system materials is not considered a desirable option and will not 31 be implemented except as a last resort. 32 The preferred options for remediation include covers and changes in landfill operating procedures. The 33 preferred alternative will depend on factors such as the amount of waste already in the landfill, the rate of 34 waste receipt, the chemistry of the leachate, the availability of other RCRA-compliant disposal facilities, 35 and similar considerations. Hence, at this time no single approach can be selected. If the ALR is 36 exceeded, potential options will be evaluated prior to selecting a remediation process. If necessary, an 37 interim solution will be implemented while the evaluation and permanent remediation is performed. 38 Examples of potential approaches include the following: 39 * The surface of the intermediate soil cover over the waste could be graded to direct runoff into a 40 shallow pond. The surface would then be covered with a discardable, temporary geomembrane 41 (e.g., 30-mil PVC or reinforced polypropylene). Precipitation water would be pumped or 42 evaporated from the pond and would not infiltrate the waste already in the landfill. Waste 43 packages would be placed only during periods of dry weather and stored temporarily at other 44 times. This type of approach would also be used, if necessary, to reduce leakage during the time 45 immediately after the ALR was exceeded, while other remediation options were being evaluated. 46 * If the landfill was nearly full, partial construction of the final closure cover might be an option. 47 This would reduce infiltration into the landfill and possibly the leakage rate, if the cover was 48 constructed over the failed area. Appendix 4C.6

--- Page 323 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility I * A layer of low-permeability soil could be placed over the existing waste, perhaps in conjunction 2 with a geomembrane, to create a second "primary" liner higher in the landfill. This new liner 3 would intercept precipitation and allow its removal. 4 * A rigid-frame or air-supported structure could be constructed over the landfill to ensure that no 5 infiltration occurred. Although costly, this approach might be less expensive than constructing a 6 new landfill. 7 In general, the selected remediation efforts would be those that are easiest to implement, with more 8 difficult or expensive options to be applied only if earlier approaches were not satisfactory. 9 4C.2. A & B 2 Part 1 -General 3 Work Included 4 This section describes requirements for clearing, grubbing and stripping of the IDF project area and 5 associated facilities. 6 Definitions 7 Interfering or Objectionable Material: Trash, rubbish, and junk. 8 Clearing: Removal of existing vegetation and interfering or objectionable material lying on or 9 protruding above ground surface. 10 Grubbing: Removal of vegetation and other organic matter including sagebrush, stumps, buried logs, 11 and roots greater than 2 inches caliper to a depth of 6 inches below subgrade. 12 Stripping: Removal of topsoil and other organic matter. Strippings suitable for topsoil shall be limited 13 to upper 6 inches. 14 Project Limits: Areas actually needed for site improvements, stockpiles, and borrow areas, as shown or 15 specified, within which work is to be performed. 16 Raw Water SuppyI 17 Depending on the availability of connections to the raw water pipeline system, water for dust control may 18 be obtained either from an existing water fill station on 4th Street near the west exit of the 200 East Area 19 or from the raw water line that crosses the IDF site. A new raw water pipeline is being installed as part of 20 Schedule A of the IDF project. 21 Whether water is obtained from the existing water fill station or from new facilities on the IDF site, use of 22 connections to the raw water system shall be in accordance with guidance from the Hanford Site Water 23 Purveyor. Use and discharge of raw water during construction for construction activities, including dust 24 control and fire protection, shall be controlled through the Hanford Site Water Purveyor, and shall comply 25 with WAC 173-200 and the State Waste Discharge Permit No. ST 4508. For any use of existing water fill 26 station or a water connection on the IDF site, the total of all IDF project water usage from the raw water 27 system shall not exceed 1,500 gpm. There is no guarantee that the 1,500 gpm will be available at all 28 times or that will be available from a single location on the IDF water system. In addition, the maximum 29 water use limitation may be periodically reduced by the Hanford Site Water Purveyor depending on the 30 other Hanford Site demands on the raw water system and/or the availability of raw water pumping 31 capacity within the Hanford raw water system. When using any connection to the raw water system, the 32 Construction General Contractor shall take whatever means are necessary to operate fill stations and other 33 connections in such a manner to prevent causing water hammer. If water usage from the system is found 34 to cause water hammer, the Hanford Site Water Purveyor may require the use of orifice plates, changes to 35 valve operation methods, and/or a reduction in water use at a water connection as necessary to eliminate 36 the water hammer. For any onsite fill station, Construction General Contractor shall provide a water 37 storage tank (minimum size 20,000 gallons) equipped with a float actuated fill valve to minimize demand 38 surges on the Hanford Water Supply. 39 Submittals-Approval Required 40 See Section 01300, SUBMITTALS, for submittal procedures. 41 Site Preparation Plan: Prior to any mobilization of equipment to the site, the Construction General 42 Contractor shall submit a Site Preparation Plan for approval. WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 Do not drag the CDN across textured geomembrane in any way that damages the geotextile 2 component or reduces the friction at the geomembrane/CDN interface. 3 In the presence of wind, all exposed CDNs shall be weighted with sandbags or equivalent. Dirt or 11 excessive dust entrapped in the CDN shall be cleaned prior to placement of the next material on top 12 of it. Excessive dust is defined as any thickness greater than 20 mils (0.02 inch) within the geonet 13 core of the CDN. In this regard, care shall be taken with the handling of sandbags, to prevent rupture 14 or damage of the sandbag. 15 Tools shall not be left in the CDN. 16 After deployment, all CDN shall be covered within a maximum period of 14 days to prevent exposure 17 of geotextile component to ultraviolet (UV) radiation (sunlight). Acceptable tying devices include strings, plastic 22 fasteners, or polymer braid. Tying devices shall be white or yellow for easy observation. Metallic 23 devices are not allowed. 24 Overlaps shall be secured every 5 feet along slopes and on the floor of the landfill. Overlaps shall be secured 25 every 6 inches in anchor trenches. Along end-to-end seams, spot-weld, or tie each row at 6-inch intervals; 26 stagger weld or ties between rows. 27 In joining CDNs, tearing the geotextile away from the geonet shall only be allowed at panels ends in 28 order to seam same material components together and shall be minimized to the extent necessary to 29 perform the required work. 30 No horizontal seams shall be allowed on side slopes except at roll ends. 31 If more than one layer of CDN is installed, joints shall be staggered. 32 Repair 33 Remove the damaged area of CDN. 34 Cut a piece of geonet to fit into the repair area. Geonet shall fit into repair area to form a flush surface 35 with the CDN. Cut geonet so that ribs are in the same orientation as existing CDN. 36 Remove any dirt or other foreign material, which may have entered the CDN. 37 Place CDN patch over damaged area. Geonet component of patch shall be tied to in-place geonet 38 component according to manufacturer's recommendations. 39 Place Type I geotextile over the exposed geonet component with an overlap of 4 inches of geotextile. 40 Heat seam repair geotextile to existing geotextile. Prevent 30 mortar from drying out and cure by applying a curing compound. Extensions shall be watertight. 31 Installation Of Rings And Covers 32 Set rings and covers at elevations indicated or as determined in field and in conformance with 33 Drawings. 34 Rings may be cast in, or shall be set in mortar. 35 The cover of a catch basin shall not be grouted to final grade until the final elevation of the adjacent 36 ground surface has been established. However, at the discretion of Geosynthetic Installer, seaming may be carried over to the 12 following workday. 13 Placement Conditions: 14 Geomembrane placement shall not proceed at an ambient temperature below 32 degrees F or above 15 104 degrees F as measured 6 inches above the geomembrane surface unless installation procedures 16 approved by the CQA Certifying Engineer are in place to address environmental conditions. 17 Geomembrane placement shall not be done during any precipitation, in the presence of excessive 18 moisture (e.g., fog, dew), in an area of ponded water, or in the presence of excessive winds. 19 Placement methods shall prevent damage to underlying soil liner or geosynthetic materials. 20 Factors such as expansion, contraction, overlap at seams, anchorage requirements, seaming progress, 21 and drainage shall be considered. Textured-surface sheets shall be aligned in a manner, which 22 maximizes theii frictional capabilities along the slope. Maneuver sheets of geomembrane into place 23 in a manner, which prevents wrinkles, folds, or similar distress, which can damage the geomembrane 24 or prevent its satisfactory alignment or seaming. A smooth-surface HDPE geomembrane rub sheet 25 shall be used when placing textured HDPE geomembrane over underlying GCL. The rub sheet shall 26 be maintained in good condition without tears, rough edges, holes, or scuff marks that can catch, 27 displace, or otherwise disturb the underlying GCL, or the overlying geomembrane. 28 Damage: Damaged panels or portions of damaged panels, which have been rejected, shall be removed 29 from the work area. Any repairs shall be made according to procedures described in this Part of the 30 Specifications. 31 Exposed Geomembrane Protection: After panel deployment, all geomembrane, except those shown as 32 permanently exposed on the Drawings, shall be covered to within a maximum period of 20 working days 33 to minimize exposure to temperature cycles that cause expansion/contraction of the geomembrane and 34 desiccation of the underlying admix liner. Any observed desiccation observed outside 37 of specification tolerance will be repaired and the geomembrane covered immediately. Additional 38 exposure areas may be required by CQA to verify complete repair areas required. WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility I Extrusion Process: 2 The extrusion-welding machine shall be equipped with gages capable of measuring the temperature at 3 the nozzle or the preheat temperature. 4 The Installer shall provide documentation regarding the extrudate and shall certify that the extrudate 5 is compatible with these Specifications and is comprised of the same resin type as the geomembrane 6 sheeting. 7 The Installer shall comply with the following: 8 The Installer shall maintain on-site a sufficient number of spare operable seaming machines (at least 9 one at all times) to ensure continuous operation. 10 The equipment used for seaming shall not be likely to damage the geomembrane. 11 The extruder shall be purged prior to beginning a seam until all heat-degraded extrudate has been 12 removed from the barrel. 13 The electric generator shall be placed on a smooth base such that no damage occurs to the 14 geomembrane. 15 Grinding shall be completed no more than 1 hour prior to seaming. 16 A smooth insulating plate or fabric shall be placed beneath the hot welding machine after usage. 17 The geomembrane shall be protected from damage in heavily trafficked areas. 18 Fusion Process: The fusion-welding machines shall be automated vehicular-mounted devices. The 19 fusion-welding machines shall be equipped with gages giving the pertinent temperatures. 20 The Installer shall comply with the following: 21 The Installer shall maintain on site a sufficient number of spare operable seaming machines (at least 22 one at all times) to ensure continuous operations. 23 The equipment used for seaming shall not be likely to damage the geomembrane. 24 The electric generator shall be placed on a smooth base such that no damage occurs to the 25 geomembrane. 26 A smooth insulating plate or fabric shall be placed beneath the hot welding machine after usage. 27 The geomembrane shall be protected from damage in heavily trafficked areas. 28 If a build-up of moisture is observed prior to seaming a movable protective layer shall be used directly 29 below each overlap of geomembrane to be seamed to prevent buildup of moisture between the sheets. 30 Seam Layout: In general, seams shall be oriented parallel to the line of maximum slope, i.e., oriented up 31 and down, not across, the slope to the maximum extent practical. In comers and odd-shaped geometric 32 locations, the number of seams shall be minimized. No seams shall be permitted within the LCRS sump 33 trough for leachate collection and riser pipes. One full panel width shall span the LCRS sump trough. 34 On the landfill floor: 35 No horizontal seam shall be less than 5 feet from the toe of the slope, or other area of potential stress 36 concentrations. 37 Over the LCRS, LDS, and SLDS sump areas in each cell, no horizontal seam shall be placed less than 38 150 feet from the toe of the north slope for a distance of at least 100 feet in each direction from the 39 LCRS and LDS sump centerline. 40 Seams shall be aligned to produce the fewest possible number of wrinkles and "fishmouths". 41 A seam numbering system consistent with the panel numbering system shall be utilized. WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility I Weather Conditions for Seaming: The allowable weather conditions for seaming are as follows: 2 Unless authorized in writing by the Construction Manager, no seaming shall be attempted at ambient 3 temperatures below 32 degrees F or above 104 degrees F as measured 6 inches above the 4 geomembrane surface. 5 The geomembrane shall be dry, protected from wind, and free of dust. 6 If the Installer wishes to use methods, which may allow seaming at ambient temperatures below 7 32 degrees F, the Installer shall certify in writing that the quality of the seams welded at these 8 temperatures is the same as the quality of seams welded at temperatures above 32 degrees F. In 9 addition, if the Installer wishes to seam at ambient temperatures below 32 degrees F, the following 10 conditions shall be satisfied in addition to the general seaming procedures: 11 For extrusion welding, preheating shall be performed. Preheating may be waived by the Construction 12 Manager if it is demonstrated to the satisfaction of the CQA Certifying Engineer that welds of 13 equivalent quality may be obtained without preheating at the expected temperature of installation. 14 Sheet grinding, if required, may be performed before preheating. 15 Observe all areas of the geomembrane that have been preheated to determine that they have not been 16 subjected to excessive melting. 17 Confirm that geomembrane surface temperatures have not decreased below the minimum specified 18 for welding, due to wind or other adverse conditions. Wind protection for the seam area may be 19 required. 20 Trial seams, as described in paragraph Trial Seams of this section, shall be made in the immediate 21 area where seaming will occur, under the same ambient temperature and preheating conditions as the 22 actual seams. New trial seams shall be made if the ambient temperature decreases by more than 23 5 degrees F from the previous trial seam conditions. Such new trial seams shall be conducted as soon 24 as seams in progress during the temperature drop have been completed. 25 Additional destructive seam tests, as described in paragraph Destructive Seam Strength Testing of 26 this section, shall be performed at intervals of 250 to 500 feet of seam length at the CQA Certifying 27 Engineer's discretion. 28 The Installer shall provide sample coupons cut from each end of the seam. 29 Seam Preparation: 30 Cleaning: Prior to seaming, the seam area shall be clean and free of moisture, dust, dirt, debris of any 31 kind, and foreign material. Special attention shall be paid to cleaning the existing geomembrane at tie-in 32 locations. 33 Overlap: Cross slope, seams on both the trench floor and sideslopes shall be overlapped so that liquids 34 are not trapped, i.e., seams shall be shingled downslope. If seam overlap grinding is required, the process 35 shall be completed according to the geomembrane manufacturer's instructions within I hour of the 36 seaming operation, and in a way, that does not damage the geomembrane. Panels of geomembrane shall 37 have a finished overlap of a minimum of 3 inches for extrusion welding and 5 inches for fusion welding. 38 Use of Solvents: No solvent or adhesive shall be used. 39 Temporary Bonding: The procedure used to temporarily bond adjacent panels together shall not 40 damage the geomembrane; in particular, the temperature of hot air at the nozzle of any spot welding 41 apparatus shall be controlled such that the geomembrane is not damaged. 42 General Seaming Procedure: The general seaming procedure used by the Installer shall be as follows: 43 Seaming shall extend to the outside edge of panels to be placed in the anchor trench. 44 If required, a firm substrate shall be provided by using a flat board, a conveyor belt, or similar hard 45 surface directly under the seam overlap to achieve proper support.
