WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility I If seaming operations are carried out at night, adequate illumination shall be provided. 2 "Fishmouths" or wrinkles at the seam overlaps shall be cut along the ridge of the wrinkle in order to 3 achieve a flat overlap. The cut "fishmouths" or wrinkles shall be seamed, and any portion where the 4 overlap is inadequate shall then be patched with an oval or round patch of the same geomembrane 5 extending a minimum of 6 inches beyond the cut in all directions. 6 Construction Quality Control Testing -Polyethylene Geomembranes 7 General: Testing requirements specified herein are intended for the Construction General Contractor 8 (and Geomembrane Installer) during geomembrane installation. Testing requirements for the CQA 9 Certifying Engineer are provided in the CQA Plan. 10 Trial Seams: 11 Trial seams shall be made on fragment pieces of geomembrane liner to verify that seaming conditions 12 are adequate. A trial seam shall be made prior to each seaming period (maximum of 6 hours) for each 13 seaming machine used that day. Also, each seamer shall make at least one trial seam each day. Trial 14 seams shall be made under the same conditions as actual seams. 15 The trial seam sample shall be at least 2 feet long by 1 foot wide (after seaming) with the seam 16 centered lengthwise. Seam overlap shall be as indicated in this Part. 17 Test three specimens for peel and two specimens for shear. Each specimen shall be at least 1 inch 18 wide and shall be cut from the trial seam sample by the Installer. The specimens shall be tested 19 respectively in shear and peel using a field tensiometer, and they shall not fail in the seam. All trial 20 seam specimens must meet the minimum requirements of Table 2, Required Seam Properties, for trial 21 seam acceptance. If a specimen fails, the entire operation shall be repeated. If the additional 22 specimen fails, the seaming apparatus and seamer shall not be accepted and shall not be used for 23 seaming until the deficiencies are corrected and two consecutive successful full trial seams are 24 achieved. 25 All test equipment shall be in calibration and conform to manufacturer's specifications. The Installer 26 shall provide the Construction Manager and CQA Certifying Engineer with current calibration 27 certificates. 28 Nondestructive Seam Continuity Testing: 29 General: 30 The Installer shall nondestructively test all field seams over their full length using a vacuum test unit, 31 air pressure test (for double fusion seams only), or other approved method (i.e., spark test). Vacuum 32 testing and air pressure testing are described below. The purpose of the nondestructive test is to 33 check the continuity of seams. It does not provide any information on seam strength. Continuity 34 testing shall be done as the seaming work progresses. Nondestructive testing will not be permitted 35 before sunrise or after sunset unless the Construction General Contractor demonstrates to the CQA 36 Certifying Engineer their capability to perform testing under reduced light conditions. Any seams, 37 which fail nondestructive testing, shall be repaired in accordance with these Specifications. Seams, 38 which cannot be nondestructively tested because of seam geometry, shall be double welded or 39 capped. 40 All test equipment shall be in calibration and conform to manufacturer's specifications. The Installer 41 shall submit current calibration certificates. 42 Vacuum Testing: The equipment shall be comprised of the following: 43 A vacuum box assembly consisting of a rigid housing, a transparent viewing window, a soft neoprene 44 gasket attached to the bottom, port hole or valve assembly, and a vacuum gage. 45 A steel vacuum tank and pump assembly equipped with a pressure controller and connections. 46 A rubber pressure/vacuum hose with fittings and connections. --- Page 399 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 A bucket and wide paint brush. 2 A soapy solution. 3 The following procedures shall be used: 4 Energize the vacuum pump and reduce the tank pressure to a minimum of 5 inches of mercury. 5 Wet a strip of geomembrane approximately 12 inches wide by 48 inches long with the soapy solution. 6 Place the vacuum box over the test area. 7 Close the bleed valve and open the vacuum valve. 8 Ensure that a leak tight seal is created. 9 For a period of not less than 10 seconds, examine the geomembrane through the viewing window for 10 the presence of soap bubbles. 11 If no bubbles appear coming from the seam after 10 seconds, close the vacuum valve and open the 12 bleed valve, move the box over the next adjoining area with a minimum 3-inch overlap, and repeat 13 the process. 14 All areas where soap bubbles appear shall be marked and repaired in accordance with this Part. 15 Air Pressure Testing: The following procedures are applicable only to those processes, which produce a 16 double seam with an enclosed air channel. All double seams with an enclosed air channel shall be air 17 pressure tested. The equipment shall be comprised of the following: 18 An air pump (manual or motor driven) capable of generating and sustaining a pressure of 60 to 65 psi. 19 A rubber hose with fittings and connections. 20 A sharp hollow needle, or other approved pressure feed device. 21 A calibrated pressure gage capable of reading pressures up to 65 psi. 22 The following procedures shall be used: 23 Seal both ends of the seam to be tested. 24 Insert needle with pressure gage, or other approved pressure feed device, into the air channel created 25 by the fusion weld. 26 Energize the air pump and pressurize the channel to a minimum 25 psi for a 1/2-inch wide channel, or 27 55 psi for a 1-inch wide channel. Close the valve and sustain the pressure for a minimum of 28 5 minutes. 29 If loss of pressure exceeds 2 psi, or does not stabilize, locate faulty area and repair in accordance with 30 this section. If significant changes in geomembrane temperature occur during the test (e.g., due to 31 cloud cover), the test shall be repeated after the geomembrane temperature has stabilized. 32 Cut end of seam opposite to the pressure gage and observe that the pressure drops. If the pressure 33 does not drop, locate the obstruction(s) in the seam, repair, and retest seam. 34 Remove needle or other approved pressure feed device and repair seam. 35 Destructive Seam Strength Testing: 36 General: 37 Destructive seam tests shall be performed at selected locations. The purpose of these tests is to 38 evaluate seam strength. Seam strength testing shall be done as the seaming work progresses. The 39 samples shall meet the requirements of Table 2, Required Seam Properties. 40 All test equipment shall be in calibration and conform to manufacturer's specifications. The Installer 41 shall submit current calibration certificates. 42 Each sample shall be tested for bonded seam shear and peel strength by an independent testing 43 laboratory. Appendix 4D.74

If any test sample fails to pass, then the procedures outlined 35 below (Procedures for Areas Failing Destructive Tests) shall be followed. 36 The CQA Certifying Engineer will mark all samples and portions with its number. The CQA 37 Certifying Engineer will also record the date and time, ambient temperature, number of seaming unit, 38 name of seamer, welding apparatus temperatures and pressures, and pass or fail descriptions, and 39 attach a copy to each sample portion. 40 Procedures for Areas Failing Destructive Tests: The following procedures shall apply whenever a 41 sample fails a destructive test, whether that test is conducted by the independent testing laboratory, the 42 Installer's laboratory, or by field tensiometer. The Installer has two options: 43 The Installer shall cap the seam between any two passing test locations, or 44 The Installer shall trace the seam to two intermediate locations 10 feet minimum from the point of the 45 failed test in each direction and take a small sample for an additional field test at each location. If 46 these additional samples pass the test, then full samples shall be taken for laboratory testing. Appendix 4D.75

WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 If these laboratory samples pass the tests, then the seam shall be capped between these locations. If 2 either sample fails, then the sampling and testing process shall be repeated to establish the zone over 3 which the seam shall be capped. 4 All acceptable capped seams shall be bounded by two locations from which samples passing CQA 5 laboratory destructive tests have been taken. In cases where the length of the capped seam exceeds 6 150 feet, a sample of the capping seam shall be taken and shall pass destructive testing as described in this 7 Part. 8 Repairs -Polyethylene Geomembranes 9 General: 10 Any portion of the geomembrane exhibiting a flaw or failing a destructive or nondestructive test shall 11 be repaired. All repairs shall be conducted in accordance with this Part. All repairs shall be subjected 12 to the nondestructive seam testing procedures described in this Part. 13 Each patch or other type of repair will be numbered and recorded. 14 Repair Procedures: 15 Patching, used to repair large holes, tears, undispersed raw materials, and contamination by foreign 16 matter. 17 Grinding and rewelding, used to repair small sections (typically with a maximum length of no more 18 than several inches) of extruded seams. 19 Spot welding or seaming used to repair pinholes. 20 Capping, used to repair large lengths of failed seams or areas where large wrinkles or fish mouths 21 have been cut to flatten the geomembrane sheet. 22 Topping, used to repair areas of inadequate seams, which have an exposed edge. Topping shall be 23 limited to an aggregate length of no more than 3 m (10 feet) on any given seam. 24 Removing bad seam and replacing with a strip of new material welded into place, used with large 25 lengths of fusion seams. 26 For all repair methods, the following provisions shall be satisfied as applicable: 27 Surfaces of the geomembrane, which are to be repaired, shall be abraded no more than one hour prior 28 to the repair. 29 All surfaces shall be clean and dry at the time of the repair. 30 Patches or caps shall extend at least 6 inches beyond the edge of the defect, and all corners of patches 31 shall be rounded with a radius of at least 3 inches. 32 The geomembrane below large caps shall be appropriately cut to avoid water or gas collection 33 between the two sheets. 34 Verification of Repairs: Each repair shall be numbered and recorded. Each repair shall be 35 nondestructively tested using the methods described in this Part. Large caps may be of sufficient extent to 36 require destructive test sampling. Repairs that fail nondestructive or destructive tests shall be redone and 37 retested until a passing test is obtained. 38 Protection Of Termination Edges 39 Along the south termination of the geomembrane, and along any termination edges of the membrane that 40 may be exposed or buried for extended periods of time prior to their joining to adjacent subsequent 41 sections, the Construction General Contractor shall protect leading edges with protective (sacrificial) 42 layers of cushion geotextile and plywood sheet as shown on the Drawings. WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility I Materials In Contact With Geomembrane 2 The requirements of this Part are intended only to assure that the installation of other materials does not 3 damage the geomembrane. Additional requirements as established in other sections of these 4 Specifications are necessary to assure that systems built with these other materials are constructed in such 5 a way as to provide proper performance. Material requirements for operations layer and drain gravel are 6 specified in Section 02315, FILL AND BACKFILL. 7 Requirements of this Part apply to geomembranes that are directly in contact with overlying soil or are 8 covered with a layer of geotextile or geocomposite. 9 Do not place granular materials in manner that will cause wrinkles to fold over or become confined to 10 form a vertical ridge. Maximum wrinkle height shall be 4 inches and spacing between wrinkles shall be 11 greater than 10 feet prior to placement of granular materials over the geomembrane. 12 Minimum Thickness: Equipment used for spreading granular material shall not be driven directly on the 13 geomembrane. A minimum thickness of 1 foot of granular material shall be maintained between 14 spreading equipment and the geomembrane. A minimum thickness of 3 feet of granular material shall be 15 maintained between rubber-tired hauling vehicles and the geomembrane. Construction haul vehicles shall 16 have a maximum ground contact pressure of 25 psi. 17 Spreading Equipment: Equipment used for spreading granular material shall be a light low ground 18 pressure dozer (such as a wide-pad Caterpillar D6M LGP or lighter), low ground pressure excavator 19 (Bucyrus-Erie 325H with 0.91-m [36-in] wide treads or lighter), or approved equal, with a maximum 20 ground contact pressure of 5 psi. 21 Spreading Operations: 22 Spreading equipment operating on soil materials shall not spin their tracks, make sharp turns, or make 23 sharp, rapid starts or stops. Soil materials shall be pushed carefully from previously placed material 24 and not dumped directly onto geosynthetics except for the drain gravel in the LDS sump and 25 operations layer material in SLDS sump. This material shall be carefully dumped onto the cushion 26 geotextile or SLDS CDN from a maximum height of 24 inches. 27 The spreading operation on the sideslope (3H:1V) shall begin at the lower elevations and shall 28 proceed either upslope or laterally at about the same elevation such that a full layer of granular 29 material is always covering the geomembrane downslope from the area being covered. In no case 30 shaU the lift thickness be less than the stated minimum. Material shall be placed in such a manner 31 that no air is trapped underneath the geomembrane. Provide and maintain a means of continuously 32 observing the depth of granular materials such as by freestanding markers until placement is 33 complete, at intervals of 50 feet maximum each way. Sharpened stakes or methods that could 34 damage the geomembrane will not be allowed. 35 Lining System Acceptance -Polyethylene Geomembranes 36 The Installer shall retain all ownership of and responsibility for the geosynthetics in the lining system 37 until acceptance by the Construction Manager. 38 The geosynthetic lining system will be accepted by the Construction Manager when all of the 39 following requirements have been satisfied: 40 The installation is finished. 41 Verification of the adequacy of all field seams and repairs, including associated testing, is complete. 42 A written construction report, including "as built" drawings and all other installation documents, has 43 been prepared by the CQA Certifying Engineer, sealed by a registered professional engineer, and 44 received by the Construction Manager. WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 Definitions 2 Grain Size: Determined by ASTM D422. 3 Imported Material: Meets requirements of this Specification and is obtained offsite and transported to 4 site. 5 Natural Moisture Content: Determined by ASTM D2216. 6 Optimum Moisture Content: Determined in accordance with ASTM D698 specified to determine 7 maximum dry density for relative compaction. 8 Admix: Natural material (base soil), as specified in this section, that when mixed with bentonite. 9 Admix Liner: Compacted liner component consisting of admix materials, designed, formulated, and 10 constructed to provide low-permeability barrier against infiltration of liquids or contaminants. 11 Tolerances 12 Thickness of the admix liner shall be a minimum of 3 feet and tolerances for the top of admix grade 13 shown on Phase I Primary Liner Plan shall be minus 0.1 foot to plus 0.3 foot. The top surface of the 14 admix liner along the north-south centerline of each cell shall be graded to provide a minimum slope 15 of 1.0% for the LCRS collection pipe installation. Do not provide calcium bentonites or chemically treated sodium bentonites. 22 The bentonite to be used in the admix shall consist of a commercially prepared material and shall have the 23 following index properties: 24 High Swelling: Ability of 2 grams of base bentonite, when mechanically reduced to minus 100 mesh, to 25 swell in water to an apparent volume of 20 cubic centimeters or more when added gradually to 100 cubic 26 centimeters of distilled water contained in graduated cylinder. 27 Dry Fineness: 28 65 percent minimum passing No. 200 U.S. Sieve. 29 The Construction General Contractor shall provide suitable containers on site to store bentonite in a 30 dry condition prior to use. 31 Base Soil 32 The base soil for the admix liner shall consist of natural soil derived from the admix base soil borrow 33 area shown on the Drawings, as specified in Section 02317, BORROW AREA EXCAVATION, or 34 from site excavations. Base soil from either source shall not be excavated below a depth of 5 feet 35 below ground surface (after stripping) without evaluation of the material suitability and approval from 36 the Engineer. This material may be temporarily stockpiled at the stockpile area as shown on the 37 Drawings, or within processing area within Phase I as approved by the Construction Manager. 38 Base soil excavated from dune sand borrows area or site excavation shall meet the following 39 requirements: The base soil shall be free of roots, woody vegetation, frozen material, rubbish, and 40 other deleterious material. Rocks greater than 1 inch in dimension shall not comprise more than 41 2 percent by weight of the base soil. Base soil shall have 20 percent minimum passing No. 200 U.S. 42 Sieve. WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility I The accuracy will be determined by operating each feed control separately and collecting and 2 weighing the material over a given period of time as determined by the CQA Certifying Engineer. 3 The material shall be collected in a dump truck (or appropriate container) supplied by the 4 Construction General Contractor, and the truck will be weighed by the Construction General 5 Contractor and verified by the CQA Certifying Engineer before and after loading. The admix shall be broken down in size sufficiently to result in at least 80 percent of 17 the soil clumps broken down to 1/2 inch in maximum size. Clods are defined as dry hard particles in 18 the admix that cannot be remolded by hand pressure. 19 If mixing is found to be insufficient to produce a thoroughly blended, uniform mixture of base soil 20 and bentonite, or the base soil and bentonite are not being mixed in the specified proportions, the 21 Construction General Contractor shall stop production of admix material. The Construction General Contractor shall not change the bentonite application rate unless 29 directed to do so by the Engineer in writing. 30 Admix shall be processed and allowed to cure at least 12 hours prior to placement. WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 The test pad location will be cleared and grubbed, and the subgrade will be compacted in the same 2 manner anticipated for construction beneath the waste disposal cells. If the moisture content of a lift of compacted admix liner falls below the 27 acceptable limit during placement operations, the Construction General Contractor shall moisture 28 condition the dry soil and re-compact the lift prior to placement of additional lifts. If the moisture 29 content of a lift of compacted soil exceeds the acceptable limit due to precipitation or over watering, 30 the Construction General Contractor, before placement of additional lifts, shall either allow the wet 31 soil to dry back or remove the wet soil. If the admix liner material cannot be conditioned to meet the 32 placement specifications, the material shall be removed and replaced with new admix liner. 33 When the final lift of admix liner placement will be interrupted for more than a few hours or when 34 precipitation is imminent, as determined by the Contractor's Site Superintendent, the lift surface shall 35 be sealed with a smooth drum roller to prevent excessive moisture infiltration. This surface shall be 36 scarified with a rotovator, or other equivalent equipment, immediately prior to resuming soil 37 placement. The Construction General Contractor shall verify that existing moisture content is within 38 the range specified in Article ADMIX LINER PLACEMENT AND COMPACTION, prior to 39 resumption of soil placement activities. 40 Placement Equipment: The Construction General Contractor shall place layers of the admix liner to 41 form a continuous monolithic material. All admix liner shall be placed and compacted with a self- 42 propelled pegfoot or padfoot roller compactor having a minimum operating weight of 68,000 pounds. 43 Smaller compaction equipment may be used in limited areas as necessary provided that the required 44 moisture/density, lift bonding, and hydraulic conductivity can be achieved. Hydraulic conductivity 45 performance specification for the admix liner will be verified in areas where the lighter equipment is 46 used. Hauling and spreading equipment will not be considered as compaction equipment. The compactor 47 feet shall be sufficiently long to knead (bond) new lifts into previously placed lifts. The moisture content shall be no more than 15 percent as determined by 35 oven-dried weight. Each package of the wood fiber mulch shall be marked by the manufacturer to show 36 the dried weight. Wood fiber mulch shall be added to the tackifier at the rate of 1,500 pounds per acre 37 minimum. 38 Straw Mulch: Straw mulch shall be air dried straw free of noxious weeds and other materials 39 detrimental to plant life. Straw shall be seasoned before baling or loading. Straw mulch so provided shall 40 be suitable for spreading with mulch blower equipment. 41 Tackifier: The tackifier shall be an organic guar tackifier derived form natural organic plant sources or a 42 100 percent polyacrylamide. The tackifier used shall contain no growth or germination inhibiting 43 materials. The guar based tackifier shall be applied at a rate of 60 pounds per acre minimum. If 44 polyacrylamide is used as the tackifier instead of guar, it shall be applied at 5 pounds per acre minimum. 45 Erosion Control Matting: 46 Erosion control matting shall be used to prevent erosion of soil due primarily to wind. Erosion control 47 matting shall be a long-life dense matting composed of nylon fiber, polyolefin fiber, or polyester 48 fibers. Appendix 4D.97

WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 The matting shall be of a consistent thickness with the fiber evenly distributed over the entire area of 2 the matting. WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 Areas to be seeded that have not either had material excavated from them or placed in them shall not 2 receive any seedbed preparation unless directed otherwise by the Construction Manager. The 3 seedbed preparation would destroy any existing soil crust. Existing soil crust provides erosion 4 protection. 5 Application of Seed and Fertilizer: Seeding and fertilizing shall be done closely following seedbed 6 preparation and shall not be done during windy weather or when the ground is frozen or excessively wet. 7 The Construction General Contractor shall notify the Construction Manager not less than 24 hours in 8 advance of any seeding operation and shall not begin the work until areas prepared or designated for 9 seeding have been approved. Following the Construction Manager's approval, seeding of the approved 10 areas shall begin immediately. 11 Seed and fertilizer shall be applied by one of the following methods: 12 Hydroseeding: Use a hydroseeder that utilizes water as the carrying agent, and maintains continuous 13 agitation through paddle blades. It shall have an operating capacity sufficient to agitate, suspend, and mix 14 into a homogeneous slurry the specified amount of seed and water or other material. Distribution and 15 discharge lines shall be large enough to prevent stoppage and shall be equipped with a set of hydraulic 16 discharge spray nozzles that will provide a uniform distribution of the slurry. Seed and fertilizer may be 17 applied in one application provided that the fertilizer is placed in the hydroseeder tank no more than I 18 hour prior to application. 19 Hand Broadcasting: 20 Apply fertilizer first. The seed shall be incorporated into the top 1/4 inch of soil by hand raking or 21 other method that is approved by the Construction Manager. 22 Wood fiber mulch shall be added as a tracer to visibly aid uniform application. The application rate 23 of wood fiber mulch used as a tracer shall not exceed 250 pounds per acre. 24 Seed shall be applied at a rate of 10 to 12 pounds pure live seed per acre. Fertilizer shall be applied at 25 a rate of 1,000 pounds per acre. 26 Mulching: 27 Straw mulch shall be evenly applied at a rate of 1.0 ton per acre within 48 hours after seeding. 28 Mulching shall not be performed when wind interferes with mulch placement. Distribution of straw 29 mulch material shall be by means of a mulch spreader that utilizes forced air to blow mulch material 30 on the seeded areas. In spreading straw mulch, the spreader shall not cut or break the straw into short 31 stalks. Straw mulch may be spread by hand over areas that were seeded by hand. Straw mulch shall 32 be crimped into the soil to a depth of 2 inches and with no more than one pass of the equipment. 33 In areas where it is not possible to crimp the straw mulch into the soil, tackifier shall be applied over 34 the straw mulch. The method of application for tackifier shall be in accordance with the 35 manufacturer's instructions. The tackifier application rate shall be as specified herein. Tackifier shall 36 be sprayed over mulch, seed, and fertilizer. The Construction Manager shall indicate which areas (if 37 any) shall have the straw mulch held down with tackifier. 38 Mulching can be accomplished by either hydromulching with wood fiber mulch, or by mulch 39 spreader (or by hand) with straw mulch. Using hydromulching, wood fiber mulch will be added to the 40 tackifier at the rate of 1,500 pounds per acre, in addition to the mulch used as tracer for hydroseeding. 41 Protection: Traffic over seeded areas shall be prohibited. WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility I Moist Curing: Cover concrete surfaces with moisture retaining cover for curing period. Exposed 2 horizontal concrete surfaces may be covered with sand or other approved material and kept wet for the 3 required period. Wood forms shall be kept sufficiently wet at all times to prevent the forms from 4 separating at the joints and the concrete from drying. 5 Membrane Curing: Concrete surfaces to receive membrane curing shall be treated with a curing 6 compound as specified or otherwise approved. The curing compound shall be applied in strict accordance 7 with the directions of the manufacturer of the compound. 8 Temperature, Wind, and Humidity: 9 Cold Weather: 10 When the mean daily outdoor temperature is less than 40 degrees F, the temperature of the concrete 11 surface shall be maintained between 55 and 90 degrees F for the required curing period. When 12 necessary, arrangements for heating, covering, insulating, or housing the concrete work shall be made 13 in advance of placement and shall be adequate to maintain the required temperature without injury 14 due to concentration of heat. Combustion heaters shall not be used during the first 24 hours unless 15 precautions are taken to prevent exposure of the concrete to exhaust gases that contain carbon 16 dioxide. If early loading is anticipated during cold weather, provide temperature protection to ensure 17 necessary strength development. 18 The concrete surface temperature requirements (based on section thickness) in ACI 306.1 may be 19 used in lieu of the 55 degrees F minimum specified before. 20 If concrete surface temperatures as measured by the inspecting agency are below the minimum curing 21 temperature but meet the freeze protection requirements, the concrete curing period shall be extended 22 to ensure adequate strength is developed. The extension time shall be at least equivalent to the time 23 period in which temperatures were too low. 24 Hot Weather: The concrete surfaces shall be kept below 100 degrees F for the curing period. When 25 necessary, provision for windbreaks, shading, fog spraying, sprinkling, ponding, or wet covering with a 26 light colored material shall be made in advance of placement, and such protective measures shall be taken 27 as quickly as concrete hardening and finishing operations will allow. 28 Rate of Temperature Change: 29 Changes in temperature of the air immediately adjacent to the concrete during and immediately 30 following the curing period shall be kept as uniform as possible and shall not exceed 5 degrees F in 31 any 1-hour or 50 degree F in any 24-hour period. 32 Use curing compound only where approved by Construction Manager. Cure formed surfaces with 33 curing compound applied in accordance with manufacturer's directions as soon as forms are removed 34 and finishing is completed. 35 Water Stops: Plastic and Hydrophilic 36 Install in accordance with manufacturer's instructions. 37 Repairing Concrete Cracks 38 Cracks requiring repair shall be determined by the Engineer and shall be repaired using epoxy injection. 39 Method of epoxy injection shall be approved by the Construction Manager prior to application. 40 Appendix 4D.1 11

WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility I Previously coated surfaces shall be recoated only after existing film is completely dry. WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 Loop Descriptions 2 Supplement 4 PLC and OIU Application Software 3 Document Objectives 4 This Supplement No. 4 to Specification Section 13401, PROCESS INSTRUMENTATION AND 5 CONTROL SYSTEMS (PICS) provides the basis for estimating the minimum level of effort required to 6 implement PLC and OIU application software for Cell No. 1 and Cell No. 2 Integrated Disposal Facilities 7 (IDF). 8 Unless otherwise directed by the Tank Farm Contractor during Application Software Submittal and 9 Design Workshops, this document provides guidelines for the programming and testing of all PLC and 10 OIU application software. Note: Issues related to Application Software Submittal and Design Workshops 11 are discussed in Section 13401, PROCESS INSTRUMENTATIONAND CONTROL SYSTEMS (PICS). 12 This Supplement No. 4 shall be used in conjunction with Contract Documents (drawings and 13 specifications, and supplements) and relevant PICS supplier technical information and manuals while 14 developing application software. 15 PICS Supplements shall be provided to Construction General Contractor in electronic format upon 16 request. 17 Reference Management Directive TFC-MD-034, Rev. General -PICS shall implement functions for the purpose of program standardization and 21 minimum PLC application software capability. Functions may not be applicable to every program 22 control loop or network. 23 2. PLC Standard Function No. 1 -Equipment Run Timers: For each equipment ON status input, 24 track the runtime of the associated equipment item. Accumulate equipment runtime in tenths of 25 hours using retentive timers with no timer reset due to equipment stoppage or power loss. Provide 26 a command interface to allow reset or adjustment of equipment run time. 27 3. PLC Standard Function No. 2A -Equipment Failure Detection: Provide for each equipment item 28 controlled by the PLC for which the PLC receives ON and AUTO or REMOTE status signals. 29 Monitor for a fail condition when the unit is in the AUTO or REMOTE mode. A failure condition 30 shall be activated when the unit is commanded by the PLC to run, and the PLC does not receive the 31 unit's ON status signal after a 10-second delay period. When a failure condition is detected, inhibit 32 the PLC run command to the unit. Reset the failure condition when the unit is taken out of AUTO 33 or REMOTE mode. 34 4. PLC Standard Function No. 2B -Equipment Flow Failure Detection: Provide for each pump 35 controlled by the PLC for which the PLC receives a PLC receives ON and AUTO or REMOTE, 36 status and a PUMP DISCHARGE flow signal. Monitor for a fail condition when the unit is in the 37 AUTO or REMOTE mode. A failure condition shall be activated when the unit is commanded by 38 the PLC to run, and the PLC does not receive or maintain a positive flow value for a 10-second 39 delay period. When a failure condition is detected, inhibit the PLC run command to the unit. Reset 40 the failure condition when the unit is taken out of AUTO or REMOTE mode. 41 5. PLC Standard Function No. 3 -Analog Signal Scaling: Provide program logic to scale process 42 analog signals to engineering units that correspond to the calibrated range of the field sensor. Store 43 the scaled value in a PLC memory register for use in process control programming and for 44 transmission to the OIU. Program PLC to monitor each analog input and ALARM in the event a 45 process signal is out of the 4-2OmA range. A process signal out-of-range ALARM condition shall 46 prevent associated process control from taking place. Appendix 4D.250

--- Page 576 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 Program PLC and OIU such that in the event a process signal is out-of-range, data point on OIU 2 shall change to color YELLOW enabling personnel to know the data is incorrect. 3 6. PLC Standard Function No. 4 -Analog alarms: Provide the capability to detect and annunciate 4 alarms, such as high-high, high, low, and low-low for analog process signals. The PLC shall 5 continuously compare the scaled process signal to a set-point value stored in PLC register memory. 6 If the scaled process signal exceeds the alarm set-point, the PLC shall initiate an alarm signal to the 7 OIU system and to external annunciation equipment as noted in the Process Control Loop 8 Descriptions. The analog alarm function shall also have the following capabilities: 9 a. Provide time delays on all alarm set-points. When the PLC detects the scaled process signal 10 exceeding set-point, initiate the alarm delay timer. At the end of the time delay, activate the 11 alarm. 12 b. Unless specified in the Loop Functional Descriptions, all analog alarms shall be self-resetting. 13 The PLC shall reset the alarm condition when the scaled process signal value is within the set- 14 point value plus a 2 percent dead band. 15 c. Where noted in the Loop Functional Descriptions, provide alarm ENABLE/DISABLE program 16 logic that respond to commands from the OIU. Suppress the activation of alarms when 17 commanded to the DISABLE mode. 18 d. Provide program logic to receive, and store in PLC register memory, alarm set-point 19 commands from the OIU. 20 7. PLC Standard Function No. 5 -Discrete alarms: Provide adjustable alarm delay timers on all 21 discrete alarm input signals monitored by the PLC. Upon detection of the alarm condition, the 22 PLC shall initiate the time delay. At the end of the time period, the PLC shall communicate the 23 alarm condition to the OIU system and to external annunciation equipment as noted in the Process 24 Control Loop Descriptions. The discrete alarm function shall also have the following capabilities: 25 a. Unless specified in the Loop Functional Descriptions, all discrete alarms shall be self-resetting. 26 The PLC shall reset the alarm condition when the alarm input signal resets. 27 b. Where noted in the Loop Functional Descriptions, provide alarm ENABLE/DISABLE program 28 logic that respond to commands from the OIU. Suppress the activation of alarms when 29 commanded to the DISABLE mode. 30 8. PLC Standard Function No. 7 -Process Flow Totalizers: For all process flow signals provide 31 program logic in the PLC to accumulate flow totals and flow total RESET. The totaled value 32 stored in the PLC shall be transmitted to the OIU for display and historical logging. PLC shall 33 increment flow total when pump ON status and minimum flow status is confirmed. 34 9. PLC Standard Function No. 8 -Pump Restart Time Delay: Provide adjustable delay timers in 35 PLC program so as to prevent rapid restart of all pumps. An adjustable timer for each pump's 36 AUTO start control logic, shall begin to countdown once a pump has stopped operating. PLC shall 37 not execute AUTO start control logic for each pump until respective adjustable delay timer's 38 accumulated value is equal to preset value of 30 seconds, except for Pumps P-205 and P-207, 39 which will have a 10-second delay period. 40 10. PLC Standard Function No. 9 -Power Failure: Program PLC to prevent PLC from executing 41 process equipment automatic control during a power failure condition. 42 PLC Loop Descriptions 43 Note: Loop Descriptions are typical for both Cell No. 1 and Cell No. 2 process equipment. 44 1. Manual Management Directive Revision TFC-MD-034, REV A GRAPHIC PROCESS DISPLAY of 3 CRITERIA FOR HUMAN-MACHINE Issue Date January 9,2004 INTERFACES Effective Date January 12, 2004 Expiration Date March 1, 2004 FUNCTIONAL AREA MANAGER: D. C. Lowe DOCUMENT OWNER: R. E. Larson 3 1.0 PURPOSE AND SCOPE 4 The purpose of this management directive (MD) is to establish the requirements for standardized criteria 5 for new graphic process displays (human-machine interfaces) that are being designed or acquired for 6 process monitoring and control systems of CH2M HILL Hanford Group, Inc. (CH2M HILL) facilities 7 and managed projects. 8 The requirements of this MD are applicable to new monitoring and control system designs (Human- 9 Machine Interfaces) for CH2M facilities and to projects that have not completed an Acceptance Test 10 Procedure (ATP). Application of the MD requirements to existing human-machine interfaces systems 11 and human-machine interfaces systems with a completed ATP will be determined, planned, and 12 performed in accordance with the resolution of PER-2003-4039. 13 2.0 IMPLEMENTATION 14 This management directive is effective on the date shown in the header and will remain in effect until a 15 new Graphic Process Display Criteria for Human-Machine Interface Standard is issued. 16 3.0 DIRECTIVE 17 The following requirements that are based on the national standard ISA-S5.5-1985, "Graphic Symbols for 18 Process Displays," are the Tank Farm Contractors (TFC) design requirement for new process monitoring 19 and control systems (Human-Machine Interfaces). 20 3.1 General 21 The following general symbol usage standards apply: 22 1. The graphic process display will follow requirements specified in ISA-S5.5 standard. 23 2. The use of outline and solid (filled) symbol forms to indicate status is as follows: 24 * An outline symbol form indicates an off, stopped, or nonactive state. 25 * A solid (filled) symbol form indicates an on, running, or active state. 26 * Status designation by use of solid or outline forms are particularly applicable to the rotating 27 equipment and valves and actuators. In depicting valve position, use solid to show open 28 (material flowing or active) and outline to show closed (material stopped or nonactive). 29 * A symbol may be partially filled or shaded to represent the characteristic of the contents of a 30 vessel, e.g. level, temperature, etc. Appendix 4D.260

--- Page 586 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 3.2 Color 2 The following standards are to be applied to the application of color to process displays: 3 1. The following color application guidelines are to be followed: 4 * The number of colors in one display should be limited to the minimum necessary (typically 4 5 or less) to satisfy the process interface objectives of the display. 6 * Compatible color combinations should be used. 7 * Use color as a redundant indictor along with text, symbol, shape, size, reverse video, 8 blinking, and intensity coding to preserve communication with individuals having limited 9 color perception. 10 * Colors are not to be used to indicate quantitative value. 11 2. Recognizing some requirements of the references 8 cited below may not be applicable, the Engineer shall judge the applicability of compliance with the 9 references not specifically addressed herein. Certificates shall acknowledge 35 that pipe and fittings meet the requirements of the Specifications. 36 Descriptive literature about the fusion equipment to be used and certification from the pipe supplier or 37 manufacturer that the joining technician(s) is certified and experienced in heat fusion joining of 38 HDPE pipe. WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 Statement by the pipe supplier that the technician is certified in the means and methods of joining the 2 supplier's pipe and fittings using butt fusion techniques. 3 Make(s) and model(s) of fusion equipment the technician is certified to join pipe with. 4 Submittals-Approval Not Required 5 Information/Record (IR): 6 Catalog and manufacturer's data sheets for HDPE pipe and fittings. 7 Catalog and manufacturer's data sheets, electrofusion couplers, mechanical cutters, and 8 appurtenances. 9 Part 2 -Products 10 All HDPE pipe and fittings shall conform with additional applicable requirements defined in the Piping 11 Schedule in Section 15060, PIPING-GENERAL. 12 HDPE Pipe 13 Resin: HDPE pipe shall be manufactured from first quality extra-high molecular weight, high density 14 polyethylene resin containing no more than 2 percent clean recycled polymer by weight. Resin shall meet 15 or exceed the requirements of ASTM D3350 for PE3408 material with a cell classification of 345434C or 16 higher. Alternate cell classifications are acceptable if one or more of the 6 numbers in the cell 17 classification is greater than the minimum. Pipe shall be rated PE3408. Pipe and fittings shall be in 18 compliance with schedule attached as supplement (see Attachment 1, HIGH DENSITY 19 POLYETHYLENE (HDPE) PIPE) or as shown on the Drawings. 20 Quality: The pipe shall have uniform wall thickness and shall be uniform in color, opacity, density, and 21 other physical properties. Pipe shall be homogeneous throughout and free of visible cracks, holes, 22 blisters, bubbles, undispersed raw materials, or any contamination by foreign matter. Any pipe with 23 nicks, scrapes, or gouges deeper than 10 percent of the nominal wall thickness shall be rejected. 24 Form: Pipe may be supplied in a continuous extruded seamless piece or in sections. 25 Manufacturer's Certificates of Compliance: 26 The manufacturer shall submit a Certificate of Compliance of the HDPE pipe supplied for the IDF 27 project, which will include that the pipe is grade PE3408 and the identity of the cell classification per 28 ASTM D3350. 29 HDPE pipe SDR shall be as indicated on the Piping Schedule in Section 15060, PIPING-GENERAL. 30 Fittings: 31 Fittings shall conform to the requirements of Article IDPE PIPE of this section, shall be compatible 32 with components of the double containment system, and HDPE manholes where required. 33 Polyethylene fittings shall be from the same manufacturer as the pipe (or approved equal), molded or 34 fabricated from polyethylene pipe and shall have the same or numerically smaller SDR than pipe 35 connecting to the fitting. Fittings shall follow requirements in Attachment 1. 36 All reducing tees shall be factory molded if available as a standard item by any manufacturer having 37 pipe meeting this section. If not available as a standard item, branch saddle reducing tees shall be 38 used. Reducers shall be shop manufactured. Fabricated branch connections will not be allowed if 39 branch saddle connections are listed in the manufacturer's catalog. 40 All molded polyethylene fittings shall have the same or higher pressure rating as the pipe when 41 installed in accordance with the latest technical specifications. All fabricated polyethylene fittings 42 shall have the same or higher pressure rating as the adjoining pipe when installed in accordance with 43 the manufacturer's recommendations. Appendix 4D.270

WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility I Double Containment Pipe 2 Pipe Materials: Both carrier pipe and containment pipe shall meet the requirements of Article HDPE 3 PIPE of this section. 4 Configuration: Double containment pipe shall consist of a carrier pipe installed within a containment 5 pipe. All pipe and fittings shall provide an annular space between the carrier and containment pipes to 6 accommodate possible flow of fluid from the carrier pipe. 7 Support Spacers: Support spacers shall be manufactured from nonmetallic, corrosion-resistant material 8 with the same or better chemical compatibility properties as the HDPE pipe. Spacer intervals and 9 attachment method to the carrier pipe shall be in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations. 10 Spacing shall be reduced if required to maintain the annulus between the carrier and containment pipes 11 and shall be positioned to allow for unrestricted passage of possible flow of fluid from the carrier pipe. 12 Spacers shall be chamfered at both ends to allow for removal of carrier pipe. Materials and systems used 13 to secure the spacers to the pipe shall have the same or better chemical compatibility properties as the 14 HDPE pipe. 15 Fittings: Fittings shall conform to the requirements of Article HDPE PIPE of this section and shall be 16 compatible with components of the single wall HDPE pipe where required (except for trench riser pipes). 17 Slotted Pipe 18 Leachate Collection Piping: Leachate collection and leak detection piping on the floor of the cells and 19 elsewhere as shown on the Drawings shall be slotted. Cleanout access pipes and leachate transmission 20 piping shall not be slotted. 21 In addition to meeting all other requirements of this section, slotted pipe shall have slots 0.128 inch wide 22 and 1.25 inches long, in five places equidistant around the pipe for 12-inch and 18-inch diameter pipes. 23 Slots shall provide a minimum of 9 square inches of open area per linear foot of pipe for 12-inch and 18- 24 inch diameter pipes. For 3-inch diameter slotted pipe, the pipe supplier shall propose a configuration of 25 0.128-inch wide slots that provides a maximum of 7 square inches of open area per linear foot of pipe. 26 Slotted pipes shall be free of cutting debris from the slot cutting process. 27 Perforated pipe with circular drill holes is not allowed. 28 Part 3 -Execution 29 General 30 All HDPE pipe and fittings shall be installed in conformance with applicable code requirements 31 referenced in Section 15060, PIPING-GENERAL. 32 Dimensions 33 Piping dimensions shown on the Drawings are approximate. It is the Construction General 34 Contractor's responsibility to furnish and install piping of the proper dimensions, which will properly 35 fit with the connecting elements, pipes, fittings, pumps, etc. 36 Installation 37 Pipe shall be handled and stored in such a manner as to ensure a sound, undamaged condition. 38 Pipe shall be cut in a neat, workmanlike manner using a mechanical cutter that will not damage the 39 pipe. 40 Joining of HDPE pipe to HDPE pipe shall be accomplished by thermal butt fusion joint; no solvent 41 welding or adhesive welding shall be allowed. Electrofusion couplings shall only be allowed when 42 access to piping is restricted and only as approved by the Engineer. Slotted leachate collection piping 43 shall be joined with thermal butt fusionjoints. Pipe shall be joined per ASTM D2657 and 44 manufacturer's recommendations. Appendix 4D.271

WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 Single butt fusion welds shall be used to create pipe sections as long as practicable. Fabricated pipe 2 sections and fittings may be joined by the double butt fusion process. 3 During installation, the pipe shall not be pulled across sharp projections that could cause gouges, 4 kinks, or other types of damage. To minimize "snaking" due to thermal expansion, protect pipe from 5 direct sunlight, or limit unrestrained length of pipe during installation. 6 Allowance for Thermal Expansion/Contraction: 7 HDPE has a coefficient of thermal expansion of 1.2 x 10-4 ft/ft/deg F. Buried HDPE pipe shall be 8 installed with excess length between anchor points such that contraction caused by temperature drop to 9 40 degrees F will produce the length of pipe between two points shown on the Drawings. Amount of 10 excess pipe depends on temperatures of pipe at the time of installation, according to Table I for buried 11 piping: 12 TABLE 1 Installation Temperature (degrees F) Excess Pipe Length (in./100 ft) 50 1.4 60 2.9 70 4.3 80 5.8 90 7.2 100 8.6 120 11.5 13 Installation temperature is of the pipe material and not ambient air temperature. Measure installation 14 temperature with a strip thermometer laid directly on the pipe. Verify temperate and excess pipe length 15 required immediately before burial. 16 Placement of Buried Pipes: 17 Excavate trench bottom and sides of ample dimensions to permit visual inspection and testing of 18 entire flange, valve, or connection. 19 The pipe shall not be dropped into the trench. Exercise care when lowering pipe into trench to 20 prevent twisting or damage to pipe. The full length of the pipe shall be firmly bedded on the trench 21 bottom. 22 The pipe shall be bedded in such a way as to maintain grade with a tolerance of -0.0 percent, 23 +0.5 percent with a uniform, constant grade and no localized low spots. 24 Pipe Base and Pipe Zone: 25 As specified in Section 02320, TRENCH BACKFILL. 26 Keep trench dry until pipe laying and joining are completed. 27 Prevent foreign material from entering pipe during placement. 28 Close and block open end of last laid pipe section when placement operations are not in progress and 29 at close of day's work. 30 Install closure sections and adapters for gravity piping at locations where pipe laying changes 31 direction. 32 After joint has been made, check pipe alignment and grade. WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 Place sufficient pipe zone material to secure pipe from movement before next joint is installed. 2 Prevent uplift and floating of pipe prior to backfilling. 3 Place pipe along pipe runs starting at one end and moving towards the other to avoid joints that will not 4 be feasible with butt fusion. 5 Tolerances: Horizontal position of pipe centerline on alignment around curves maximum variation of 6 1.0 foot from position shown. 7 Pipe Cover: 8 Minimum 2 feet 6 inches from finished elevation of overlying material, unless otherwise shown. 9 Temporarily close pipe ends as required to avoid introducing dirt or other foreign material into the pipe. 10 Trenching and backfilling operations shall be conducted in accordance with the requirements of 11 Section 02320, TRENCH BACKFILL, for utility trenching. If trenching is used, underlying materials 12 shall not be disturbed or damaged in anyway. Backfilling operations shall ensure that no voids are 13 present under or at the sides of the pipe. Backfill shall initially be placed to the top of the pipe, then hand 14 compacted. The remainder of the trench shall then be backfilled and compacted by hand or with a power 15 tamper only. 16 On the floor of the cell, pipe may be placed directly on geosynthetic layers prior to placing drainage 17 gravel. Placement of gravel around pipes shall be by hand unless otherwise approved by the Engineer. 18 Placement operations shall ensure that no voids are present under or at the sides of the pipe. Placement 19 operations shall not disturb the position of the pipe. 20 Where flanged joints are used, the bolts shall be evenly torqued using a crossing pattern to gradually 21 tighten the lug nuts. Torque values shall be as recommended by the flange manufacturer. Flanged joints 22 shall be retorqued after one hour or more has passed. Apply anti-seize compound on all threaded surfaces 23 before tightening. 24 Flaws (minor imperfections, damaged areas, etc.) in HDPE pipe with a depth of 10 percent or less of the 25 nominal wall thickness will not require repair or replacement. In double containment systems, carrier 26 pipe with flaws deeper than 10 percent of the wall thickness shall be replaced. Single pipe or containment 27 pipe with flaws between 10 and 25 percent of the wall thickness shall be repaired in accordance with the 28 pipe manufacturer's recommendations. The Construction General Contractor shall certify in writing that 29 the repaired area will have material properties that meet or exceed those of intact pipe. Any pipe with 30 flaws deeper than 25 percent of the nominal wall thickness shall be rejected. 31 All valves and equipment shall be supported independently from pipe. Anchor valves such that turning 32 moment resulting from their operation will not be transmitted to pipe. 33 Special Precautions at Flanges: Polyethylene pipe connected to heavy fittings, manholes, and rigid 34 structures shall be supported in such a manner that no subsequent relative movement between 35 polyethylene pipe at flanged joint and rigid structures is possible. 36 Butt-fusion shall be performed in accordance with pipe manufacturer's recommendations as to equipment 37 and technique. 38 Weld Beads: Remove internal weld beads from the side slope risers and horizontal sections of slotted 39 pipe where the LCRS and LDS pumps will be placed and the horizontal and vertical sections of the LCRS 40 level transducer pipe. Remove all plastic debris from inside pipe. 41 Slotted Pipe: Slotted pipe shall be cut and joined so that full contact is made around the entire 42 circumference of the weld. Partial weld contact because ofjoints through a slot row is not acceptable. 43 Locator Ribbon 44 Locator ribbon shall be installed as specified in Section 02320, TRENCH BACKFILL. Appendix 4D.273

WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 SECTION 15022 -HIGH DENSITY POLYETHYLENE MANHOLES SCHED. WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 Limitations: Threaded taps in pipe barrel are unacceptable. 2 Cleaninq 3 Following assembly and testing, and prior to final acceptance, flush pipelines (except as stated below) 4 with water at 2.5 fps minimum flushing velocity until foreign matter is removed. 5 The up-slope riser pipe and slotted pipe shall be cleaned internally after deburring by pulling cotton 6 pillows attached to ropes through pipe repeatedly until no debris comes out of pipe with pillow. 7 Water flushing shall not be permitted. WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility I Test Pressure: 2 Per Section 15060, Piping-General 3 Exposed Piping: 4 Perform testing on installed piping prior to application of insulation. 5 Prior to pressure testing, check all manually operated valves for smooth operation and count and 6 record number of turns to open and close each valve. 7 Maximum Filling Velocity: 0.25 feet per second, applied over full area of pipe. 8 Vent piping during filling. Open vents at high points of piping system or loosen flanges, using at least 9 four bolts, or use equipment vents to purge air pockets. 10 HDPE Piping 11 Test Procedure: The test procedure consists of an initial expansion phase and then the test phase. Prior 12 to the test procedure the test medium and pipe test section shall be allowed time to equalize in 13 temperature. Testing shall not be allowed if temperatures of the test medium or pipe test section exceed 14 100 degrees F. 15 Maintain the test pressure for a period of 3 hours during the initial expansion phase by adding water as 16 needed. 17 At the beginning of the test phase after the initial expansion phase, reduce pressure by 10 psi. Maintain 18 this test pressure for a period of 1 hour. 19 Under no circumstances shall the testing be allowed to exceed 8 hours. 20 Acceptance Criteria: 21 The test phase is passed and the pressure test is acceptable if the pressure remains steady (within 22 5 percent of the test phase beginning pressure) for 1 hour and there are no indications, visible or 23 otherwise, of leakage. 24 If acceptance criteria is not met, any leakage points shall be fixed and any other changes made to the 25 piping system as necessary. Retest and repeat until acceptance criteria is met. 26 Empty pipe of water prior to final cleaning. 27 Buried Piping: Test piping using the same procedure as outlined for exposed piping as described above. 28 PVC and Non-HDPE Piping: 29 Perform testing on installed piping prior to application of insulation. 30 Prior to pressure testing, check all manually operated valves for smooth operation and count and 31 record number of turns to open and close each valve. 32 Maximum Filling Velocity: 33 0.25 foot per second, applied over full area of pipe. 34 Vent piping during filling. Open vents at high points of piping system or loosen flanges, using at 35 least four bolts, or use equipment vents to purge air pockets. 36 Maintain hydrostatic test pressure continuously for 30 minutes, minimum, and for such additional 37 time as necessary to conduct examinations for leakage. No fluid shall be added to the system, and 38 system shall not drop below 95 percent of the test pressure during the test period. 39 Examine exposed joints and connections for leakage. 40 No loss of fluid allowed. Find any leakage points, fix, and retest as specified. 41 Empty pipe of water prior to final cleaning or disinfection. Appendix 4D.306

--- Page 632 ---
WA7890008967 Integrated Disposal Facility 1 Pneumatic Test 2 General: Pneumatic testing shall be performed for outer pipe of double-wall HDPE piping and 3 atmospheric drains. 4 Double-Wall Pipe: Inner carrier pipe shall be full of water when outer containment pipe is tested to 5 prevent damage to carrier pipe and riser pipes. 6 Equipment: 7 Gauges shall be calibrated within manufacturer's recommended frequency and calibration shall be 8 current. 9 Install gauges, air piping manifolds, and valves at ground surface. 10 Provide pressure release device, such as rupture disc or pressure relief valve, to relieve pressure at 11 10 psi or less. 12 Restrain plugs used to close lines to prevent blowoff. 13 Procedure: 14 Maintain test pressure for 10 to 60 minutes but not for more than 60 minutes. 15 Slowly introduce air into pipe section until internal air pressure reaches required test pressure. (A 16 maximum 5% gauge loss is acceptable.) 17 Allow 2 minutes minimum for air temperature to stabilize. 18 Examine exposed joints and connections for leakage using liquid bubble tests or other method to 19 determine source of leakage approved by the construction manager. 20 No loss in pressure allowed. Find any leakage points, fix, and retest as specified. 21 Defective Piping Sections: Replace or test and seal individual joints, and retest as specified. 22 END OF SECTION 15992 Appendix 4D.307
