WA7890008967 LERF and 200 Area ETF 1 C.2.1 Load-in Station 2 The 200 Area ETF receives aqueous waste from LERF or the Load-In Station. The 200 Area ETF 3 Load-In Station, located due east of the surge tank and outside of the perimeter fence (Figure C.4), was 4 designed and constructed to provide the capability to unload, store, and transfer aqueous waste to the 5 LERF or 200 Area ETF from tanker trucks and other containers (such as drums). The Load-In Station 6 consists of two truck bays equipped with load-in tanks, transfer pumps, filtration system, level 7 instrumentation for tanker trucks, leak detection capabilities for the containment basin and transfer line, 8 and an underground transfer line that connects to lines in the surge tank berm, allowing transfers to either 9 the 200 Area ETF surge tank or LERF. The Load-In Station is covered with a steel building for weather 10 protection. Tanker trucks and other containers are used to unload aqueous waste at the Load-In Station. 11 To perform unloading, the tanker truck is positioned on a truck pad, a 'load-in' transfer line is connected 12 to the truck, and the tanker contents are pumped into one of the Load-In Station tanks, the surge tank, or 13 directly to the LERF. For container unloading, the container is placed on the truck pad and the container 14 contents are pumped into one of the Load-In Station tanks, the surge tank, or directly to the LERF. 15 During unloading operations, solids may be removed from the waste by pumping the contents of the 16 tanker truck or container through a filtration system. If solids removal is not needed, the filtration system 17 is not used and the solution is transferred directly to the Load-In Station tanks, surge tank, or to LERF. 18 Any leaks at the Load-In Station drain to the sump. A leak detector in the sump alarms locally and in the 19 200 Area ETF control room. Alarms are monitored continuously in the control room during Load-in 20 Station transfers and at least daily at times when waste is not being received at the Load-In Station. 21 Alternatively, leaks can be visually detected. 22 C.2.2 Effluent Treatment Facility Operating Configuration 23 Because the operating configuration of the 200 Area ETF can be adjusted or modified, most aqueous 24 waste streams can be effectively treated to below Delisting and Discharge Permit limits. The operating 25 configuration of the 200 Area ETF depends on the unique chemistry of an aqueous waste stream(s). 26 Before an aqueous waste stream is accepted for treatment, the waste is characterized and evaluated. 27 Information from the characterization is used to adjust the treatment process or change the configuration 28 of the 200 Area ETF process units, as necessary, to optimize the treatment process for a particular 29 aqueous waste stream. 30 Typically, an aqueous waste is processed first in the primary treatment train, where the 200 Area ETF is 31 configured to process an aqueous waste through the UV/OX unit first, followed by the RO unit. 32 However, under an alternate configuration, an aqueous waste could be processed in the RO unit first. For 33 example, high concentrations of nitrates in an aqueous waste might interfere with the performance of the 34 UV/OX. In this case, the 200 Area ETF could be configured to process the waste in the RO unit before 35 the UV/OX unit. 36 The flexibility of the 200 Area ETF also allows some aqueous waste to be processed in the secondary 37 treatment train first. For example, for small volume aqueous waste with high concentrations of some 38 anions and metals, the approach could be to first process the waste stream in the secondary treatment 39 train. This approach would prevent premature fouling or scaling of the RO unit. The liquid portion (i.e., 40 untreated overheads from the 200 Area ETF evaporator and thin film dryer) would be sent to the primary 41 treatment train. 42 Figure C.5 and Figure C.6 provide example process flow diagrams for two different operating 43 configurations. 44 C.2.3 Primary Treatment Train 45 The primary treatment train consists of the following processes: 46 * Influent Receipt/Surge tank -inlet, surge capacity. 47 * Filtration -for suspended solids removal. Addendum C.8

--- Page 863 ---
WA7890008967 LERF and 200 Area ETF 1 * UV/OX -organic destruction. 2 * pH adjustment -waste neutralization. 3 * Hydrogen peroxide decomposition -removal of excess hydrogen peroxide. 4 * Degasification -removal of carbon dioxide. 5 * RO -removal of dissolved solids. 6 * IX -removal of dissolved solids. 7 * Verification -holding tanks during verification. 8 Influent Receipt/Surge Tank. Depending on the configuration of the ETF, the surge tank is one inlet 9 used to feed an aqueous waste into the 200 Area ETF for treatment. In Configuration 1 (Figure C.5), the 10 surge tank is the first component downstream of the LERF. The surge tank provides a storage/surge 11 volume for chemical pretreatment and controls feed flow rates from the LERF to the 200 Area ETF. 12 However, in Configuration 2 (Figure C.6), aqueous waste from LERF is fed directly into the treatment 13 units. In this configuration, the surge tank receives aqueous waste, which has been processed in the RO 14 units, and provides the feed stream to the remaining downstream process units. In yet another 15 configuration, some small volume aqueous waste could be received into the secondary treatment train 16 first for processing. In this case, the aqueous waste would be received directly into the secondary waste 17 receiving tanks. Finally, the surge tank also receives waste extracted from various systems within the 18 primary and secondary treatment train while in operation. 19 The surge tank is located outside the 200 Area ETF on the south side. In the surge tank (Fiyure C.7), the 20 pH of an aqueous waste is adjusted using the metered addition of sulfuric acid and sodium hydroxide, as 21 necessary, to prepare the waste for treatment in downstream processes. In addition, hydrogen peroxide or 22 biocides could be added to control biological growth in the surge tank. A pump recirculates the contents 23 in the surge tank, mixing the chemical reagents with the waste to a uniform pH. 24 Filtration. Two primary filter systems remove suspended particles in an aqueous waste: a rough filter 25 removes the larger particulates, while a fine filter removes the smaller particulates. The location of these 26 filters depends on the configuration of the primary treatment train. However, the filters normally are 27 located upstream of the RO units. 28 The solids accumulating on these filter elements are backwashed to the secondary waste receiving tanks 29 with pulses of compressed air and water, forcing water back through the filter. The backwash operation is 30 initiated either automatically by a rise in differential pressure across the filter or manually by an operator. 31 The filters are cleaned chemically when the backwashing process does not facilitate acceptable filter 32 performance. 33 Auxiliary fine and rough filters (e.g., disposable filters) have been installed to provide additional filtration 34 capabilities. Depending on the configuration of the ETF, the auxiliary filters are operated either in series 35 with the primary filters to provide additional filtration or in parallel, instead of the primary fine and rough 36 filters, to allow cleaning/maintenance of the primary fine and rough filters while the primary treatment 37 train is in operation. 38 Ultraviolet Light/Oxidation. Organic compounds contained in an aqueous waste stream are destroyed 39 in the UV/OX system (Fiaure C.8). Hydrogen peroxide is mixed with the waste. 40 The UV/OX system uses the photochemical reaction of UV light on hydrogen peroxide to form hydroxyl 41 radicals and other reactive species that oxidize the organic compounds. The final products of the 42 complete reaction are carbon dioxide, water, and inorganic ions. 43 Organic destruction is accomplished in two UV/OX units operating in parallel. During the UV/OX 44 process, the aqueous waste passes through reaction chambers where hydrogen peroxide is added. While 45 in the UV/OX system, the temperature of an aqueous waste is monitored. Heat exchangers are used to 46 reduce the temperature of the waste should the temperature of the waste approach the upper limits for the 47 UV/OX or RO systems. Addendum C.9

--- Page 864 ---
WA7890008967 LERF and 200 Area ETF 1 pH Adjustment. The pH of a waste stream is monitored and controlled at different points throughout the 2 treatment process. Within the primary treatment train, the pH of a waste can be adjusted with sulfuric 3 acid or sodium hydroxide to optimize operation of downstream treatment processes or adjusted before 4 final discharge. For example, the pH of an aqueous waste would be adjusted in the pH adjustment tank 5 after the UV/OX process and before the RO process. In this example, pH is adjusted to cause certain 6 chemical species such as ammonia to form ammonium sulfate, thereby increasing the rejection rate of the 7 RO. 8 Hydrogen Peroxide Decomposition. Typically, hydrogen peroxide added into the UV/OX system is not 9 consumed completely by the system. Because hydrogen peroxide is a strong oxidizer, the residual 10 hydrogen peroxide from the UV/OX system is removed to protect the downstream equipment. The 11 hydrogen peroxide decomposer uses a catalyst to break down the hydrogen peroxide that is not consumed 12 completely in the process of organic destruction. The aqueous waste is sent through a column that breaks 13 down the hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen. The gas generated by the decomposition of the 14 hydrogen peroxide is vented to the vessel off gas system. 15 Degasification. The degasification column is used to purge dissolved carbon dioxide from the aqueous 16 waste to reduce the carbonate loading to downstream dissolved solids removal processes within the 17 200 Area ETF primary treatment train. The purged carbon dioxide is vented to the vessel off gas system. 18 Reverse Osmosis. The RO system (Figure C.9) uses pressure to force clean water molecules through 19 semi-permeable membranes while keeping the larger molecule contaminants, such as dissolved solids, 20 and large molecular weight organic materials, in the membrane. The RO process uses a staged 21 configuration to maximize water recovery. The process produces two separate streams, including a clean 22 'permeate' and a concentrate (or retentate), which are concentrated as much as possible to minimize the 23 amount of secondary waste produced. 24 The RO process is divided into first and second stages. Aqueous waste is fed to the first RO stage from 25 the RO feed tank. The secondary waste receiving tanks of the secondary treatment train receive the 26 retentate removed from the first RO stage, while the second RO stage receives the permeate (i.e., 'treated' 27 aqueous waste from the first RO stage). In the second RO stage, the retentate is sent to the first stage RO 28 feed tank while the permeate is sent to the IX system or to the surge tank, depending on the configuration 29 of the ETF. 30 Two support systems facilitate this process. An anti-scale system injects scale inhibitors as needed into 31 the feed waste to prevent scale from forming on the membrane surface. A clean-in-place system using 32 cleaning agents, such as descalants and surfactants, cleans the membrane pores of surface and subsurface 33 deposits that have fouled the membranes. 34 Ion Exchange. Because the RO process removes most of the dissolved solids in an aqueous waste, the 35 IX process (Figure C.10) acts as a polishing unit. The IX system consists of three columns containing 36 beds of cation and/or anion resins. This system is designed to allow for regeneration of resins and 37 maintenance of one column while the other two are in operation. Though the two columns generally are 38 operated in series, the two columns also can be operated in parallel or individually. 39 Typically, the two columns in operation are arranged in a primary/secondary (lead/lag) configuration, and 40 the third (regenerated) column is maintained in standby. 41 When dissolved solids breakthrough the first IX column and are detected by a conductivity sensor, this 42 column is removed from service for regeneration, and the second column replaces the first column and 43 the third column is placed into service. The column normally is regenerated using sulfuric acid and 44 sodium hydroxide. The resulting regeneration waste is collected in the secondary waste receiving tanks. 45 Spent resins are transferred into a disposal container should regeneration of the IX resins become 46 inefficient Free water is removed from the container and returned to the surge tank. Dewatered resins are 47 transferred to a final storage/disposal point. Addendum C.10

--- Page 865 ---
WA7890008967 LERF and 200 Area ETF I Verification. The three verification tanks (Figure C. 11) are used to hold the treated effluent while a 2 determination is made that the effluent meets discharge limits. The effluent can be returned to the 3 primary treatment train for additional treatment, or to the LERF, should a treated effluent not meet 4 Discharge Permit or Final Delisting requirements. 5 The three verification tanks alternate between three operating modes: receiving treated effluent, holding 6 treated effluent during laboratory analysis and verification, or discharging verified effluent. Treated 7 effluent may also be returned to the 200 Area ETF to provide 'clean' service water for operational and 8 maintenance functions, e.g., for boiler water and for backwashing the filters. This recycling keeps the 9 quantity of fresh water used to a minimum. 10 C.2.4 Secondary Treatment Train 11 The secondary treatment system typically receives and processes the following by-products generated 12 from the primary treatment train: concentrate from the first RO stage, filter backwash, regeneration waste 13 from the ion exchange system, and spillage or overflow received into the process sumps. Depending on 14 the operating configuration, however, some aqueous waste could be processed in the secondary treatment 15 train before the primary treatment train (refer to Figure C.5 and Figure C.6 for example operating 16 configurations). 17 The secondary treatment train provides the following processes: 18 * Secondary waste receiving -tank receiving and chemical addition. 19 * Evaporation -concentrates secondary waste streams. 20 * Concentrate staging -concentrate receipt, pH adjustment, and chemical addition. 21 * Thin film drying -dewatering of secondary waste streams. 22 * Container handling -packaging of dewatered secondary waste. 23 Secondary Waste Receiving. Waste to be processed in the secondary treatment train is received into two 24 secondary waste receiving tanks, where the pH can be adjusted with sulfuric acid or sodium hydroxide for 25 optimum evaporator performance. Chemicals, such as reducing agents, may be added to waste in the 26 secondary waste receiving tanks to reduce the toxicity or mobility of constituents in the powder. 27 Evaporation. The 200 Area ETF evaporator is fed alternately by the two secondary waste receiving 28 tanks. One tank serves as a waste receiver while the other tank is operated as the feed tank. The 29 200 Area ETF evaporator vessel (also referred to as the vapor body) is the principal component of the 30 evaporation process (Figure C.12). 31 Feed from the secondary waste receiving tanks is pumped through a heater to the recirculation loop of the 32 200 Area ETF evaporator. In this loop, concentrated waste is recirculated from the 200 Area ETF 33 evaporator, to a heater, and back into the evaporator where vaporization occurs. As water leaves the 34 evaporator system in the vapor phase, the concentration of the waste in the evaporator increases. When 35 the concentration of the waste reaches the appropriate density, a portion of the concentrate is pumped to 36 one of the concentrate tanks. 37 The vapor that is released from the 200 Area ETF evaporator is routed to the entrainment separator, where 38 water droplets and/or particulates are separated from the vapor. The 'cleaned' vapor is routed to the vapor 39 compressor and converted to steam. 40 The steam from the vapor compressor is sent to the heater (reboiler) and used to heat the recirculating 41 concentrate in the 200 Area ETF evaporator. From the heater, the steam is condensed and fed to the 42 distillate flash tank, where the saturated condensate received from the heater drops to atmospheric 43 pressure and cools to the normal boiling point through partial flashing (rapid vaporization caused by a 44 pressure reduction). The resulting distillate is routed to the surge tank. The non-condensable vapors, 45 such as air, are vented through a vent gas cooler to the vessel off gas system. Addendum C. 11

--- Page 866 ---
WA7890008967 LERF and 200 Area ETF I Concentrate Staging. The concentrate tanks make up the head end of the thin film drying process. From 2 the 200 Area ETF evaporator, concentrate is pumped into two concentrate tanks, and pH adjusted 3 chemicals, such as reducing agents, may be added to reduce the toxicity or mobility of constituents when 4 converted to powder. Waste is transferred from the concentrate tanks to the thin film dryer for conversion 5 to a powder. The concentrate tanks function alternately between concentrate receiver and feed tank for 6 the thin film dryer. However, one tank may serve as both concentrate receiver and feed tank. 7 Because low solubility solids (i.e., calcium and magnesium sulfate) tend to settle in the concentrate tanks, 8 these solids must be removed to prevent fouling and to protect the thin film dryer, and to maintain 9 concentrate tank capacity. 10 Thin Film Drying. From the concentrate tanks, feed is pumped to the thin film dryer (Figure C.13) that 11 is heated by steam. As the concentrated waste flows down the length of the dryer, the waste is dried. The 12 dried film, or powder, is scraped off the dryer cylinder by blades attached to a rotating shaft. The powder 13 is funneled through a cone-shaped powder hopper at the bottom of the dryer and into the Container 14 Handling System. 15 Overhead vapor released by the drying of the concentrate is condensed in the distillate condenser. Excess 16 heat is removed from the distillate by a water-cooled heat exchanger. Part of the distillate is circulated 17 back to the condenser spray nozzles. The remaining distillate is pumped to the surge tank. Any 18 noncondensible vapors and particulates from the spray condenser are exhausted to the vessel off gas 19 system. 20 Container Handling. Before an empty container is moved into the Container Handling System 21 (Figure C.14), the lid is removed and the container is placed on a conveyor. The containers are moved 22 into the container filling area after passing through an air lock. The empty container is located under the 23 thin film dryer, and raised into position. The container is sealed to the thin film dryer and a rotary valve 24 begins the transfer of powder to the empty container. Air displaced from the container is vented to the 25 distillate condenser attached to the 200 Area ETF evaporator that exhausts to the vessel off gas system. 26 The container is filled to a predetermined level, then lowered from the thin film dryer and moved along a 27 conveyor. The filled container is manually recapped, and moved along the conveyor to the airlock. At 28 the airlock, the container is moved onto the conveyor by remote control. The airlock is opened, the smear 29 sample (surface wipe) is taken, and the contamination level counted. A 'C' ring is installed to secure the 30 container lid. If the container has contaminated material on the outside, the container is wiped down and 31 retested. Filled containers that pass the smear test are labeled, placed on pallets, and moved by forklift to 32 the filled container storage area. Section C.3 provides a more detailed discussion of container handling. 33 C.2.5 Other Effluent Treatment Facility Systems 34 The 200 Area ETF is provided with support systems that facilitate treatment in the primary and secondary 35 treatment trains and that provide for worker safety and environmental protection. An overview of the 36 following systems is provided: 37 * Monitor and control system 38 * Vessel off gas system 39 * Sump collection system 40 * Chemical injection feed system 41 * Verification tank recycle system 42 * Utilities 43 C.2.5.1 Monitor and Control System 44 The operation of the 200 Area ETF is monitored and controlled by a centralized computer system 45 (i.e., monitor and control system or MCS). Addendum C.12

WA7890008967 LERF and 200 Area ETF I The MCS continuously monitors data from various field indicators, such as pH, flow, tank level, 2 temperature, pressure, conductivity, alarm status, and valve switch positions. Data gathered by the MCS 3 enable operations and engineering personnel to document and adjust the operation of the ETF. 4 Emergency communications equipment and warning systems (e.g. fire alarms and evacuation alarms) are 5 included in Addendum J, Contingency Plan. These emergency response notification alarms are 6 monitored continuously at central Hanford Facility locations (e.g. Hanford Fire Station) and do not rely 7 on staff being present in the ETF control room for notification and response. 8 C.2.5.2 Vessel Off gas System 9 Ventilation for various tanks and vessels is provided through the vessel off gas system. The system 10 includes a moisture separator, duct heater, pre-filter, high-efficiency particulate air filters, carbon absorber 11 (when required to reduce organic emissions), exhaust fans, and ductwork. Gasses ventilated from the 12 tanks and vessels enter the exhaust system through the connected ductwork. The vessel off gas system 13 draws vapors and gasses off the following tanks and treatment systems: 14 * Surge tank 15 * Vent gas cooler (off the ETF evaporator/distillate flash tank) 16 * pH adjustment tank 17 * Concentrate tanks 18 * Degasification system 19 * First and second RO stages 20 * Dry powder hopper 21 * Effluent pH adjustment tank 22 * Drum capping station 23 * Secondary waste receiving tanks 24 * Distillate condenser (off the thin film dryer) 25 * Sump tanks 1 and 2 26 The vessel off gas system maintains a negative pressure with respect to the atmosphere, which produces a 27 slight vacuum within tanks, vessels, and ancillary equipment for the containment of gas vapor. This 28 system also provides for the collection, monitoring, and treatment of confined airborne in-vessel 29 contaminants to preclude over-pressurization. The high-efficiency particulate air filters remove 30 particulates and condensate from the air stream before these are discharged to the heating, ventilation, and 31 air conditioning system. 32 C.2.5.3 Sump Collection System 33 Sump tanks I and 2 compose the sump collection system that provides containment of waste streams and 34 liquid overflow associated with the 200 Area ETF processes. The process area floor is sloped to two 35 separate trenches that each drain to a sump tank located under the floor of the 200 Area ETF 36 (Figure C.15). One trench runs the length of the primary treatment train and drains to Sump Tank 2, 37 located underneath the verification tank pump floor. The second trench collects spillage primarily from 38 the secondary treatment train and flows to Sump Tank 1, located near the 200 Area ETF evaporator. 39 Sump tanks I and 2 are located below floor level (Figure C. 15). An eductor in these tanks prevents 40 sludge from accumulating. 41 C.2.5.4 Chemical Injection Feed System 42 At several points within the primary and secondary treatment trains, sulfuric acid and sodium hydroxide 43 (or dilute solutions of these reagents) are metered into specific process units to adjust the pH. For 44 example, a dilute solution of 4 percent sulfuric acid and 4 percent sodium hydroxide could be added to 45 the secondary waste receiving tanks to optimize the evaporation process. Miscellaneous 2 waste generated from maintenance and operations activities are stored at the ETF. The waste could 3 include process waste, such as used filter elements; spent RO membranes; damaged equipment, and 4 decontamination and maintenance waste, such as contaminated rags, gloves, and other personal protective 5 equipment. Containers of miscellaneous waste which have free liquids generally are packaged with 6 absorbents. 7 Several container collection areas could be located within the 200 Area ETF process and container 8 handling areas. These collection areas are used only to accumulate waste in containers. Once a container 9 is filled, the container is transferred to a container storage area (Figure C.3 and Figure C.4), to another 10 TSD unit, or to a less-than-90-day storage pad. Containers stored in the additional storage area 11 (Figure C.4) are elevated or otherwise protected from contact with accumulated liquids. The container 12 storage area within 200 Area ETF is a 22.9 x 8.5-meter room located adjacent to the 200 Area ETF 13 process areas. The containers within the container storage area are clearly labeled, and access to these 14 containers is limited by barriers and by administrative controls. The 200 Area ETF floor provides 15 secondary containment, and the 200 Area ETF roof and walls protects all containers from exposure to the 16 elements. 17 Waste also could be placed in containers for treatment as indicated in Addendum A. For example, sludge 18 that accumulates in the bottoms of the process tanks is removed periodically and placed into containers. 19 In this example, the waste is solidified by decanting the supemate from the container and the remainder of 20 the waste is allowed to evaporate, or absorbents are added, as necessary, to address remaining liquids. 21 Following treatment, this waste either is stored at the 200 Area ETF or transferred to another treatment, 22 storage, and disposal (TSD) unit. 23 C.3.1 Description of Containers 24 The containers used to collect and store dry powder waste are 208-liter steel containers. Most of the 25 aqueous waste received at 200 Area ETF, and maintenance and operation waste generated, are stored in 26 208-liter steel or plastic containers; however, in a few cases, the size of the container could vary to 27 accommodate the size of a particular waste. For example, some process waste, such as spent filters, 28 might not fit into a 208-liter container. In the case of spent resin from the IX columns, the resin is 29 dewatered, and could be packaged in a special disposal container. In these few cases, specially sized 30 containers could be required. In all cases, however, only approved containers are used and are compatible 31 with the associated waste. Typically, 208-liter containers are used for treatment. 32 Current operating practices indicate the use of new 208-liter containers that have either a polyethylene 33 liner or a protective coating. Any reused or reconditioned container is inspected for container integrity 34 before use. Overpack containers are available for use with damaged containers. Overpack containers 35 typically are unlined steel or polyethylene. 36 Per Addendum A, a maximum of 147,630 liters of dangerous and/or mixed waste could be stored in 37 containers in the 200 Area ETF. 38 C.3.2 Container Management Practices 39 Before use, each container is checked for signs of damage such as dents, distortion, corrosion, or 40 scratched coating. 41 For dry powder loading, empty containers on pallets are raised by a forklift and manually placed on the 42 conveyor that transports the containers to the automatic filling station in the container handling room 43 (Figure C.14). The container lids are removed and replaced manually following the filling sequence. 44 After filling, containers exit the container handling room via the filled drum conveyor. Locking rings are 45 installed, the container label is affixed, and the container is moved by dolly or forklift to the container 46 storage area. 47 Addendum C.15

When the containers in a collection area are full, the containers are transferred by dolly or forklift 9 to the container storage area or to an appropriate TSD unit. Containers used for treating waste also are 10 labeled. The lids on these containers are removed as required to allow for treatment. During treatment, 11 access to these containers is controlled through physical barriers and/or administrative controls. 12 The filled containers in the container storage area are inventoried, checked for proper labeling, and placed 13 on pallets or in a separate containment device as necessary. Each pallet is moved by forklift. Within the 14 container storage area, palletized containers are stacked no more than three pallets high and in rows no 15 more than two containers wide. Unobstructed aisles with a minimum of 76-centimeter aisle space 16 separate rows. 17 C.3.3 Container Labeling 18 Labels are affixed on containers used to store dry powder when the containers leave the container 19 handling room. Labels are affixed on other waste containers before use. Every container is labeled with 20 the date that the container was filled. Appropriate major risk labels, such as "corrosive", "toxic", or 21 "F-listed", also are added. Each container also has a label with an identification number for tracking 22 purposes. 23 C.3.4 Containment Requirements for Managing Containers 24 Secondary containment is provided in the container management areas within the ETF. The secondary 25 containment provided for tank systems also serves the container management areas. This section 26 describes the design and operation of the secondary containment structure for these areas. 27 C.3.4.1 Secondary Containment System Design 28 For the container management areas, the reinforced concrete floor and a 15.2-centimeter rise (berm) along 29 the walls of the container storage area of the 200 Area ETF provides secondary containment. The 30 engineering assessment required for tanks (Mausshardt 1995) also describes the design and construction 31 of the secondary containment provided for the 200 Area ETF container management areas. All systems 32 were designed to national codes and standards (e.g., American Society for Testing Materials, American 33 Concrete Institute standards). 34 The floor is composed of cast-in-place, pre-formed concrete slabs, and has a minimum thickness of 15.2 35 centimeters. All slab joints and floor and wall joints have water stops installed at the mid-depth of the 36 slab. In addition, filler was applied to each joint. The floor and berms are coated with a chemically 37 resistant; high-solids epoxy coating system consisting of primer and top coating. This coating material is 38 compatible with the waste managed in containers and is an integral part of the secondary containment 39 system for containers. 40 The floor is sloped to drain any solution in the container storage area to floor drains along the west wall. 41 Each floor drain consists of a grating over a 20.3-centimeter diameter drain port connected to a 4-inch 42 polyvinyl chloride transfer pipe. The pipe passes under this wall and connects to a trench running along 43 the east wall of the adjacent process area. This trench drains solution to sump tank 1. 44 The container storage area is separated from the process area by a common wall and a door for access to 45 the two areas (Figure C.3). These two areas also share a common floor and trenches that, with the 46 15.2-centimeter rise of the containing walls, form the secondary containment system for the process area 47 and the container storage area. Where appropriate, absorbents are added to fix any trace liquids 10 present. Large volumes of liquid are not stored in the container storage area. However, liquids might be 11 present in those containers that are in the treatment process. The maximum volume of waste that can be 12 stored in containers in the container storage area is 147,630 liters. 13 Because they are interconnected by floor drains, both the process area and the container storage area are 14 considered in the containment system capacity. The volume available for secondary containment in the 15 process area is approximately 68,000 liters, as discussed in the engineering assessment (Mausshardt 16 1995). Using the dimensions of the container storage area (23.6 by 8.5 by 0.2 meters), and assuming that 17 50 percent of the floor area is occupied by containers, the volume of the container storage area is 18 15,300 liters. The Truck Bay loading areas (see Figure C.4) also provides 10,500 liters of containment as 19 it is connected to the other two areas. The combined volume of the Truck Bay loading areas and process 20 area, and container handling area available for secondary containment, is 93,800 liters. The sump tanks are equipped with alarms that notify operating personnel 29 that a leak is occurring. The sump tanks also are equipped with pumps to transfer waste to the surge tank 30 or the secondary treatment train. 31 C.3.4.6 Prevention of Ignitable, Reactive, and Incompatible Wastes in Containers 32 Individual waste types (i.e., ignitable, corrosive, and reactive) are stored in separate containers. A waste 33 that could be incompatible with other wastes is separated and protected from the incompatible waste. 34 Incompatible wastes are evaluated using the methodology documented in 40 CFR 264, Appendix V. For 35 example, acidic and caustic wastes are stored in separate containers. Free liquids are absorbed in 36 miscellaneous waste containers that hold incompatible waste. Additionally, ETF-specific packaging 37 requirements for these types of waste provide extra containment with each individual container. For 38 example, each item of acidic waste is individually bagged and sealed within a lined container. 39 C.4 Tank Systems 40 This section provides specific information on tank systems and process units. For the load-in tanks, a similar 19 integrity assessment was performed (KEH 1995 and HNF 2009a). Specifically, the assessment 20 documents the following considerations: 21 * Adequacy of the standards used during design and construction of the facility. 22 * Characteristics of the solution in each tank. 23 * Adequacy of the materials of construction to provide corrosion protection from the solution in 24 each tank. 25 * Results of the leak tests and visual inspections. 26 The results of these assessments demonstrate that tanks and ancillary equipment have sufficient structural 27 integrity and are acceptable for storing and treating dangerous and/or mixed waste. The assessments also 28 state that the tanks and building were designed and constructed to withstand a design-basis earthquake. 29 Independent, qualified registered professional engineers certified these tank assessments. 30 The scope of the 200 Area ETF tank integrity assessment was based on characterization data from process 31 condensate. To assess the effect that other aqueous waste might have on the integrity of the 200 Area 32 ETF tanks, the chemistry of an aqueous waste will be evaluated for its potential to corrode a tank 33 (e.g., chloride concentrations will be evaluated). The tank integrity assessment for the load-in tanks was 34 based on characterization data from several aqueous waste streams. The chemistry of an aqueous waste 35 stream not considered in the load-in tank integrity assessment also will be evaluated for the potential to 36 corrode a load-in tank. 37 Consistent with the recommendations of the integrity assessment, a corrosion inspection program was 38 developed. Periodic integrity assessments are scheduled for those tanks predicted to have the highest 39 potential for corrosion. These inspections are scheduled annually or longer, based on age of the tank 40 system, materials of construction, characteristics of the waste, operating experience, and 41 recommendations of the initial integrity assessment. These 'indicator tanks' include the concentrate 42 tanks, secondary waste receiving tanks, and verification tanks. One of each of these tanks will be 43 inspected yearly to determine if corrosion or coating failure has occurred. Should significant corrosion or 44 coating failure be found, an additional tank of the same type would be inspected during the same year. 45 Addendum C.22

--- Page 877 ---

The epoxy 21 coating is considered integral to the secondary containment system for the tanks and ancillary equipment. 22 The concrete containment systems are maintained such that any cracks, gaps, holes, and other 23 imperfections are repaired in a timely manner. Thus, the concrete containment systems do not allow 24 spilled liquid to reach soil or groundwater. There are a number of personnel doorways and vehicle access 25 points into the 200 Area ETF process areas. Releases of any spilled or leaked material to the environment 26 from these access points are prevented by 15.2-centimeter concrete curbs, sloped areas of the floor 27 (e.g., truck ramp), or trenches. 28 Containment Capacity and Maintenance. Each of these containment areas is designed to contain more 29 than 100 percent of the volume of the largest tank in each respective system. Secondary containment 30 systems for the surge tank, and the verification tanks, which are outside the ETF, also are large enough to 31 include the additional volume from a 25-year, 24-hour storm event; i.e., 5.3 centimeters of precipitation. 32 Sprinkler System. WA7890008967 LERF and 200 Area ETF 1 C.4.3.1.2 Specific Containment Systems 2 The following discussion presents a description of the individual containment systems associated with 3 specific tank systems. 4 Load-In Tank Secondary Containment. The load-in tanks 59A-TK-109 and -117 are mounted on a 5 46-centimeter-thick reinforced concrete slab (Drawing H-2-817970). Secondary containment is provided 6 by a pit with 30.5-centimeter-thick walls and a floor constructed of reinforced concrete. The load-in tank 7 pit is sloped to drain solution to a sump. The depth of the pit varies with the slope of the floor, with an 8 average thickness of about 1.1 meters. The volume of the secondary containment is about 73,000 liters, 9 which is capable of containing the volume of at least one load-in tank (i.e., 34,200 liters). Leaks are 10 detected by a leak detector that alarms locally, in the 200 Area ETF control room, and by visual 11 inspection of the secondary containment. Alarms are monitored continuously in the ETF control room 12 during Load-in Station transfers and at least daily when there are no Load-in Station transfers occurring. 13 Adjacent to the pit is a 25.4-centimeter-thick reinforced concrete pad that serves as secondary 14 containment for the load-in tanker trucks, containers, transfer pumps, and filter system that serve as the 15 first tanker truck unloading bay. The pad is inside the metal Load-in building and is 15.2 centimeters 16 below grade with north and south walls gently sloped to allow truck access. The pad has a 3-inch drain 17 pipe to route waste solution to the adjacent load-in tank pit. Based on characterization data, the waste stream is evaluated to 10 determine if the stream is acceptable for treatment or storage. Specific tank management practices are 11 discussed in the following sections. 12 C.4.4.1.1 Rupture, Leakage, Corrosion Prevention 13 Most aqueous waste streams can be managed such that corrosion would not be a concern. For example, 14 an aqueous waste stream with high concentrations of chloride might cause corrosion problems when 15 concentrated in the secondary treatment train. One approach is to adjust the corrosion control measures in 16 the secondary treatment train. An alternative might be to blend this aqueous waste in a LERF basin with 17 another aqueous waste that has sufficient dissolved solids, such that the concentration of the chlorides in 18 the secondary treatment train would not pose a corrosion concern. 19 Additionally, the materials of construction used in the tanks systems (Table C.5) make it unlikely that an 20 aqueous waste would corrode a tank. For more information on corrosion prevention, refer to 21 Addendum B, Waste Analysis Plan. 22 If operating experience suggests that most aqueous waste streams can be managed such that corrosion 23 would not be a concern, operating practices and integrity assessment schedules and requirements will be 24 reviewed and modified as appropriate. 25 When a leak in a tank system is discovered, the leak is immediately contained or stopped by isolating the 26 leaking component. Following containment, the requirements of WAC 173-303-640(7), incorporated by 27 reference, are followed. These requirements include repair or closure of the tank/tank system component, 28 and certification of any major repairs. 29 C.4.4.2 Overfilling Prevention 30 Operating practices and administrative controls used at the 200 Area ETF to prevent overfilling a tank are 31 discussed in the following paragraphs. The 200 Area ETF process is controlled by the MCS. The MCS 32 monitors liquid levels in the 200 Area ETF tanks and has alarms that annunciate on high-liquid level to 33 notify operators that actions must be taken to prevent overfilling of these vessels. As an additional 34 precaution to prevent spills, many tanks are equipped with overflow lines that route solutions to sump 35 tanks I and 2. These tanks include the pH adjustment tank; RO feed tanks, effluent pH adjustment tank, 36 secondary waste receiving tanks, and concentrate tanks. 37 The following section discusses feed systems, safety cutoff devices, bypass systems, and pressure 38 controls for specific tanks and process systems. 39 Tanks. All tanks are equipped with liquid level sensors that give a reading of the tank liquid volume. All 40 of the tanks are equipped further with liquid level alarms that are actuated if the liquid volume is near the 41 tank overflow capacity. In the actuation of the surge tank alarm, a liquid level switch trips, sending a 42 signal to the valve actuator on the tank influent lines, and causing the influent valves to close. 43 The operating mode for each verification tank, i.e., receiving, holding, or discharging, can be designated 44 through the MCS; modes also switch automatically. When the high-level set point on the receiving 45 verification tank is reached, the flow to this tank is diverted and another tank becomes the receiver. The 46 full tank is switched into verification mode. The third tank is reserved for discharge mode. Addendum C.28

--- Page 883 ---
WA7890008967 LERF and 200 Area ETF 1 The liquid levels in the pH adjustment, first and second RO feed, and effluent pH adjustment tanks are 2 maintained within predetermined operating ranges. Should any of these tanks overflow, the excess waste 3 is piped along with any leakage from the feed pumps to a sump tank. 4 When waste in a secondary waste-receiving tank reaches the high-level set point, the influent flow of 5 waste is redirected to the second tank. In a similar fashion, the concentrate tanks switch receipt modes 6 when the high-level set point of one tank is reached. 7 Filter Systems. All filters at 200 Area ETF (i.e., the Load-In Station, rough, fine, and auxiliary filter 8 systems) are in leak-tight steel casings. For the rough and fine filters, a high differential pressure, which 9 could damage the filter element, activates a valve that shuts off liquid flow to protect the filter element 10 from possible damage. To prevent a high-pressure situation, the filters are cleaned routinely with pulses 11 of compressed air that force water back through the filter. Cleaning is terminated automatically by 12 shutting off the compressed air supply if high pressure develops. The differential pressure across the 13 auxiliary filters also is monitored. A high differential pressure in these filters would result in a system 14 shutdown to allow the filters to be changed out. 15 The Load-In Station filtration system has pressure gauges for monitoring the differential pressure across 16 each filter. A high differential pressure would result in discontinuing filter operation until the filter is 17 replaced. 18 Ultraviolet Light/Oxidation System and Decomposers. A rupture disk on the inlet piping to each of 19 the UV/OX reaction vessels relieves to the pH adjustment tank in the event of excessive pressure 20 developing in the piping system. Should the rupture disk fail, the aqueous waste would trip the moisture 21 sensor, shut down the UV lamps, and close the surge tank feed valve. Also provided is a level sensor to 22 protect UV lamps against the risk of exposure to air. Should those sensors be actuated, the UV lamps 23 would be shut down immediately. 24 The piping and valving for the hydrogen peroxide decomposers are configured to split the waste flow: 25 half flows to one decomposer and half flows to the other decomposer. Alternatively, the total flow of 26 waste can be treated in one decomposer or both decomposers can be bypassed. A safety relief valve on 27 each decomposer vessel can relieve excess system pressure to a sump tank. 28 Degasification System. The degasification column is typically supplied aqueous waste feed by the pH 29 adjustment tank feed pump. This pump transfers waste solution through the hydrogen peroxide 30 decomposer, the fine filter, and the degasification column to the first RO feed tank. 31 The degasification column is designed for operation at a partial vacuum. A pressure sensor in the outlet 32 of the column detects the column pressure. The vacuum in the degasification column is maintained by a 33 blower connected to the vessel off gas system. The column is protected from extremely low pressure 34 developed by the column blower by the use of an intake vent that is maintained in the open position 35 during operation. The column liquid level is regulated by a flow control system with a high- and low- 36 level alarm. Plate-type heat exchanger cools the waste solution fed to the degasification column. 37 Reverse Osmosis System. The flow through the first and second RO stages is controlled to maintain 38 constant liquid levels in the first and second stage RO feed tanks. 39 Polisher. Typically, two of the three columns are in operation (lead/lag) and the third (regenerated) 40 column is in standby. When the capacity of the resin in the first column is exceeded, as detected by an 41 increase in the conductivity of the column effluent, the third column, containing freshly regenerated IX 42 resin, is brought online. The first column is taken offline, and the waste is rerouted to the second column, 43 and to the third. Liquid level instrumentation and automatically operated valves are provided in the IX 44 system to prevent overfilling. 45 Effluent Treatment Facility Evaporator. Liquid level instrumentation in the secondary waste receiving 46 tanks is designed to preclude a tank overflow. A liquid level switch actuated by a high-tank liquid level 47 causes the valves to reposition, closing off flow to the secondary waste receiving tanks. Secondary 48 containment for these tanks routes liquids to a sump tank. Addendum C.29

Those tanks that 14 store or treat dangerous waste at the 200 Area ETF (Section C.4. 1.1) are identified with a label, which 15 reads PROCESS WATER/WASTE. The labels are legible at a distance of at least fifty feet or as 16 appropriate for legibility within the ETF. Additionally, these tanks bear a legend that identifies the waste 17 in a manner, which adequately warns employees, emergency personnel, and the public of the major risk(s) 18 associated with the waste being stored or treated in the tank system(s). 19 Caution plates are used to show possible hazards and warn that precautions are necessary. Caution signs 20 have a yellow background and black panel with yellow letters and bear the word CA UTION. Danger 21 signs show immediate danger and signify that special precautions are necessary. These signs are red, 22 black, and white and bear the word DANGER. 23 Tanks and vessels containing corrosive chemicals are posted with black and white signs bearing the word 24 CORROSIVE. DANGER -UNAUTHORIZED PERSONNEL KEEP OUT signs are posted on all exterior 25 doors of the ETF, and on each interior door leading into the process area. Tank ancillary piping is also 26 labeled PROCESS WATER or PROCESS LIQUID to alert personnel which pipes in the process area 27 contains dangerous and/or mixed waste. 28 All tank systems holding dangerous waste are marked with labels or signs to identify the waste contained 29 in the tanks. The labels or signs are legible at a distance of at least 50-feet and bear a legend that 30 identifies the waste in a manner that adequately warns employees, emergency response personnel, and the 31 public, of the major risk(s) associated with the waste being stored or treated in the tank system(s). 32 C.4.6 Air Emissions 33 Tank systems that contain extremely hazardous waste that is acutely toxic by inhalation must be designed 34 to prevent the escape of such vapors. To date, no extremely hazardous waste has been managed in 35 200 Area ETF tanks and is not anticipated. However, the 200 Area ETF tanks have forced ventilation that 36 draws air from the tank vapor spaces to prevent exposure of operating personnel to any toxic vapors that 37 might be present. The vapor passes through a charcoal filter and two sets of high-efficiency particulate 38 air filters before discharge to the environment. The Load-in tanks and verification tanks are vented to the 39 atmosphere. 40 C.4.7 Management of Ignitable or Reactive Wastes in Tanks Systems 41 Although the 200 Area ETF is permitted to accept waste that is designated ignitable or reactive, such 42 waste would be treated or blended immediately after placement in the tank system so that the resulting 43 waste mixture is no longer ignitable or reactive. Aqueous waste received does not meet the definition of a 44 combustible or flammable liquid given in National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) code number 45 30 (NFPA 1996). 46 Addendum C.30

The maximum capacity of each basin is 34 million liters. The dimensions of 14 each basin at the anchor wall are approximately 103 meters by 85 meters. The typical top dimensions of 15 the wetted area are approximately 89 meters by 71 meters, while the bottom dimensions are 16 approximately 57 by 38 meters. Total depth from the top of the dike to the bottom of the basin is 17 approximately 7 meters. The typical finished basin bottoms lie at about 4 meters below the initial grade 18 and 175 meters above sea level. The dikes separating the basins have a typical height of 3 meters and 19 typical top width of 11.6 meters around the perimeter of the impoundments. 20 C.5.1 List of Dangerous Waste 21 A list of dangerous and/or mixed aqueous waste that can be stored in LERF is presented in Addendum A. 22 Addendum B, Waste Analysis Plan also provides a discussion of the types of waste that are managed in 23 the LERF. 24 C.5.2 Construction, Operation, and Maintenance of Liner System 25 General information concerning the liner system is presented in the following sections. Information 26 regarding loads on the liner, liner coverage, UV light exposure prevention, and location relative to the 27 water table are discussed. 28 C.5.2.1 Liner Construction Materials 29 The LERF employs a double-composite liner system with a leachate detection, collection, and removal 30 system between the primary and secondary liners. Each basin is constructed with an upper or primary 31 liner consisting of a high-density polyethylene geomembrane laid over a bentonite carpet liner. The lower 32 or secondary liner in each basin is a composite of a geomembrane laid over a layer of soil/bentonite 33 admixture with a hydraulic conductivity less than 10' centimeters per second. The synthetic liners extend 34 up the dike wall to a concrete anchor wall that surrounds the basin at the top of the dike. A batten system 35 bolts the layers in place to the anchor wall (Figure C.16). 36 Figure C.17 is a schematic cross-section of the liner system. The liner components, listed from the top to 37 the bottom of the liner system, are the following: 38 * Primary 1.5-millimeter high-density polyethylene geomembrane 39 * Bentonite carpet liner 40 * Geotextile 41 * Drainage gravel (bottom) and geonet (sides) 42 * Geotextile 43 * Secondary 1.5-millimeter high-density polyethylene geomembrane 44 * Soil/bentonite admixture (91 centimeters on the bottom, 107 centimeters on the sides) Addendum C.31

--- Page 886 ---
WA7890008967 LERF and 200 Area ETF * Geotextile 2 The primary geomembrane, made of 1.5-millimeter high-density polyethylene, forms the basin surface 3 that holds the aqueous waste. The secondary geomembrane, also 1.5-millimeter high-density 4 polyethylene, forms a barrier surface for leachate that might penetrate the primary liner. The high-density 5 polyethylene chemically is resistant to constituents in the aqueous waste and has a relatively high strength 6 compared to other lining materials. The high-density polyethylene resin specified for the LERF contains 7 carbon black, antioxidants, and heat stabilizers to enhance its resistance to the degrading effects of UV 8 light. The approach to ensuring the compatibility of aqueous waste streams with the LERF liner materials 9 and piping is discussed in Addendum B, Waste Analysis Plan. 10 Three geotextile layers are used in the LERF liner system. The layers are thin, nonwoven polypropylene 11 fabric that chemically is resistant, highly permeable, and resistant to microbiological growth. The first 12 two layers prevent fine soil particles from infiltrating and clogging the drainage layer. The second 13 geotextile also provides limited protection for the secondary geomembrane from the drainage rock. The 14 third geotextile layer prevents the mixing of the soil/bentonite admixture with the much more porous and 15 granular foundation material. 16 A 30.5-centimeters-thick gravel drainage layer on the bottom of the basins between the primary and 17 secondary liners provides a flow path for liquid to the leachate detection, collection, and removal system. 18 A geonet (or drainage net) is located immediately above the secondary geomembrane on the basin 19 sidewalls. The geonet functions as a preferential flow path for liquid between the liners, carrying liquid 20 down to the gravel drainage layer and subsequently to the leachate sump. The geonet is a mesh made of 21 high-density polyethylene, with approximately 13-millimeter openings. 22 The soil/bentonite layer is 91 centimeters thick on the bottom of the basins and 107 centimeters thick on 23 the basin sidewalls; its permeability is less than 10-7 centimeters per second. This composite liner design, 24 consisting of a geomembrane laid over essentially impermeable soil/bentonite, is considered best 25 available technology for solid waste landfills and surface impoundments. The combination of synthetic 26 and clay liners is reported in the literature to provide the maximum protection from waste migration 27 (Forseth and Kmet 1983). 28 A number of laboratory tests were conducted to measure the engineering properties of the soil/bentonite 29 admixture, in addition to extensive field tests performed on three test fills constructed near the LERF site. 30 For establishing an optimum ratio of bentonite to soil for the soil/bentonite admixture, mixtures of various 31 ratios were tested to determine permeability and shear strength. A mixture of 12 percent bentonite was 32 selected for the soil/bentonite liner and tests described in the following paragraphs demonstrated that the 33 admixture meets the desired permeability of less than 10-7 centimeters per second. Detailed discussion of 34 test procedures and results is provided in Report of Geotechnical Investigation, 242-A Evaporation and 35 PUREX Interim Storage Basins (Chen-Northem 1990). 36 Direct shear tests were performed according to ASTM D3080 test procedures (ASTM 1990) on 37 soil/bentonite samples of various ratios. Based on these results, the conservative minimum Mohr- 38 Coulomb shear strength value of 30 degrees was estimated for a soil/bentonite admixture containing 39 12 percent bentonite. 40 The high degree of compaction of the soil/bentonite layer [92 percent per ASTM Dl 557 (ASTM 1991)] 41 was expected to maximize the bonding forces between the clay particles, thereby minimizing moisture 42 transport through the liner. With respect to particle movement ('piping'), estimated fluid velocities in this 43 low-permeability material are too low to move the soil particles. Therefore, piping is not considered a 44 problem. 45 For the soil/bentonite layer, three test fills were constructed to demonstrate that materials, methods, and 46 procedures used would produce a soil/bentonite liner that meets the EPA permeability requirement of less 47 than 10' centimeters per second. All test fills met the EPA requirements. 48 Addendum C.32

--- Page 887 ---
WA7890008967 LERF and 200 Area ETF 1 A thorough discussion of construction procedures, testing, and results is provided in Report of 2 Permeability Testing, Soil-bentonite Test Fill (Chen-Northern 1991 a). 3 The aqueous waste stored in the LERF is typically a dilute mixture of organic and inorganic constituents. 4 Though isolated instances of soil liner incompatibility have been documented in the literature (Forseth 5 and Kmet 1983), these instances have occurred with concentrated solutions that were incompatible with 6 the geomembrane liners in which the solutions were contained. Key physical properties include thickness (1.5 millimeters 21 [60 mil]) and impermeability (hydrostatic resistance of over 360,000 kilogram per square meter). 22 Physical properties meet National Sanitation Foundation Standard 54 (NSF 1985). Testing to determine 23 if the liner material is compatible with typical dilute waste solutions was performed and documented in 24 9090 Test Results (WHC 1991). 25 Soil/Bentonite Liner. The soil/bentonite admixture consists of 11.5 to 14.5 percent bentonite mixed into 26 well-graded silty sand with a maximum particle size of 4.75 millimeters (No. 4 sieve). Test fills were 27 performed to confirm the soil/bentonite admixture applied at LERF has hydraulic conductivity less than 28 10' centimeters per second, as required by WAC 173-303-650(2)() for new surface impoundments. 29 Bentonite Carpet Liner. The bentonite carpet liner consists of bentonite (90 percent sodium 30 montmorillonite clay) in a primary backing of woven polypropylene with nylon filler fiber, and a cover 31 fabric of open weave spunlace polyester. The montmorillonite is anticipated to retard migration of 32 solution through the liner, exhibiting a favorable cation exchange for adsorption of some constituents 33 (such as ammonium). Based on composition of the bentonite carpet and of the type of aqueous waste 34 stored at LERF, no chemical attack, dissolution, or degradation of the bentonite carpet liner is anticipated. 35 Geotextile. The nonwoven geotextile layers consist of long-chain polypropylene polymers containing 36 stabilizers and inhibitors to make the filaments resistant to deterioration from UV light and heat exposure. 37 The geotextile layers consist of continuous geotextile sheets held together by needle punching. Edges of 38 the fabric are sealed or otherwise finished to prevent outer material from pulling away from the fabric or 39 raveling. 40 Drainage Gravel. The drainage layer consists of thoroughly washed and screened, naturally occurring 41 rock meeting the size specifications for Grading Number 5 in Washington State Department of 42 Transportation construction specifications (WSDOT 1988). The specifications for the drainage layer are 43 given in Table C.10. Hydraulic conductivity tests (Chen-Northern 1992a, 1992b, 1992c) showed the 44 drainage rock used at LERF met the sieve requirements and had a hydraulic conductivity of at least 45 1 centimeter per second, which exceeded the minimum of at least 0.1 centimeters per second required by 46 WAC 173-303-650(2)(j) for new surface impoundments. 47 Addendum C.33

Contractors were required to submit 32 construction quality control plans that included procedures, techniques, tools, and equipment used for the 33 construction and care of liner and leachate system. Methods for installation of all components were 34 screened to ensure that the stresses on the liner system were kept to a minimum. 35 Calculations were performed to estimate the risk of damage to the secondary high-density polyethylene 36 liner during construction (Calculations for LERF Part B Permit Application [HNF 1997]). The greatest 37 risk expected was from spreading the gravel layer over the geotextile layer and secondary geomembrane. 38 The results of the calculations show that the strength of the geotextile was sufficiently high to withstand 39 the stress of a small gravel spreader driving on a minimum of 15 centimeters of gravel over the geotextile 40 and geomembrane. The likelihood of damage to the geomembrane lying under the geotextile was 41 considered low. 42 To avoid driving heavy machinery directly on the secondary liner, a 28-meter conveyer was used to 43 deliver the drainage gravel into the basins. The gravel was spread and consolidated by hand tools and a 44 bulldozer. The bulldozer traveled on a minimum thickness of 30.5 centimeters of gravel. Addendum C.34

Static load on the primary liner is 22 roughly 6,400 kilograms per square meter. Load on the secondary liner is slightly higher because of the 23 weight of the gravel drainage layer. Assuming a density of 805 kilograms per square meter for the 24 drainage gravel [conservative estimate based on specific gravity of 2.65 (Ambrose 1988)], the secondary 25 high-density polyethylene liner carries approximately 7,200 kilograms per square meter when a basin is 26 full. 27 Side slope liner stresses were calculated for each of the layers in the basin sidewalls and for the pipe 28 trench on the northwest corner of each basin (HNF 1997). Results of these calculations indicate factors of 29 safety against shear were 1.5 or greater for the primary geomembrane, geotextile, geonet, and secondary 30 geomembrane. 31 Because the LERF is not located in an area of seismic concern, as identified in Appendix VI of 32 40 CFR 264 and WAC 173-303-282(6)(a)(I), discussion and calculation of potential seismic events are 33 not required. 34 C.5.2.1.4 Stresses Resulting from Settlement, Subsidence, or Uplift 35 Uplift stresses from natural sources are expected to have negligible impact on the liner. Groundwater lies 36 approximately 62 meters below the LERF, average annual precipitation is only 16 centimeters, and the 37 average unsaturated permeability of the soils near the basin bottoms is high, ranging from about 38 5.5 x 104 centimeters per second to about I centimeter per second (Chen-Northern 199 1b). Therefore, no 39 hydrostatic uplift forces are expected to develop in the soil underneath the basins. In addition, the soil 40 under the basins consists primarily of gravel and sand, and contains few or no organic constituents. 41 Therefore, uplift caused by gas production from organic degradation is not anticipated. 42 Based on the design of the soil-bentonite liner, no structural uplift stresses are present within the lining 43 system (Chen-Northern 199 1b). 44 Regional subsidence is not anticipated because neither petroleum nor extractable economic minerals are 45 present in the strata underlying the LERF basins, nor is karst (erosive limestone) topography present. 46 Addendum C.35

--- Page 890 ---
WA7890008967 LERF and 200 Area ETF 1 Dike soils and soil/bentonite layers were compacted thoroughly and proof-rolled during construction. 2 Calculation of settlement potential showed that combined settlement for the foundation and soil/bentonite 3 layer is expected to be about 2.7 centimeters. Settlement impact on the liner and basin stability is 4 expected to be minimal (Chen-Northem 199 1b). 5 C.5.2.1.5 Internal and External Pressure Gradients 6 Pressure gradients across the liner system from groundwater are anticipated to be negligible. The LERF 7 is about 62 meters above the seasonal high water table, which prevents buildup of water pressure below 8 the liner. The native gravel foundation materials of the LERF are relatively permeable and free draining. 9 The 2 percent slope of the secondary liner prevents the pooling of liquids on top of the secondary liner. 10 Finally, the fill rate of the basins is slow enough (average 190 liters per minute) that the load of the liquid 11 waste on the primary liner is gradually and evenly distributed. 12 To prevent the buildup of gas between the liners, each basin is equipped with 21 vents in the primary 13 geomembrane located above the maximum water level that allow the reduction of any excess gas 14 pressure. Gas passing through these vents exit through a single pipe that penetrates the anchor wall into a 15 carbon adsorption filter. This filter extracts nearly all of the organic compounds, ensuring that emissions 16 to the air from the basins are not toxic. 17 C.5.2.2 Liner System Location Relative to High-Water Table 18 The lowest point of each LERF basin is the northwest corner of the sump, where the typical subgrade 19 elevation is 175 meters above mean sea level. Based on data collected from the groundwater monitoring 20 wells at the LERF site, the seasonal high-water table is located approximately 62 meters or more below 21 the lowest point of the basins. This substantial thickness of unsaturated strata beneath the LERF provides 22 ample protection to the liner from hydrostatic pressure because of groundwater intrusion into the 23 soil/bentonite layer. Further discussion of the unsaturated zone and site hydrogeology is provided in 24 Addendum D, Groundwater Monitoring Plan. 25 C.5.2.3 Liner System Foundation 26 Foundation materials are primarily gravels and cobbles with some sand and silt. The native soils onsite 27 are derived from unconsolidated Holocene sediments. These sediments are fluvial and glaciofluvial sands 28 and gravels deposited during the most recent glacial and postglacial event. Grain-size distributions and 29 shape analyses of the sediments indicate that deposition occurred in a high-energy environment (Chen- 30 Northern 1990). 31 Analysis of five soil borings from the LERF site was conducted to characterize the natural foundation 32 materials and to determine the suitability of onsite soils for construction of the impoundment dikes and 33 determine optimal design factors. Well-graded gravel containing varying amounts of silt, sand, and 34 cobbles comprises the layer in which the basins were excavated. This gravel layer extends to depths of 35 10 to 11 meters below land surface (Chen-Northern 1990). The basins are constructed directly on the 36 subgrade. Excavated soils were screened to remove oversize cobbles (greater than 15 centimeters in the 37 largest dimension) and used to construct the dikes. 38 Settlement potential of the foundation material and soil/bentonite layer was found to be low. The 39 foundation is comprised of undisturbed native soils. The bottom of the basin excavation lies within the 40 well-graded gravel layer, and is dense to very dense. Below the gravel is a layer of dense to very dense 41 poorly graded and well-graded sand. Settlement was calculated for the gravel foundation soils and for the 42 soil/bentonite layer, under the condition of hydrostatic loading from 6.4 meters of fluid depth. The 43 combined settlement for the soils and the soil/bentonite layer is estimated to be about 2.7 centimeters. 44 This amount of settlement is expected to have minimal impact on overall liner or basin stability 45 (Chen-Northem 199 1b). Settlement calculations are provided in Calculations for Liquid Effluent 46 Retention Facility Part B Permit Application (HNF 1997). 47 Addendum C.36

WA7890008967 LERF and 200 Area ETF 1 The load bearing capacity of the foundation material, based on the soil analysis discussed previously, is 2 estimated at about 48,800 kilograms per square meter [maximum advisable presumptive bearing capacity 3 (Hough 1969)]. Anticipated static and dynamic loading from a full basin is estimated to be less than 4 9,000 kilograms per square meter (Section C.5.2.1.3), which provides an ample factor of safety. 5 When the basins are empty, excess hydrostatic pressure in the foundation materials under the liner system 6 theoretically could result in uplift and damage. However, because the native soil forming the foundations 7 is unsaturated and relatively permeable, and because the water table is located at a considerable depth 8 beneath the basins, any infiltration of surface water at the edge of the basin is expected to travel 9 predominantly downward and away from the basins, rather than collecting under the excavation itself. 10 No gas is expected in the foundation because gas-generating organic materials are not present. 11 Subsidence of undisturbed foundation materials is generally the result of fluid extraction (water or 12 petroleum), mining, or karst topography. Neither petroleum, mineral resources, nor karst are believed to 13 be present in the sediments overlying the Columbia River basalts. Potential groundwater resources do 14 exist below the LERF. Even if these sediments were to consolidate from fluid withdrawal, their depth 15 most likely would produce a broad, gently sloping area of subsidence that would not cause significant 16 strains in the LERF liner system. Consequently, the potential for subsidence related failures are expected 17 to be negligible. 18 Borings at the LERF site, and extensive additional borings in the 200 East Area, have not identified any 19 significant quantities of soluble materials in the foundation soil or underlying sediments (Last et al. 1989). 20 Consequently, the potential for sinkholes is considered negligible. 21 C.5.2.4 Liner System Exposure Prevention 22 Both primary and secondary geomembranes and the floating cover are stabilized with carbon black to 23 prevent degradation from UV light. Furthermore, none of the liner layers experience long-term exposure 24 to the elements. During construction, thin polyethylene sheeting was used to maintain optimum moisture 25 content and provide protection from the wind for the soil/bentonite layer until the secondary 26 geomembrane was laid in place. The secondary geomembrane was covered by the geonet and geotextile 27 as soon as quality control testing was complete. Once the geotextile layer was completed, drainage 28 material immediately was placed over the geotextile. The final (upper) geotextile layer was placed over 29 the drainage gravel and immediately covered by the bentonite carpet liner. This was covered 30 immediately, in turn, by the primary high-density polyethylene liner. 31 Both high-density polyethylene liners, geotextile layers, and geonet are anchored permanently to a 32 concrete wall at the top of the basin berm. During construction, liners were held in place with many 33 sandbags on both the basin bottoms and side slopes to prevent wind from lifting and damaging the 34 materials. Calculations were performed to determine the amount of fluid needed in a basin to prevent 35 wind lift damage to the primary geomembrane. Approximately 15 to 20 centimeters of solution are kept 36 in each basin to minimize the potential for uplifting the primary liner (HNF 1997). 37 The entire lining system is covered by a very low-density polyethylene floating cover that is bolted to the 38 concrete anchor wall. The floating cover prevents evaporation and intrusion from dust, precipitation, 39 vegetation, animals, and birds. A patented tensioning system is employed to prevent wind from lifting the 40 cover and automatically accommodate changes in liquid level in the basins. The cover tension 41 mechanism consists of a cable running from the flexible geosynthetic cover over a pulley on the tension 42 tower (located on the concrete anchor wall) to a dead man anchor. These anchors (blocks) simply hang 43 from the cables on the exterior side of the tension towers. The anchor wall also provides for solid 44 attachment of the liner layers and the cover, using a 6.4-millimeter batten and neoprene gasket to bolt the 45 layers to the concrete wall, effectively sealing the basin from the intrusion of light, precipitation, and 46 airborne dust (Figure C.16). 47 Addendum C.37

After the liner around the leaking section is 18 cleaned, repairs to the geomembrane will be made by the application of a piece of high-density 19 polyethylene sheeting, sufficient in size to extend approximately 8 to 15 centimeters beyond the damaged 20 area, or as recommended by the vendor. A round or oval patch will be installed using the same type of 21 equipment and criteria used for the initial field installations. 22 C.5.2.4.2 Control of Air Emissions 23 The floating covers limit evaporation of aqueous waste and releases of volatile organic compounds into 24 the atmosphere. To accommodate volumetric changes in the air between the fluid in the basin and the 25 cover, and to avoid problems related to 'sealing' the basins too tightly, each basin is equipped with a 26 carbon filter breather vent system. Any air escaping from the basins must pass through this vent, 27 consisting of a pipe that penetrates the anchor wall and extends into a carbon adsorption filter unit. 28 C.5.2.5 Liner Coverage 29 The liner system covers the entire ground surface that underlies the retention basins. The primary liner 30 extends up the side slopes to a concrete anchor wall at the top of the dike encircling the entire basin 31 (Figure C.16). 32 C.5.3 Prevention of Overtopping 33 Overtopping prevention is accomplished through administrative controls and liquid-level instrumentation 34 installed in each basin. The instrumentation includes local liquid-level indication as well as remote 35 indication at the ETF. Before an aqueous waste is transferred into a basin, administrative controls are 36 implemented to ensure overtopping will not occur during the transfer. The volume of feed to be 37 transferred is compared to the available volume in the receiving basin. The transfer is not initiated unless 38 there is sufficient volume available in the receiving basin or a cut-off level is established. The transfer 39 into the basin would be stopped when this cut-off level is reached. 40 In the event of a 25-year, 24-hour storm event, precipitation would accumulate on the basin covers. 41 Through the self-tensioning design of the basin covers and maintenance of adequate freeboard, all 42 accumulated precipitation would be contained on the covers and none would flow over the dikes or 43 anchor walls. The 25-year, 24-hour storm is expected to deliver 5.3 centimeters of rain or approximately 44 61 centimeters of snow. Cover specifications include the requirement that the covers be able to withstand 45 the load from this amount of precipitation. Because the cover floats on the surface of the fluid in the 46 basin, the fluid itself provides the primary support for the weight of the accumulated precipitation. Addendum C.38

--- Page 893 ---
WA7890008967 LERF and 200 Area ETF I Through the cover self-tensioning mechanism, there is ample 'give' to accommodate the overlying load 2 without overstressing the anchor and attachment points. 3 Rainwater and snow evaporate readily from the cover, particularly in the arid Hanford Facility climate, 4 where evaporation rates exceed precipitation rates for most months of the year. The black color of the 5 cover further enhances evaporation. Thus, the floating cover prevents the intrusion of precipitation into 6 the basin and provides for evaporation of accumulated rain or snow. 7 C.5.3.1 Freeboard 8 Under current operating conditions, 0.61 meter of freeboard is maintained at each LERF basin, which 9 corresponds to an operating level of 6.8 meters, or 29.5 million liters. 10 C.5.3.2 Immediate Flow Shutoff 11 The mechanism for transferring aqueous waste is either through pump transfers with on/off switches or 12 through gravity transfers with isolation valves. These methods provide positive ability to shut off 13 transfers immediately in the event of overtopping. Overtopping a basin during a transfer is very unlikely 14 because the low flow rate into the basin provides long response times. At a flow rate of 284 liters per 15 minute, approximately 11 days would be required to fill a LERF basin from the 6.8-meter operating level 16 (i.e., 0.61 meter of freeboard) to maximum capacity of 34 million liters (i.e., the 7.4-meter level). 17 C.5.3.3 Oufflow Destination 18 Aqueous waste in the LERF is transferred routinely to 200 Area ETF for treatment. However, should it 19 be necessary to immediately empty a basin, the aqueous waste either would be transferred to the 200 Area 20 ETF for treatment or transferred to another basin (or basins), whichever is faster. If necessary a 21 temporary pumping system may be installed to increase the transfer rate. 22 C.5.4 Structural Integrity of Dikes 23 The structural integrity of the dikes was certified attesting to the structural integrity of the dikes, signed 24 by a qualified, registered professional engineer. 25 C.5.4.1 Dike Design, Construction, and Maintenance 26 The dikes of the LERF are constructed of onsite native soils, generally consisting of cobbles and gravels. 27 Well-graded mixtures were specified, with cobbles up to 15 centimeters in the largest dimension, but not 28 constituting more than 20 percent of the volume of the fill. The dikes are designed with a 3:1 (3 units 29 horizontal to 1 unit vertical) slope on the basin side, and 2.25:1 on the exterior side. The dikes are 30 approximately 8.2 meters high from the bottom of the basin, and 3 meters above grade. 31 Calculations were performed to verify the structural integrity of the dikes (HNF 1997). The calculations 32 demonstrate that the structural strength of the dikes is such that, without dependence on any lining 33 system, the sides of the basins can withstand the pressure exerted by the maximum allowable quantity of 34 fluid in the impoundment. The dikes have a factor of safety greater than 2.5 against failure by sliding. 35 C.5.4.2 Dike Stability and Protection 36 In the following paragraphs, various aspects of stability for the LERF dikes and the concrete anchor wall 37 are presented, including slope failure, hydrostatic pressure, and protection from the environment. 38 Failure in Dike/Impoundment Cut Slopes. A slope stability analysis was performed to determine the 39 factor of safety against slope failure. The computer program 'PCSTABL5' from Purdue University, using 40 the modified Janbu Method, was employed to evaluate slope stability under both static and seismic 41 loading cases. One hundred surfaces per run were generated and analyzed. The assumptions used were 42 as follows (Chen-Northem 1991b): 43 * Weight of gravel: 2,160 kilograms per cubic meter. 44 * Maximum dry density of gravel: 2,315 kilograms per cubic meter.
