WA7890008967 PUREX Storage Tunnels 1 11.0 CLOSURE AND FINANCIAL ASSURANCE 2 Closure of the Plutonium Uranium Extraction Facility (PUREX) Storage Tunnels requires coordination 3 with closure of the PUREX Plant to ensure a cost effective closure for both units. In addition, the nature 4 of the mixed waste located within the PUREX Plant and PUREX Storage Tunnels precludes the 5 determination of the type of treatment and/or disposition of the waste at this time. 6 The PUREX Storage Tunnels will be managed as a Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) 7 storage unit until closure can be coordinated with the final closure plan for the PUREX Plant. The 8 PUREX Storage Tunnels closure plan will be submitted after any required National Environmental 9 Policy Act of 1969 documentation and land usage agreements, which initiate disposition and aid in 10 identifying or developing necessary disposition activities, have been adopted. The PUREX Storage 11 Tunnels closure plan will be submitted for the Washington State Department of Ecology (Ecology) 12 approval with the PUREX Plant closure plan. 13 The PUREX Storage Tunnels closure plan will be written to meet the requirements of Washington 14 Administrative Code (WAC) 173-303-140 and WAC 173-303-610. This closure plan might consider but 15 will not be limited to the following options for either in situ disposal or retrieval/clean closure of this 16 unit. 17 Federal facilities are not required to comply with WAC 173-303-620 as is stated in the regulations and as 18 described in Hanford Facility RCRA Permit, WA7890008967 (Permit) Condition II.H.3. 19 11.1 In Situ Disposal Options 20 This closure plan might consider but will not be limited to the following options for in situ disposal of 21 waste in this unit. 22 11.1.1 Backfilling the PUREX Storage Tunnels with Gravel 23 This option could involve backfilling the tunnels with gravel to eliminate void space and prevent ground 24 subsidence. A modified commercially available centrifugal rock-throwing device could be placed in 25 newly constructed risers evenly spaced along each tunnel roof. Fill material could be supplied and 26 dispersed into the tunnels by automated controls. Following the fill process, all equipment could be 27 removed from the tunnel roofs and all means of access to the tunnels could be permanently sealed. Final 28 activities could involve the construction of a final surface barrier that meets RCRA landfill cover 29 requirements to prevent water from leaching mixed waste contained in the tunnels. 30 11.1.2 Injecting the PUREX Storage Tunnels with Grout 31 This option could involve the injection of grout material into each tunnel to stabilize and immobilize 32 contained materials and prevent ground subsidence. A grout injector could be alternately placed in 33 newly constructed risers evenly spaced along each tunnel roof. Grout material could be supplied and 34 dispersed into the tunnels by automated controls. The grout material could be injected in lifts to 35 accommodate curing and heat dissipation normally associated with the use of this type of material. Final 36 activities could involve the construction of a final surface barrier that meets RCRA landfill cover 37 requirements to prevent water from leaching mixed waste contained in the tunnels. 38 11.1.3 Combination of Grout Injection and Backfilling 39 This option combines grout injection with gravel backfilling similar to the processes discussed 40 previously. Grout could be injected first to fill void spaces under the railcars and provide a basal 41 structure. Gravel could be dispersed to fill remaining void space and prevent ground subsidence. Final 42 activities could involve the construction of a final surface barrier that meets RCRA landfill cover 43 requirements to prevent water from leaching mixed waste contained in the tunnels. Chapter 11.5

--- Page 1147 ---
WA7890008967 PUREX Storage Tunnels 1 11.2 Retrieval/Clean Closure Options 2 This closure plan might consider but will not be limited to the following options for retrieval/clean 3 closure of this unit. 4 11.2.1 Retrieval and Disposal in the PUREX Plant 5 Railcars stored in both tunnels could be remotely retrieved one at a time and moved beneath the 6 horizontal door of the railroad tunnel extension for remote viewing, and if possible, characterization. 7 Transfer procedures could be initiated to move waste material from the railcars to the PUREX Plant 8 canyon deck area. Following transfer of the waste material, the railcars could be decontaminated and 9 removed for final disposition at other onsite units. Final disposition of the waste transferred to the 10 canyon deck area could be in accordance with PUREX Plant closure documentation. The PUREX 11 Storage Tunnels could be closed after submittal and implementation of a PUREX Storage Tunnels 12 closure plan in conjunction with PUREX Plant closure documentation. The PUREX Storage Tunnels 13 closure plan will detail verification sampling and analysis to be performed as a part of closure activities. 14 11.2.2 Retrieval and Physical Processing (size reduction) in the PUREX Plant and 15 Subsequent Disposal 16 Retrieval of waste material stored in the tunnels could be similar to that described in the previous section. 17 Once the waste material was transferred to the PUREX Plant canyon deck area, characterization and size 18 reduction of waste material could proceed. An area located on the canyon deck or in a process cell could 19 be modified to include all necessary equipment to perform characterization and size reduction activities. 20 Size reduction could be performed through various technologies that include, but are not limited to, flame 21 cutting, water jet cutting, sawing, or other technologies. Final disposition of the processed waste 22 material either onsite or offsite could be in accordance with regulations and procedures in place at that 23 time. The PUREX Storage Tunnels could be closed after submittal and implementation of a PUREX 24 Storage Tunnels closure plan in conjunction with PUREX Plant closure documentation. The PUREX 25 Storage Tunnels closure plan will detail verification sampling and analysis to be performed as a part of 26 closure activities. 27 11.2.3 Construction of a New Facility for Retrieval, Processing, and Treatment of 28 Equipment for Disposal 29 This option involves the construction of a new unit that is either mobile or stationary to excavate, 30 retrieve, and treat waste material stored in the tunnels. The unit could be constructed in a manner 31 consistent with the retrieval and handling requirements for large, contaminated waste material. 32 Following retrieval, the waste material could be treated in accordance with final onsite or offsite 33 disposition requirements identified at such time. The excavated tunnels could have a temporary surface 34 barrier placed in position until verification and sampling analysis could be performed as a part of closure 35 activities to be performed in conjunction with PUREX Plant closure. These signs will be written in 7 English, legible from a distance of 7.6 meters, and visible from any approach to the active portion. 8 [WAC 173-303-310(2)(a)]. 9 E.1.1 Waiver 10 A waiver of the security procedures and equipment requirements for the PUREX Storage Tunnels is not 11 requested. WA7890008967 PUREX Storage Tunnels I F. PREPARDENESS AND PREVENTION 2 F.1 Preparedness and Prevention Requirements 3 This addendum discusses preparedness and prevention measures for the Plutonium Uranium Extraction 4 Facility (PUREX) Storage Tunnels. 5 F.1.1 Equipment Requirements 6 The following sections describe the internal and external communications systems and emergency 7 equipment required. 8 F.1.1.1 Internal Communications 9 The PUREX Storage Tunnels are not occupied and personnel entry is allowed only on a very limited basis 10 and under close supervision. Normal and emergency communications equipment (portable two-way 11 radios) is available for use. 12 F.1.1.2 External Communications 13 External communications equipment for summoning emergency assistance from the Hanford Fire 14 Department and/or emergency response teams are provided by two-way portable radios or other devices. 15 F.1.1.3 Emergency Equipment 16 Equipment included in the emergency plan for the PUREX Storage Tunnels is provided in Addendum J. 17 F.1.1.4 Water for Fire Control 18 The fire hazard associated with the operation of the PUREX Storage Tunnels is considered to be very low 19 because of the minimal amount of combustibles stored within the tunnels and the lack of an ignition 20 source. In the event it is determined there is a fire in the storage area of the tunnels, the contingency plan 21 will be activated. Because of the potential of the mixed waste stored within the tunnels to leach, the use 22 of water for fire control will be avoided if possible. Reductions of the air supply to the storage area by 23 isolation of the tunnel exhaust system, if operating, should permit the fire to self-extinguish. Should the 24 fire continue to propagate, heavy equipment and cranes will be called to the scene to cover areas of the 25 tunnels that might collapse. Heavy equipment and cranes are readily available on the Hanford Facility at 26 all times and generally are available for deployment to the scene of an emergency within 1 hour. In the 27 event that a fire resulted in the collapse of the tunnels, a recovery plan will be developed in accordance 28 with emergency response procedures included in Addendum J. The recovery plan will take into 29 consideration plans, if any, for retrieval of the waste stored within the tunnel(s). 30 F.1.2 Aisle Space Requirement 31 Requirements for aisle space are not considered appropriate for the safe operation of the PUREX Storage 32 Tunnels and were not included in design documents. 33 F.2 Preventive Procedures, Structures, and Equipment 34 The following sections describe preventive procedures, structures, and equipment. 35 F.2.1 Unloading Operations 36 Operation of the PUREX Storage Tunnels does not involve the loading or unloading of dangerous waste. 37 All loading and unloading operations are conducted at the PUREX Facility or other onsite units. 38 Therefore, the requirements of WAC 173-303-806(4)(a)(viii)(A) are not applicable to the PUREX 39 Storage Tunnels. Addendum F.5

--- Page 1161 ---
WA7890008967 PUREX Storage Tunnels 1 F.2.2 Runoff 2 The design of the PUREX Storage Tunnels included consideration and provisions for the control of runoff 3 and run-on. Construction of both tunnels included the application of a moisture barrier before placement 4 of the soil overburden. On Tunnel Number 1, 40.8-kilogram mineral surface roofing was applied to the 5 external surfaces of the structural timbers (top and sides). The roofing material was nailed in place with 6 an overlap of approximately 10 centimeters at all joints and seams. All interior and exterior steel surfaces 7 of Tunnel Number 2 were coated with at least a 0.9-millimeter bituminous, solvent coal tar base, coating 8 compound. The coating was applied using a two coat system, with each coat not less than 9 0.45 millimeters, ensuring a total dry film thickness of not less than 0.9 millimeter. 10 The soil overburden covering the PUREX Storage Tunnels also is contoured to provide a side slope of 11 2 (horizontal) to 1 (vertical). This construction serves to divert any seasonal or unanticipated run-on 12 away from the storage area of the PUREX Storage Tunnels. For potential situations where a natural 13 catastrophic event occurs, inspections of the tunnel side slopes are conducted to ensure the contours 14 remain in a condition that ensures proper runoff and continues to divert run-on away from the tunnel 15 storage areas. 16 Run-on at the PUREX Storage Tunnels is controlled by the design features of the exterior of the tunnels 17 that serve to divert run-on away from the interior of the tunnels. Additionally, all waste within the tunnels 18 is stored well above the floor level on railcars. The control of run-on combined with the storage of all 19 waste above the floor elevation provides adequate assurance that runoff will not occur at the PUREX 20 Storage Tunnels. 21 F.2.3 Water Supplies 22 Water was supplied to the PUREX Storage Tunnels from the PUREX Plant. This water was used for the 23 sole purpose of filling the water-fillable doors should it have been determined necessary. There are no 24 other sources or uses of water at the PUREX Storage Tunnels. The line that supplied water to the 25 PUREX Storage Tunnels was blanked and emptied during deactivation activities. In the future, a 26 temporary source of water would be provided for filling the water fillable door. 27 F.2.4 Equipment and Power Failures 28 The procedures, structures, and equipment used to mitigate the effects of equipment failure and power 29 outage are described in the following sections. 30 F.2.4.1 Mitigation of the Effects of Equipment Failure 31 Maintaining safe storage of materials in the PUREX Storage Tunnels is not contingent on continued 32 operation of equipment. The operable equipment associated with the PUREX Storage Tunnels were the 33 remote controlled locomotive or waste placement and removal equipment, the railcars, and the water- 34 fillable door and ventilation system for both tunnels. No operable equipment is associated with either 35 tunnel, as these tunnels have been sealed and may no longer receive dangerous waste. Backup or 36 redundant systems are not provided for either tunnel, as failure of the equipment would not have the 37 potential to result in a release of dangerous waste to the environment. There are no hazards associated 38 with tunnel equipment failure. 39 F.2.4.2 Mitigation of the Effects of Power Failure 40 Maintaining safe storage of materials in the PUREX Storage Tunnels is not contingent on continued 41 supply of electrical power. Electrical power is required to operate the water-fillable door and the 42 ventilation fan in both tunnels. Backup or redundant ventilation systems are not provided as the system is 43 operated only to maintain air balance and provide secondary control of mixed waste airborne particulate. 44 Power failure to either tunnel would not have the potential to result in the release of dangerous waste or 45 mixed waste to the environment. There are no hazards associated with the shutdown of the tunnel 46 ventilation systems due to loss of electrical power. Addendum F.6

--- Page 1162 ---
WA7890008967 PUREX Storage Tunnels I F.2.5 Personnel Protection Equipment 2 Personnel entering the PUREX Storage Tunnels are required to wear special protective clothing and 3 respiratory protection at all times because of the material stored in the PUREX Storage Tunnels. 4 Protective clothing and full-face respirators with filters are considered to be sufficient protection from the 5 dangerous waste stored within the PUREX Storage Tunnels. Personnel are trained and qualified in using 6 the protective equipment and are checked routinely for mask fit. 7 F.3 Prevention of Reaction of Ignitable, Reactive, andlor Incompatible Waste 8 There is no reactive or incompatible waste stored in the PUREX Storage Tunnels. The only ignitable 9 waste stored within the tunnels is silver nitrate. The silver nitrate is present within the silver reactors 10 (deposited on unglazed ceramic packing) stored in Tunnel Number 2. 11 Although silver nitrate exhibits the characteristic of ignitability, it is contained within stainless steel 12 vessels, stored on railcars above the floor level, and isolated from combustible materials and other 13 dangerous waste. Additional measures to prevent reaction of the ignitable waste are not considered 14 necessary. 15 Addendum F.7

WA7890008967 PUREX Storage Tunnels 1 1. INSPECTION REQUIREMENTS 2 This Addendum discusses the inspection requirements for dangerous waste management units within the 3 Plutonium Uranium Extraction Facility (PUREX) Storage Tunnels. 4 1.1 PUREX Storage Tunnels 5 Because waste within the PUREX Storage Tunnels is inaccessible and exposure to the mixed waste would 6 be extremely hazardous to personnel, inspection of the tunnel interior will not be performed. External 7 inspections of the tunnels will be performed annually. The inspection schedule, log, and records will be 8 maintained in the Hanford Facility Operating Record, PUREX Storage Tunnels File for a minimum of 9 5 years. 10 Information from inspections will be recorded on inspection logs. The log forms are used to initiate 11 corrective action if necessary. The elements inspected at the PUREX Storage Tunnels are identified in 12 Table 1.1. Abnormal conditions are recorded, evaluated, and corrective action initiated as necessary. 13 Table 1.1. Inspection Schedule inspectionRequirement Description Freten Types of ProblemsFrequency Perform external surveillance of Annual External surfaces of the PUREX PUREX Storage Tunnels Storage Tunnels are observed for evidence of structural deterioration. Tunnel subsidence, erosion of the earth cover, and vent stack damage are of primary concern. The points of access to the PUREX Storage Tunnels are inspected to ensure warning signs are in place, visible, and legible. 14 Addendum.I.5
